title: Question 21

children: An 81-year-old man is seen for a preoperative evaluation before total right hip arthroplasty. Medical history is significant for mild cognitive impairment, COPD, chronic kidney disease, diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. Medications are topical NSAIDs, albuterol and tiotropium inhalers, metformin, and lisinopril.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal.

children.referenceRange: Blood gases, Oxygen saturation, arterial (ambient air)
children: Oxygen saturation

is 95% breathing ambient air. BMI is 24. The patient is alert and oriented. Decreased right hip range of motion, especially internal rotation, is present. Cardiac examination is normal. Pulmonary examination reveals distant breath sounds without wheezing.
Which of the following assessments would best predict surgery-related morbidity and mortality?
Frailty is a multifactorial state of decreased physiologic reserves and increased vulnerability to stressors.
Frailty is associated with perioperative complications, prolonged hospital stays, and increased mortality.
A frailty assessment (
Option C

) would best predict surgery-related morbidity and mortality and should be performed in this patient to identify increased risk. Frailty is a multifactorial state of decreased physiologic reserves and increased vulnerability to stressors. In persons older than 65 years, the estimated incidence of frailty is 10% to 20% and increases with each decade. Standardized indices to objectively measure frailty include the Frailty Index, the frailty phenotype, the FRAIL (Fatigue, Resistance, Ambulation, Illness, and Loss of weight) scale, and the Osteoporotic Fractures Frailty Scale. The FRAIL scale is the easiest to administer and score. In the perioperative period, frailty is associated with higher rates of complications, prolonged hospital stays, and increased rates of morbidity and mortality. Frailty is a risk factor for poor surgical outcomes, and thus it is important to engage the frail patient and family in conversations around decision making before elective surgeries. A frailty assessment may inform discussions with the patient and family regarding surgical techniques, pre- and postoperative strategies to minimize risk, and likely outcomes.
Screening chest radiography (
Option A

) is generally not recommended for patients undergoing surgery unless there are new signs and symptoms suggestive of undiagnosed or progressive pulmonary disease. Multiple studies have shown that chest radiographs are usually not effective at predicting postoperative outcomes or changing perioperative management. When abnormal findings are noted, they typically could have been predicted through history and physical examination.
Preoperative ECG (
Option B

) is reasonable in patients with known coronary artery disease, arrhythmia, peripheral artery disease, cerebrovascular disease, or structural heart disease undergoing moderate- to high-risk surgeries. However, ECG abnormalities in older patients are common, with a prevalence of 75% in one observational study, but are not associated with cardiac events and do not predict perioperative morbidity or mortality. Risk scores, such the Revised Cardiac Risk Index score and others, do predict perioperative morbidity and mortality.
Spirometry (
Option D

) is not useful for predicting surgical risk and should not be routinely ordered for preoperative evaluation, including in patients with COPD (as is the case for this patient). Furthermore, evidence does not support a spirometric threshold below which the risk of surgery is unacceptable and spirometry is a poor predictor of morbidity or mortality. Spirometry might be helpful in patients with obstructive airways disease if there is suspicion that the patient is not optimally treated; the presence of reversible airflow obstruction suggests the need for more aggressive therapy.

objective.__html: Screen for frailty in a preoperative geriatric patient.

references: Alvarez-Nebreda ML, Bentov N, Urman RD, et al. Recommendations for preoperative management of frailty from the Society for Perioperative Assessment and Quality Improvement (SPAQI). J Clin Anesth. 2018;47:33-42.

title: Question 22

children: A 45-year-old man is evaluated during a routine visit. He reports no symptoms, and his medical and family history are unremarkable. He does not smoke cigarettes, and he engages in moderate exercise for 150 minutes per week and consumes a Mediterranean diet. He takes no medications.
On physical examination, blood pressure is 120/78 mm Hg; other vital signs are normal. BMI is 25. The remainder of the physical examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate cardiovascular disease assessment?
The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends calculating the cardiovascular disease risk in adults aged 40 to 75 years using the Pooled Cohort Equations.
The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force does not recommend screening for coronary artery disease with either resting or exercise ECG in asymptomatic patients at low risk.
The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends calculating the cardiovascular disease risk (
Option A

) in adults aged 40 to 75 years using the Pooled Cohort Equations. This requires measurement of serum lipid levels to determine risk for an atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) event. The USPSTF recommendation has shifted away from routine measurement of serum lipid levels and toward identifying adults with a 10-year risk for a cardiovascular event that is 10% or greater. For adults 40 to 75 years of age, the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association also recommends routine assessment of traditional cardiovascular risk factors and calculation of the 10-year risk for ASCVD by using the Pooled Cohort Equations.
The USPSTF does not recommend screening for carotid artery stenosis, such as carotid artery ultrasonography (
Option B

), in the general adult population. The rationale for this recommendation is based on the very low prevalence of carotid stenosis (0.5%-1%) and the resulting high rate of false-positive results yielded by commonly used ultrasonography. Auscultation of the neck for carotid bruits is ineffective for screening as well. Screening for carotid stenosis in asymptomatic patients could lead to harm as a result of complications from unnecessary angiographic studies or endarterectomy.
The USPSTF does not recommend screening for coronary artery disease with either resting or exercise ECG (
Options C, D

) in asymptomatic patients at low risk, defined by the USPSTF as a 10-year cardiovascular event risk less than 10% using the Pooled Cohort Equations. In patients at intermediate or high risk for such events, evidence was inadequate to assess the relative benefits and harms of screening (I statement). Similarly, the American College of Physicians recommends against screening low-risk and asymptomatic adults with resting or exercise ECG.

Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in the United States, accounting for 1 of every 3 deaths among adults. The rationale for calculating cardiovascular risk is that some asymptomatic individuals between 40 and 75 years of age without a history of cardiovascular disease may have undetected atherosclerotic changes and may be candidates for preventive interventions. Assessing cardiovascular risk to identify persons that will benefit from prevention strategies is reasonable (
Option E

objective.__html: Assess cardiovascular disease risk.

references: Bibbins-Domingo K, Grossman DC, Curry SJ, et al; US Preventive Services Task Force. Statin use for the primary prevention of cardiovascular disease in adults: US Preventive Services Task Force recommendation statement. JAMA. 2016;316:1997-2007.

title: Question 23

children: A 65-year-old man is seen for a preoperative medical evaluation 2 weeks before total left shoulder arthroplasty. Medical history is significant for COPD. He was hospitalized 6 months ago for COPD exacerbation. He reports no changes in cough or sputum production. He has no shortness of breath or fever. Screening for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) with the STOP-BANG questionnaire categorizes the patient as low risk for OSA. He has a 30–pack-year history of cigarette smoking but quit smoking 6 years ago. Medications are inhaled tiotropium, beclomethasone, and albuterol.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal.

children.referenceRange: Blood gases, Oxygen saturation, arterial (ambient air)
children: Oxygen saturation

is 94% breathing ambient air. There are decreased breath sounds throughout and an increased expiratory phase. Left shoulder range of motion is painful and restricted. The remainder of the examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate perioperative pulmonary assessment?
Patients with COPD should be screened preoperatively for signs and symptoms of COPD exacerbation.
Chest radiography, arterial blood gas analysis, or spirometry is not routinely indicated in the preoperative evaluation of patients with chronic lung disease.
No further testing is required for this patient (
Option D

). Perioperative pulmonary complications include pneumonia, respiratory failure, and exacerbation of underlying lung disease. There is a limited role for routine perioperative pulmonary testing in patients with COPD. Patients with COPD should be screened preoperatively for signs and symptoms of COPD exacerbation. Patients should also be screened for obstructive sleep apnea, which is associated with adverse perioperative outcomes, including cardiac events, pulmonary complications, and ICU admissions. A validated screening tool for OSA is the 8-item STOP-BANG questionnaire. One point is assigned for each “yes” response about Snoring, Tiredness, Observed apneas, elevated blood Pressure, BMI >35, Age >50 years, Neck circumference >40 cm, and male Gender. Cumulative points determine the risk for OSA: low risk, 0 to 2 points; intermediate risk, 3 to 5 points; high risk, 5 points.
Evidence for the benefit of preoperative arterial blood gas analysis (
Option A
) is lacking. The results are rarely helpful in managing patients with stable chronic lung disease or predicting clinical outcomes.
Routine preoperative chest radiography (
Option B

) is not recommended in patients with chronic lung disease unless clinical examination or history suggests a change in pulmonary status. In only approximately 2% of cases does screening chest radiography lead to changes in perioperative management, and abnormal findings can usually be predicted on the basis of clinical examination. It may be reasonable, but not necessary, to obtain chest radiographs in patients older than 70 years with chronic cardiopulmonary disease if they have not had chest radiography in the previous 6 months. Preoperative chest radiography may be indicated in patients undergoing thoracic or mediastinal surgery, which this patient is not.
Although spirometry (
Option C
) may help delineate progression of airflow obstruction due to worsening COPD, results do not change perioperative management in patients such as this one. There is no absolute value of FEV
or FEV
/FVC that precludes surgery, nor do these values help predict perioperative pulmonary complications.

objective.__html: Perform perioperative pulmonary assessment in a patient with COPD.

references: Miskovic A, Lumb AB. Postoperative pulmonary complications. Br J Anaesth. 2017;118:317-34.
doi:10.1093/bja/aex002

title: Question 24

children: A 62-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for a rash that developed over his entire body during the past week. He was discharged from the hospital 15 days ago for a COPD exacerbation. He received prednisone for 5 days and levofloxacin for 7 days. Medical history is significant for chronic plaque psoriasis that he does not treat. Medications are tiotropium and salmeterol-fluticasone.

On physical examination, the patient appears ill and is bundled in blankets and shivering. Temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F); other vital signs are normal. The rash covers 90% of body surface area. Representative skin and nail findings are
shown
Oral mucosa is normal.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Erythroderma describes the condition of erythema covering greater than 80% body surface area.
Up to 40% of cases of erythroderma are idiopathic; exacerbation of a preexisting rash (e.g., psoriasis, atopic dermatitis) and medication reaction are other common etiologies.
The most likely diagnosis is erythroderma (
Option B

), specifically erythrodermic psoriasis. Erythroderma is a descriptive term for erythema covering greater than 80% body surface area. Up to 40% of cases are idiopathic; exacerbation of a preexisting rash (e.g., psoriasis, atopic dermatitis) and medication reaction are other common etiologies. Psoriasis can flare violently to erythrodermic psoriasis after exposure to systemic glucocorticoids; for this reason, systemic corticosteroids are very rarely used for treatment of psoriasis. However, patients receiving glucocorticoids for other conditions may develop an erythrodermic flare. Erythrodermic psoriasis can be fatal, with mortality resulting from fluid loss, high-output heart failure, infection, hypothermia, or hypocalcemia (because calcium is consumed during the rapid turnover of keratinocytes).
Drug-induced hypersensitivity syndrome (DIHS) (
Option A

) occurs 2 to 6 weeks after exposure to a medication. It is characterized by polymorphous macules papules or plaques and the development of pronounced facial edema and lymphadenopathy. Nail changes are not typical of DIHS. The time course and appearance of nearly total body erythema in this patient make DIHS an unlikely diagnosis.
Lichen planus (
Option C

) typically presents as purple flat-topped pruritic papules that may exhibit a diffuse, hypertrophic form. The papules are typically purple or hyperpigmented and with thicker crusting scale, in contrast to the deep red color with fine lamellar scale seen in this patient. Although lichen planus can affect the nail, it tends to cause thinner, atrophic nails with red streaks or pterygium unguis (dorsal pterygium), which manifests as a triangular plate dystrophy.
Pemphigus vulgaris (
Option D

), an autoimmune blistering disease, presents with erosions rather than the scaly plaques seen in this patient. In addition, pemphigus vulgaris always involves the oral mucosa; this patient's mucosa is normal.
Stevens-Johnson syndrome/toxic epidermal necrolysis (SJS/TEN) (
Option E

) presents as purple dusky macules on the trunk that progress to vesicles, erosions, and ulceration. Painful mucosal erosions develop in as many as 95% of patients. This patient's diffuse erythroderma is inconsistent with SJS/TEN.

objective.__html: Diagnose erythroderma.

references: Inamadar AC, Ragunatha S. The rash that becomes an erythroderma. Clin Dermatol. 2019;37:88-98.
doi:10.1016/j.clindermatol.2018.12.002

title: Question 25

children: A 23-year-old woman is evaluated for a 1-week history of vaginal discharge and odor. The patient is sexually active with men, and her last sexual encounter was 2 weeks ago. She takes an oral contraceptive pill for contraception. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and she takes no other medications.

The external genitalia examination is normal. Pelvic examination shows a thin, gray homogenous discharge with a mild odor. The cervix is normal appearing, without discharge. Bimanual examination is unremarkable.
Vaginal pH is 5.0. Wet mount shows 30% clue cells. There are no hyphae on a potassium hydroxide preparation. Whiff test result is positive. A pregnancy test result is negative.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

text.__html: Nucleic acid amplification test for bacterial vaginosis

children: Diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis is based on the presence of at least three of the four Amsel criteria: vaginal pH greater than 4.5; thin, homogeneous vaginal discharge; a positive amine (whiff) test result in which application of 10% potassium hydroxide to vaginal secretions results in a fishy odor; and at least 20% clue cells on saline wet mount.
Recommended treatment of bacterial vaginosis includes metronidazole (oral or vaginal gel) or clindamycin (vaginal cream).
The most appropriate management is oral metronidazole (
Option D

) for bacterial vaginosis. Bacterial vaginosis is the most common cause of vaginitis. It results from the loss of the normal hydrogen peroxide–producing lactobacilli in the vagina, with an increase in the vaginal pH that contributes to an overgrowth of
Gardnerella vaginalis

and other anaerobes. Anaerobic overgrowth results in the production of amines, causing the characteristically malodorous discharge. Diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis is based on the Amsel criteria, which requires presence of three of the following four criteria: vaginal pH greater than 4.5; thin, homogeneous vaginal discharge; a positive amine (whiff) test result in which application of 10% potassium hydroxide (KOH) to vaginal secretions results in a fishy odor; and at least 20% clue cells on saline wet mount. This patient meets all four Amsel criteria and can begin treatment for bacterial vaginosis. Recommended treatment of bacterial vaginosis includes metronidazole (oral or vaginal gel) or clindamycin (vaginal cream). Suggested alternative regimens include clindamycin (oral), secnidazole (oral), and tinidazole (oral).
Although a nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) (
Option A

) can confirm the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis, it is not required to make the diagnosis when the Amsel criteria are satisfied. Although NAAT and rapid antigen tests can be helpful in clinical settings in which there is no access to microscopy, such testing is not necessary in this situation.
Oral azithromycin (
Option B
) is the appropriate treatment for chlamydia. However, results of this patient's examination do not suggest cervicitis; her cervix was normal appearing, and no purulence was noted at the os.
Oral fluconazole (
Option C

) is an appropriate treatment for vaginal candidiasis but not for bacterial vaginosis. Patients with vaginal yeast infections typically present with itching and a thick white discharge. The diagnosis is confirmed when KOH wet mount of the discharge demonstrates yeast, hyphae, and pseudohyphae.

objective.__html: Treat bacterial vaginosis.

references: Workowski KA, Bachmann LH, Chan PA, et al. Sexually transmitted infections treatment guidelines, 2021. MMWR Recomm Rep. 2021;70:1-187.

title: Question 26

children: A 45-year-old woman is evaluated for 4-month history of persistent rhinorrhea, frontal headache, loss of smell, and malaise. She has self-treated with saline irrigation and antihistamine/decongestants.

On physical examination, vital signs are normal. Nasal turbinates are swollen, and thick yellow nasal discharge is noted. Maxillae and forehead are tender to palpation. The remainder of the examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test to perform next?

Patients with chronic sinusitis, characterized by nasal congestion, purulent rhinorrhea, and headache for more than 12 weeks, should undergo either nasal endoscopy or CT of the sinuses for diagnostic purposes.
In patients with chronic sinusitis, the findings most commonly seen on CT include mucosal thickening, sinus ostial obstruction, polyps, and sinus opacification.
The most appropriate diagnostic test to perform next is CT of the sinuses (
Option A

). Chronic sinusitis manifests with at least 12 weeks of nasal congestion with purulent drainage, diminished sense of smell, or facial pain/pressure. It may be associated with nasal polyposis (with a strong association with asthma). Demonstration of mucosal involvement by nasal endoscopy or imaging (typically CT) is necessary for diagnosis. The findings most commonly seen on CT scan include mucosal thickening, sinus ostial obstruction, polyps, and sinus opacification. Treatment includes glucocorticoids and antibiotics. CT without contrast is the most commonly used imaging modality for the diagnosis of chronic sinusitis.
Although mucosal disease can be demonstrated with MRI (
Option B

), CT has higher resolution and better diagnostic accuracy for mucosal disease and sinus ostial occlusion. In addition, MRI is more costly than CT and does not provide a more accurate diagnosis. MRI should be considered when there is suspicion for infection or inflammation that extends beyond the sinus cavities.

The possibility of infection with unusual or resistant organisms is suggested by the persistence of symptoms despite previous antibiotic therapy. In this case, it is important to obtain bacterial and/or fungal cultures directly from the sinus via nasal endoscopy or by sinus puncture. Nasal swabs (
Option C

) are inadequate because they do not accurately predict the infecting organism and cannot be used to guide therapy. This patient has no indication for bacterial and/or fungal culture at this time. Findings on CT may suggest the need for more aggressive evaluation.
Plain radiography of the sinuses (
Option D

) may show changes suggestive of chronic sinusitis, including sinus opacification and mucosal thickening. These findings, however, are nonspecific. Furthermore, plain radiography lacks sufficient sensitivity to determine the presence or extent of potential bony erosion by infection.

objective.__html: Evaluate a patient with suspected chronic sinusitis.

references: Kwah JH, Peters AT. Nasal polyps and rhinosinusitis. Allergy Asthma Proc. 2019;40:380-4.

title: Question 27

children: A 42-year-old man is evaluated for premature ejaculation. He reports that during sexual intercourse, he ejaculates within 30 seconds after vaginal penetration, which causes him significant psychological distress. He has no decrease in libido or difficulty maintaining an erection. Medical history is positive for depressive symptoms predating the onset of premature ejaculation. He takes no medications.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
Premature ejaculation is defined as ejaculation with minimal stimulation that occurs earlier than desired; treatment is indicated if associated with psychological distress.

Paroxetine monotherapy or combined with a phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitor is considered first-line treatment for premature ejaculation; complete therapeutic effect is reached within 2 to 3 weeks of use.
The most appropriate management is paroxetine (
Option B

). This patient has premature ejaculation, which is defined as ejaculation with minimal stimulation that occurs earlier than desired. Premature ejaculation that causes self-reported psychological distress in the patient or partner is an indication for treatment. The diagnosis of premature ejaculation is solely based on history. Clinicians should obtain a thorough sexual history (frequency of premature ejaculation, antecedent sexual activities, aggravating and alleviating factors, the impact of premature ejaculation, and any concomitant erectile dysfunction). Assessment for an underlying mood condition is also imperative, given the association between premature ejaculation and development of poor self-esteem and depression. Although the specific pathophysiologic mechanism of premature ejaculation is unknown, dysfunction of 5-hydroxytryptamine (5-HT) receptors and penile hypersensitivity are believed to be involved. Paroxetine and other selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are considered first-line therapy and are the most appropriate pharmacologic management option for this patient. A meta-analysis of available trials suggests that paroxetine may be the most effective SSRI. Complete therapeutic response typically occurs within 2 to 3 weeks of continuous use. Owing to upregulation of 5-HT receptors, therapeutic benefit may decline after 6 to 12 months. The combination of a SSRI plus a phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitor may be the most effective treatment for premature ejaculation but is associated with more side effects than monotherapies.
Clomipramine (
Option A

), a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) with serotonergic activity, is effective for premature ejaculation. It is considered second-line therapy, however, because TCAs have more side effects than SSRIs. Clomipramine can be used when SSRIs are either ineffective or not tolerated, but it would be inappropriate to initiate clomipramine in this patient before a trial of paroxetine.
The squeeze or start-stop technique (
Options C, D

) should not be considered in place of starting fluoxetine. The squeeze technique involves squeezing the glans of the penis when nearing orgasm until the urge to ejaculate subsides. Developed in the 1950s, the start-stop technique involves stimulating the penis until the patient feels the urge to ejaculate and then stopping until the urge subsides. This process is repeated multiple times until ejaculation. Although initial studies suggested that both methods were effective, subsequent evidence has been less convincing.
A topical anesthetic agent (
Option E

) made of 2.5% prilocaine and lidocaine is an effective therapy, resolving premature ejaculation more quickly than an SSRI, and can be used on an as-needed basis for patients who do not want to take a daily oral medication. However, in this patient with depressive symptoms, paroxetine is a better choice.

objective.__html: Manage premature ejaculation.

references: Liu H, Zhang M, Huang M, et al. Comparative efficacy and safety of drug treatment for premature ejaculation: a systemic review and Bayesian network meta-analysis. Andrologia. 2020;52:e13806.

title: Question 28

children: A 54-year-old asymptomatic woman is evaluated during a wellness visit. She has a 35–pack-year smoking history but quit smoking 12 years ago. She has no medical problems and takes no medications.
Physical examination, including vital signs, is unremarkable.
Which of the following is the most appropriate lung cancer screening strategy for this patient?

text.__html: Annual low-dose CT of the chest
One-time low-dose CT of the chest

children: The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends lung cancer screening with an annual low-dose CT of the chest for persons aged 50 years to 80 years with at least a 20-pack-year smoking history who are still smoking or who quit within the past 15 years.
Screening alone cannot prevent most lung cancer–related deaths, and smoking cessation is essential.
The most appropriate lung cancer screening strategy for this patient is annual low-dose CT of the chest (
Option B

). Smoking is the most important risk factor for the development of lung cancer, and risk increases with additional years of tobacco exposure and age. Lung cancer has a poor prognosis, and nearly 90% of persons with lung cancer die of the disease. However, early-stage non–small cell lung cancer has a better prognosis and can be treated with surgical resection. The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force guidelines recommend lung cancer screening with an annual low-dose CT scan for persons aged 50 years to 80 years with at least a 20-pack-year smoking history and who are still smoking or who quit within the past 15 years. Screening should be discontinued once a person has not smoked for 15 years or develops a health problem that substantially limits life expectancy or the ability or willingness to have curative lung surgery. Shared decision making, including providing patients with information about radiation exposure with CT, risk for false-positive diagnoses, and anxiety related to surveillance of slow-growing lung nodules, is a crucial element in making the decision to screen. Screening alone cannot prevent most lung cancer–related deaths, and smoking cessation is essential. This patient has a significant smoking history within the past 15 years and should be offered screening.
Chest radiography (
Option A

) is not an effective means of screening for lung cancer. Multiple studies have investigated chest radiography screening in patients at risk for lung cancer, and none has demonstrated a mortality benefit.
One-time screening with low-dose CT (
Option C

) is not the optimal strategy because continued annual screening is associated with the discovery of cancers that were not detected on the initial screen. Most guidelines recommend annual screening until at least the age of 74 years or until at least 15 years has passed since the patient quit smoking.
Not screening this patient for lung cancer is not the best strategy (
Option D
). Annual screening with low-dose CT in patients with a significant past or current smoking history results in a 20% to 24% reduction in lung cancer mortality.

objective.__html: Screen for lung cancer in at-risk patients.

references: Krist AH, Davidson KW, Mangione CM, et al; US Preventive Services Task Force. Screening for lung cancer: US Preventive Services Task Force recommendation statement. JAMA. 2021;325:962-70.

title: Question 29

children: A 32-year-old man is evaluated for a 2-year history of nail changes. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable. Family history is significant for plaque psoriasis in his brother. He takes no medications.
Nine of 10 fingernails are dystrophic. Nail findings are
shown
Toenails are not involved. The remainder of the skin and hair examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Nail psoriasis, which more commonly affects the fingernails than toenails, is characterized by dystrophic nails with yellow-red (oil stain) discoloration, pitting, and distal onycholysis.
The most likely diagnosis is nail psoriasis (
Option C

). Nail psoriasis is characterized by dystrophic nails with yellow-red (oil stain) discoloration caused by inflammation of the nail bed; pitting caused by inflammation of the nail matrix; and distal onycholysis (separation of nail plate from the nail bed). Other findings include nail plate thickening, distal nail plate crumbling, and splinter hemorrhages. Nail psoriasis more commonly affects the fingernails than the toenails. Nail psoriasis typically occurs in patients with psoriasis, but occasionally the nail changes may precede the skin changes. A family history of psoriasis can be helpful, as can a through physical examination looking for “hidden” areas of plaque psoriasis in the gluteal cleft, periumbilically, in the concha of the ear, and on the scalp. Nail psoriasis is strongly associated with psoriatic arthritis. Patients with psoriasis, particularly involving the nails, should be screened for psoriatic arthritis at diagnosis and follow-up.
Paronychia (
Option A
) is an infection of the nail fold. Acute paronychia is characterized by painful swelling of the nail fold, most commonly caused by
Staphylococcus aureus

. It typically affects only one nail. Chronic paronychia tends to be more insidious and involve multiple fingers. In adults, it is most often seen in those with frequent hand immersion in water. There is tender swelling in the nail folds, with missing or dystrophic cuticles. Chronic paronychia can cause ridging of the nail plate. These findings are not present in this patient, making chronic paronychia an unlikely diagnosis.
Lichen planus (
Option B

) can affect the nails in about 10% of cases. It causes nail plate dystrophy, including longitudinal roughness and ridging, nail thinning, red-streaking, and pterygium unguis formation (scarring of the proximal nail fold and matrix), as
shown
This patient's findings are inconsistent with nail lichen planus.
In patients with onychomycosis (
Option D

), the toenails are more commonly affected than fingernails. This patient's toenails are not involved. Nail pitting is not seen in onychomycosis but is present in this patient's nails. At times, it can be difficult to exclude onychomycosis by physical examination alone. In such cases, potassium hydroxide preparation, periodic acid-Schiff staining, or fungal culture is indicated.

objective.__html: Diagnose nail psoriasis.

references: Hinshaw MA, Rubin A. Inflammatory diseases of the nail unit. Semin Cutan Med Surg. 2015;34:109-16.

title: Question 30

children: A 69-year-old woman is seen for a preoperative medical evaluation before total right hip arthroplasty. Medical history is significant for hypertension, degenerative joint disease, and hypothyroidism. There has been no recent change in her clinical status or medications. Review of systems is negative. Medications are levothyroxine, chlorthalidone, and lisinopril.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. BMI is 22. There is restricted and painful range of right hip motion. The remainder of the physical examination is normal.
Two months ago, thyroid-stimulating hormone measurement and serum electrolytes were normal. No other laboratory findings are available.
Which of the following is the most appropriate preoperative laboratory testing for this patient?
Urinalysis is not indicated before joint arthroplasty in asymptomatic patients.
Patients whose laboratory test results in the past 4 months were normal and whose clinical status is stable do not need repeat testing before surgery.
The most appropriate preoperative laboratory testing for this patient is hemoglobin and serum creatinine measurement (
Option B

). Preoperative laboratory testing is primarily driven by patient-related factors. Overtesting in the preoperative period is common and leads to higher costs and additional downstream testing, which can cause harm. Preoperative hemoglobin testing is indicated in a patient with signs or symptoms suggestive of anemia, recent blood loss, use of medications that could affect hematopoiesis, or anticipated significant blood loss. Patient-related factors that may drive preoperative serum creatinine testing include hypertension, chronic kidney disease, diabetes, cardiac disease, and medications that affect kidney function. Total hip arthroplasty is associated with significant blood loss, and establishing the patient's baseline hemoglobin level will be helpful. This patient has hypertension and is taking lisinopril, both of which can alter kidney function, and serum creatinine measurement is indicated.
In all patients undergoing surgery, a careful preoperative bleeding history, including a family history, should be obtained. Coagulation studies (
Option A

) are indicated in patients taking anticoagulants, those with known or suspected liver dysfunction, or those with a personal or family history suggestive of abnormal bleeding. A platelet count is reasonable in patients with a history of bleeding diathesis, those with a myeloproliferative disorder, those taking myelotoxic medications, or those with cirrhosis. This patient does not have indications for coagulation studies or platelet count.

This patient has been receiving thyroid hormone replacement, and her thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level was normal 2 months ago. Patients whose test results in the past 4 months were normal and have a stable clinical status do not need repeated testing before surgery; a free serum thyroxine level is unnecessary in a patient with a normal TSH level and on a stable dose of levothyroxine (
Option C

There is little evidence that treatment of asymptomatic bacteriuria will prevent postsurgical prosthetic joint infection, and it is not indicated. Inappropriate treatment of asymptomatic bacteriuria is a major driver of antimicrobial resistance, particularly in health care facilities. Treatment of asymptomatic bacteriuria is, however, indicated in patients scheduled to undergo an invasive procedure involving the urinary tract. Urinalysis (
Option D
) in this asymptomatic patient undergoing orthopedic surgery is unnecessary.

objective.__html: Obtain appropriate preoperative laboratory testing.

references: Edwards AF, Forest DJ. Preoperative laboratory testing. Anesthesiol Clin. 2018;36:493-507.

title: Question 31

children: A 39-year-old woman comes to the office to discuss bariatric surgery. She has been unable to lose weight with diet and exercise, including supervised weight loss programs. She has tried naltrexone-bupropion and phentermine-topiramate with modest success, but the weight returned after medication discontinuation. Medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus. Medications are metformin and liraglutide.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. BMI is 45. The remainder of the examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
Sleeve gastrectomy is associated with less weight loss compared with Roux-en-Y gastric bypass but fewer 30-day postoperative complications.
The most appropriate treatment for this patient is sleeve gastrectomy (
Option D

). Guidelines recommend bariatric surgery for patients with a BMI of 40 or greater or for those with a BMI of 35 or greater who have at least one serious weight-related comorbid condition, such as type 2 diabetes mellitus, obstructive sleep apnea, or knee or hip osteoarthritis. Sleeve gastrectomy is accomplished by excising the part of the stomach along the greater curvature, creating an approximately 85% reduction in size of the stomach. It results in restriction of caloric intake via early satiety with a smaller stomach and hormonal (glucagon-like peptide-1 and related hormones) appetite suppression. The smaller gastric surface area also results in less production of ghrelin, an appetite stimulant. Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) surgery has the most efficacy data and remains superior to other procedures for weight loss, but it also has the highest rate of early postoperative complications. RYGB consists of creating a small proximal gastric pouch separate from the distal stomach and creating a biliopancreatic limb that connects the Roux limb to the gastrojejunostomy. The weight loss with sleeve gastrectomy is less than RYGB surgery. Sleeve gastrectomy, however, is associated with fewer major surgical complications at 30 days than other forms of bariatric surgery. After 5 years, the two bariatric procedures do not differ in regard to health-related quality of life or major complications.
Gastric banding (
Option A
) is often complicated by band erosion and slippage. Due to complications and poor efficacy, sleeve gastrectomy is preferred.
The FDA has approved intragastric balloons (
Option B

) and vagal blockade devices, which resulted in modest weight loss in trials. However, long-term safety and efficacy data are lacking, and most insurance companies classify these devices as investigational.

This patient is taking liraglutide, which promotes weight loss, and has tried two different weight loss medications with modest initial success but experienced weight gain upon their discontinuation. This is common for patients who take weight loss medications. Orlistat (
Option C

) is less effective in achieving target weight loss than the weight loss medications that this patient has already tried. Provided that this patient has no contraindications to bariatric surgery, sleeve gastrectomy is an appropriate choice.

objective.__html: Treat obesity with sleeve gastrectomy.

references: Arterburn D, Wellman R, Emiliano A, et al; PCORnet Bariatric Study Collaborative. Comparative effectiveness and safety of bariatric procedures for weight loss: A PCORnet cohort study.

She has no chest pain, presyncope, or change in weight. Medications are tiotropium, budesonide, and albuterol inhalers; furosemide; metoprolol; lisinopril; and 2 L/min of oxygen via nasal cannula during exertion.
On physical examination, blood pressure is 145/80 mm Hg, pulse rate is 109/min, respiration rate is 24/min, and

A recent transthoracic echocardiogram showed an ejection fraction of 40%, moderate to severe right ventricle dysfunction, pulmonary artery systolic pressure of 65 mm Hg, and tricuspid regurgitation. ECG shows right bundle branch block.
Which of the following is the most appropriate preoperative management of this patient?

Patients with high-risk pulmonary hypertension undergoing noncardiac surgery have high risk for complications, including myocardial ischemia, venous thromboembolism, cardiogenic shock, and dysrhythmias, and should be evaluated by a pulmonary hypertension specialist before undergoing surgery.
The most appropriate preoperative management of this patient is to cancel surgery (
Option A

) and refer the patient for evaluation by a pulmonary hypertension (PH) specialist. In the perioperative period, PH, defined as pulmonary artery pressure (PAP) greater than 25 mm Hg, is associated with mortality rates of 4% to 24% and significant morbidity in up to 42% of patients. Potential complications of PH include myocardial infarction, arrhythmias, right ventricular (RV) failure, venous thromboembolism, and pulmonary failure. Patients with high-risk PH features, including group 1 PH (pulmonary arterial hypertension), PAP greater than 70 mm Hg, and moderate or severe RV dysfunction, should undergo a thorough preoperative risk assessment by a PH specialist. Surgery should generally be avoided in patients with severe PH. This patient has severe COPD and heart failure with reduced ejection fraction with evidence of PH and moderate to severe right ventricular dysfunction. She should be referred to a PH specialist for evaluation prior to the elective procedure.
Although increasing this patient's furosemide (
Option B

) may be indicated for heart failure and volume overload, changes to the medication regimen should be made as part of an overall treatment strategy and not as part of a preoperative evaluation. Decisions regarding medication management in the perioperative period in this patient should be made in conjunction with a PH specialist.

Most cases of PH are caused by left-sided heart disease and hypoxic respiratory disorders. Treatment is directed toward the underlying disorder. Patients with group 1 PH (which includes idiopathic and heritable pulmonary arterial hypertension, and disease related to drugs and toxins, connective tissue diseases, HIV infection, schistosomiasis, and portal hypertension) may be treated with a calcium channel blocker or vasodilator therapy, such as tadalafil (
Option C
) following vasoreactivity testing. Starting tadalafil is not indicated.
Chronic hypoxia with resultant pulmonary vasoconstriction may be a major contributor to a patient's PH, but further evaluation is necessary prior to instituting continuous oxygen therapy (
Option D

A 33-year-old woman is evaluated during a preconception counseling visit. She is nulliparous. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. She is asymptomatic, without medical problems. She received her measles, mumps, and rubella vaccine during childhood and an influenza vaccine during the most recent influenza season. She received the tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine 6 years ago and recently completed the hepatitis B vaccine series. She is unsure whether she had chickenpox. She is sexually active with her husband only. Her last Pap smear was obtained 1 year ago and was normal; human papillomavirus testing was negative. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. Her only medication is a prenatal vitamin.
A pregnancy test result is negative.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

text.__html: Obtain nucleic acid amplification test for chlamydia

children: All women considering pregnancy should be assessed for immunity to varicella and rubella.
If an already pregnant woman is not immune to either varicella or rubella, these vaccines should be administered after delivery and before hospital discharge.
The most appropriate management is to obtain a varicella antibody titer (
Option D

). All women considering pregnancy should be assessed for immunity to varicella and rubella. This patient reports receiving the measles, mumps, and rubella vaccine during childhood but is unsure whether she had varicella (chickenpox). She should have a varicella antibody titer test. If she is not immune to varicella, she should receive the varicella vaccine and be instructed to wait 4 weeks before attempting to conceive. If an already pregnant woman is not immune to either varicella or rubella, these vaccines should be administered after delivery but before hospital discharge. Immunizations to be avoided during pregnancy include live vaccines (varicella, rubella, measles, mumps, live attenuated influenza, live attenuated herpes zoster) and human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine.
All pregnant women should receive a tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine (
Option A

) between 27 weeks' and 36 weeks' gestation with each pregnancy, helping to ensure immunity to the child upon birth. Administering Tdap during pregnancy is recommended regardless of when a patient received her last tetanus vaccination. This patient is currently not pregnant and should not receive the Tdap vaccine at this visit because she is otherwise current with this vaccination.
A nucleic acid amplification test for chlamydia (
Option B

) is not indicated for this patient. Chlamydia screening of all sexually active women younger than 25 years is recommended. Women aged 25 years or older should be screened if they have sexually transmitted infection (STI) risk factors, such as new or multiple sex partners, sex partners who have multiple other partners, no or inconsistent condom use (outside a monogamous partnership), previous STI, current STI, or exchanging sex for money or drugs. This patient is not high risk, and although screening for STIs is considered routine during pregnancy, it is not necessary during preconception care.
A Pap smear is not indicated (
Option C

). The patient's last Pap smear was obtained 1 year ago and was normal; HPV testing was negative. Women aged 30 to 39 years who have a normal Pap smear and a negative HPV test result do not require another Pap smear for 5 years.

objective.__html: Provide preconception care for an average-risk woman.

title: Question 34

children: A 51-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for a 2-day history of sloughing skin in his mouth and on his face, neck, trunk, and arms. His eyes are unaffected, and he reports no dysuria. He has no other symptoms. Medical history is significant for rosacea treated with doxycycline for the past 6 months.
On physical examination, the patient is not toxic appearing. Vital signs are normal. The rash is
shown

Other areas of involvement include the face, neck, chest, and proximal arms. Erosions are also noted across the buccal mucous and the hard and soft palates. There is no conjunctival, urethral, or perineal involvement.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune blistering disorder that presents with flaccid oral or other mucosal bullae that rupture easily and leave erosions.
Bullous pemphigoid is an autoimmune blistering disease that features tense bullae with pruritus as the predominant symptom.
The most likely diagnosis is pemphigus vulgaris (
Option C

), an autoimmune bullous disease (ABD). ABDs are caused by antibodies interfering with cohesion between keratinocytes of the epidermis (desmosomes) or between the epidermis and dermis (basement membrane zone). ABDs can be subdivided into intraepidermal and subepidermal disorders. Intraepidermal ABDs present with flaccid vesicles that rupture easily, whereas subepidermal ABDs show intact, tense bullae. Pemphigus vulgaris is the most common intraepidermal ABD, and its incidence increases with age. It presents with flaccid oral or other mucosal bullae that rupture easily and leave erosions. Lesions heal with pigment change but otherwise do not scar. This patient has an acute onset of a blistering disorder. Pemphigus vulgaris always involves the oral mucosa and may affect the skin in varying degrees.
Bullous pemphigoid (
Option A
) is an ABD that features tense bullae. Although bullae may rupture and result in erosions, typically several bullae are present on examination (as
shown
. Pruritus is the predominant symptom in bullous pemphigoid.
Dermatitis herpetiformis (
Option B
) presents with clustered fragile vesicles that break down quickly, leaving small erosions on the elbows, knees, or buttocks. It intensely pruritic and does not involve the oral mucosa.
Although Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) (
Option D
) and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) (
Option E

) should be considered in any patient with desquamative features in the acute setting, several aspects of this patient's presentation make these life-threatening conditions unlikely. Patients with SJS and TEN present with significant skin pain (even in unaffected areas), malaise, and fever and typically appear toxic. Furthermore, patients with SJS and TEN present with two mucosal surfaces involved, whereas this patient has only one involved mucosal surface: the mouth. SJS or TEN occurs secondary to medication or infection, typically within 2 weeks of administration, usually shorter. Although this patient has a history of doxycycline use, it was started 6 months ago, not within the 2-week window typical for SJS and TEN.

objective.__html: Diagnose pemphigus vulgaris.

references: Kridin K. Pemphigus group: overview, epidemiology, mortality, and comorbidities. Immunol Res. 2018;66:255-70.

title: Question 35

children: A 52-year-old man is evaluated for decreased hearing and a 4-year history of tinnitus without vertigo. The patient does not notice hearing loss but has come for evaluation based on his wife's recommendation. He has no history of noise exposures. He takes no medications.

On physical examination, the whispered voice test suggests left hearing loss. Otoscopy reveals no cerumen impaction or other blockage of the external auditory canal. Tympanic membranes appear normal. Placement of a 256-Hz vibrating tuning fork midline on the forehead results in a louder sound in the right ear. For each ear, the tuning fork sound is louder when placed in front of the external ear canal compared with placement on the mastoid process.
Which of the following is the most likely cause of hearing loss in this patient?
Hearing loss is categorized according to the anatomic deficit: conductive, sensorineural, or mixed.
Conductive hearing loss is more often associated with pain or ear drainage, whereas sensorineural hearing loss is more often accompanied by tinnitus or vertigo.
The most likely cause of hearing loss in this patient is sensorineural hearing loss of the left ear (
Option C

). Hearing loss is categorized according to the anatomic deficit: conductive, sensorineural, or mixed. Conductive hearing loss is more often associated with pain or ear drainage, whereas sensorineural hearing loss is more often accompanied by tinnitus or vertigo. In patients with hearing loss, physical examination should include otoscopic examination as well as the Weber and Rinne tests. The Weber test assesses sensorineural hearing. In the Weber test, a 256-Hz vibrating tuning fork is applied to the midline forehead, bridge of the nose, or teeth. A normal result is no lateralization of loudness of the sound (sound loudness equal in both ears). In the presence of sensorineural hearing loss, the sound lateralizes (is louder) in the uninvolved ear. In this patient, the sound was louder in the right ear; thus, the left ear is impaired. The Rinne test assesses conductive hearing. In this test, the patient is asked to identify whether the tuning fork sound is louder when placed on the mastoid process (bone conduction) or when placed in front of the external auditory canal (air conduction). A normal test is associated with air conduction louder than bone conduction. This patient, with a Weber test that lateralizes to the right ear (the “good ear”) and normal conduction in the left ear (air conduction greater than bone conduction) has sensorineural hearing loss of the left ear. The most concerning condition causing chronic unilateral sensorineural hearing loss with tinnitus is an acoustic neuroma. The first diagnostic step is confirmation of the hearing loss with audiometry followed by MRI of the internal auditory meatus.
This patient has normal conductive hearing in both the right and left ears (
Options A, B
) as confirmed by the bilaterally normal Rinne test (air conduction greater than bone conduction).

The Weber test, because it bypasses the tympanic membrane and ossicles, tests sensorineural hearing. In this patient, the Weber test lateralized to the right ear (sound was louder in the right ear); this ear has normal sensorineural function (
Option D
). The sound was heard less well in the ear with impaired sensorineural function, the left ear.

objective.__html: Diagnose sensorineural hearing loss.

references: Cunningham LL, Tucci DL. Hearing loss in adults. N Engl J Med. 2017;377:2465-73.

title: Question 36

children: A 57-year-old man is evaluated for a 2-day history of mild to moderate burning left flank pain with an associated rash that appeared shortly after pain onset.
Skin findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
A dermatomal eruption of grouped vesicles or pustules on an erythematous base is consistent with the diagnosis of herpes zoster.

Oral acyclovir, valacyclovir, or famciclovir is effective for treating herpes zoster if initiated within 72 hours of presentation and can shorten the disease course as well as decrease the likelihood of postherpetic neuralgia.
The most appropriate treatment is valacyclovir (
Option B

) for this patient with herpes zoster infection. Initiation of systemic antiviral therapy (acyclovir, valacyclovir, or famciclovir) can help attenuate the duration of rash and symptoms during a herpes zoster outbreak and reduce the risk for postherpetic neuralgia if administered within the first 72 hours after onset of symptoms. Valacyclovir and famciclovir are often preferred because of possible increased efficacy and decreased frequency of dosing compared with acyclovir. This effect is best established in patients older than 50 years. Varicella-zoster virus is a DNA virus that causes varicella (chickenpox), which is an acute illness with fever and an eruption of vesicles on an erythematous base that is transmitted by respiratory droplets. After primary infection, the virus remains latent in the dorsal root or cranial ganglia. Reactivation causes herpes zoster. Prodromal symptoms, such as burning, stinging, or tingling, often occur in a localized region, followed by a dermatomal eruption of grouped vesicles or pustules on an erythematous base. The most common dermatomes affected are in the thoracic region. With involvement of the first division of the trigeminal nerve (forehead extending over upper eyelid, or nasal tip involvement), ophthalmologic evaluation is mandatory because herpes zoster ophthalmicus and possible blindness can result. If vesicles are noted in the external ear canal, evaluation by an otolaryngologist may be required because peripheral facial paralysis and auditory/vestibular symptoms can occur (Ramsay Hunt syndrome).
Whereas systemic acyclovir is an effective option for shortening symptoms and decreasing the likelihood of postherpetic neuralgia, topical acyclovir (
Option A
) or topical penciclovir is ineffective and should not be used.
Gabapentin may be useful in alleviating the pain associated with post-herpetic neuralgia once it has become established, but there is no evidence that gabapentin plus an antiviral decreases (
Option C
) the likelihood of developing postherpetic neuralgia. As is the case with glucocorticoids, gabapentin may be used as an adjunctive therapy in patients with severe pain with acute neuritis.
Although commonly prescribed in the past, evidence is insufficient to support the addition of glucocorticoids, such as prednisone (
Option D

), to antiviral therapy to reduce the symptoms of herpes zoster or the incidence of postherpetic neuralgia. Postherpetic neuralgia is defined as chronic neuropathic pain that persists for 3 months or more after the initial onset of herpes zoster. Glucocorticoids may be considered as adjunctive therapy in patients with severe acute neuritis, but this is not necessary in this patient with mild to moderate pain.

objective.__html: Treat herpes zoster.

references: Schmader K. Herpes zoster.

title: Question 37

children: A 66-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency department for severe aching pain and visual blurring in the right eye that began 2 hours ago. She describes seeing halos around lights, accompanied by a throbbing, periocular, right-sided headache and nausea. She reports no other symptoms. Medical history is significant for depression and hyperopia. Her only medication is paroxetine.

On physical examination, blood pressure is 160/94 mm Hg and pulse rate is 102/min. The right pupil is 4 mm in diameter and responds minimally to direct light. There is diffuse conjunctival injection, and the cornea appears cloudy. Visual acuity is 20/60. The globe is tense and tender to palpation. There is no erythema or edema of eyelids or surrounding eye structures. Funduscopic examination shows cupping of the optic disc. Examination of the left eye is unremarkable; visual acuity is 20/30.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Acute angle-closure glaucoma presents with sudden onset of unilateral visual disturbance, which frequently includes seeing halos around lights, accompanied by severe eye pain, eye redness, nausea, vomiting, and headache.
Patients with angle-closure glaucoma have narrow anterior chamber angles, which inhibit drainage of the aqueous fluid.
The most likely diagnosis is acute angle-closure glaucoma (ACG) (
Option A

). Acute ACG presents with unilateral visual disturbance and seeing halos around lights, often accompanied by severe eye pain, eye redness, nausea, vomiting, and headache. Patients with ACG have narrow anterior chamber angles, which inhibit drainage of the aqueous fluid; see image
shown

Attacks of acute ACG more commonly occur in the evening, when lower light levels cause mydriasis and folding back of the iris, blocking the narrow angle. Risk factors for acute ACG include older age; female sex; hyperopia; and receipt of certain drugs, such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors. Common examination findings include a mid-dilated, minimally responsive pupil; conjunctival injection; decreased visual acuity; and globe tenderness to palpation. Funduscopic examination reveals an increased cup-to-disc ratio if chronic ACG is also present. Ophthalmology referral within 1 hour of presentation is necessary to minimize risk for permanent visual loss.
Bacterial keratitis (
Option B

) is most commonly seen in patients who use contact lenses and wear their lenses overnight or improperly wash the lenses with nonsterile water. Patients with bacterial keratitis have eye pain, redness, foreign body sensation, and difficulty keeping the affected eye open. They do not see halos around lights or have nausea, vomiting, or periorbital headache, as seen in this patient.
Orbital cellulitis (
Option C

) is an infection of the globe, ocular fat, and ocular muscles of the orbit that can be both vision- and life-threatening because of potential spread into the brain. Patients with orbital cellulitis frequently have ophthalmoplegia and proptosis and not the clouded cornea and pupillary changes seen in this patient. Orbital cellulitis warrants hospitalization for intravenous antibiotics.
Patients with scleritis (
Option D

) present with a painful red eye accompanied by visual disturbance and photophobia. The cardinal sign of scleritis is edema of the sclera, often associated with a violaceous discoloration of the underlying sclera and intense dilation of episcleral blood vessels. Tenderness is invariably present. These findings are not present in this patient.

objective.__html: Diagnose acute angle-closure glaucoma.

references: Jonas JB, Aung T, Bourne RR, et al. Glaucoma. Lancet. 2017;390:2183-93.

title: Question 38

children: A 66-year-old woman is evaluated during a wellness visit. She reports no symptoms. She does not recall the last time she had a Pap smear, and medical records from her previous physician are not available. She has no history of sexually transmitted infection, gynecologic cancer, or surgical history.
Which of the following is the most appropriate cervical cancer screening strategy for this patient?

text.__html: Cervical cytology with human papillomavirus testing

children: Routine screening for cervical cancer can be discontinued at age 65 years in non–high-risk women, provided that the patient has undergone adequate prior screening.

The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force defines adequate prior screening as three consecutive negative cytology results or two consecutive negative cytology tests plus human papillomavirus test results within the past 10 years, with the most recent test occurring within 5 years.
The most appropriate cervical cancer screening strategy for this patient is cervical cytology with human papillomavirus (HPV) testing (
Option B

). Routine screening for cervical cancer can be discontinued at age 65 years in non–high-risk women, provided that the patient has undergone adequate prior screening. The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) defines adequate prior screening as three consecutive negative cytology results or two consecutive negative cytology tests plus negative HPV test results within the past 10 years, with the most recent test occurring within 5 years. Recommendations from the American Cancer Society (ACS) are similar and state that screening can be discontinued at age 65 years in patients who have appropriate negative screening in the preceding 10 years and who do not have a history of cervical intraepithelial neoplasia grade 2 or more significant disease in the preceding past 25 years. Women older than 65 years who have never been screened or in whom the adequacy of prior screening cannot be confirmed, such as this patient, should undergo screening. There is up to a 74% mortality reduction from cervical cancer in women who have never been screened. Currently, two FDA-approved primary HPV tests are available for cervical cancer screening, and both are approved as standalone cervical screening tests beginning at age 25 years. Five HPV tests are FDA-approved for co-testing (HPV testing plus cytology). The USPSTF recommends screening with cytology every 3 years, primary high-risk HPV testing every 5 years, or co-testing every 5 years. The ACS favors primary HPV testing every 5 years. When primary HPV testing is unavailable, the ACS recommends HPV co-testing every 5 years or, alternatively, cytology alone every 3 years.
Upon inspection of the cervix, lesions that are raised, bleed, or have a wart-like appearance should be biopsied, regardless of previous cytology results. Biopsy (
Option A
) is not a screening method for cervical cancer and should not be done in this patient without an acceptable indication.
Colposcopy (
Option C

) provides an illuminated, magnified view of the cervix, vagina, vulva, or anus. Colposcopy is used for patients with abnormal Pap smear results in which a cervical lesion is strongly suspected. It has no role as a primary screening modality.
Discontinuing cervical screening is not the correct strategy (
Option D
). This patient has incomplete records to substantiate previous cervical cancer screening. Therefore, cervical cancer screening should be initiated until criteria for discontinuation are met.

objective.__html: Screen for cervical cancer in older adults.

references: Curry SJ, Krist AH, Owens DK, et al; US Preventive Services Task Force. Screening for cervical cancer: US Preventive Services Task Force recommendation statement. JAMA. 2018;320:674-86.

title: Question 39

children: A 48-year-old man is evaluated for a 2-month history of a painless lesion on his left shoulder that has been increasing in size and is now 2 cm in diameter. Medical history is unremarkable.
Skin findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Nodular melanomas do not always fulfill the ABCDE diagnostic criteria; they may be uniform in color (or amelanotic) and have regular, symmetric borders, making them difficult to diagnose until a later stage.
All suspicious pigmented lesions must be biopsied.
The most likely diagnosis is nodular melanoma (
Option C

). In general, the ABCDE identifying characteristics (Asymmetry, irregular Border, multiple Colors, Diameter >6 mm, and Evolution or change over time) can help diagnose melanoma. However, nodular melanomas do not always fulfill the ABCDE diagnostic criteria. As seen in this patient, nodular melanomas may be uniform in color and have regular, symmetric borders, making them difficult to diagnose until a later stage. Some nodular melanomas may be amelanotic or have a pink hue (as
shown
, adding to the diagnostic difficulty.

Most nodular melanomas are smooth, but others are eroded and have a particularly poor prognosis. Nodular melanomas grow rapidly (fulfilling the Evolution diagnostic criterion), particularly vertical growth, and are more aggressive than other subtypes. Because of the increased thickness of the melanoma at diagnosis and aggressive behavior, prompt identification, biopsy, and treatment are imperative. All suspicious pigmented lesions must be biopsied. The preferred method to biopsy a pigmented lesion is an excisional biopsy with a 1- to 3-mm margin to obtain the entire lesion and prevent sampling error.
A hemangioma (
Option A

) is a typically red or pink benign vascular tumor. Infantile hemangiomas are common but resolve before adulthood. Cherry hemangiomas are common in adults and typically increase in number with age. Although hemangiomas can be blue or purple, they would not have the black appearance or rapid growth of this patient's nodular melanoma.
A keratoacanthoma (
Option B

) has a distinct appearance and clinical course. It appears rapidly (within 4-6 weeks) as a round pink nodule with a central, keratin-filled crater, giving it a “volcaniform” appearance. After its rapid growth, some keratoacanthomas tend to involute in 6 months. Because keratoacanthomas are difficult to differentiate from squamous cell carcinoma, they are often treated with surgical excision. The lack of a keratin-filled center and uniform black pigmentation of this patient's skin lesion differentiates it from a keratoacanthoma.
A pigmented basal cell carcinoma (BCC) (
Option D

) typically has features of a nodular BCC, such as rolled, pearly, translucent borders and arborizing telangiectasias. Use of dermoscopy can help distinguish pigmented BCC from melanoma clinically, and skin biopsy confirms the diagnosis. This patient's lesion is pigmented but has no other features of a nodular BCC.

objective.__html: Diagnose nodular melanoma.

references: Mar VJ, Chamberlain AJ, Kelly JW, et al. Clinical practice guidelines for the diagnosis and management of melanoma: melanomas that lack classical clinical features. Med J Aust. 2017;207:348-50.

title: Question 40

children: A 28-year-old woman is seen during a routine visit. She is in the third trimester of a normal pregnancy. She is up to date on all of her immunizations and received the tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis vaccine during her first pregnancy 24 months ago and the inactivated influenza vaccine just before the start of the current pregnancy. She has no medical problems. She takes a multivitamin and folic acid but no other medications or supplements.
Which of the following is the most appropriate vaccination?

text.__html: Tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis

children: Pregnant women should receive one dose of the tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis vaccine between 27 weeks' and 36 weeks' gestation with every pregnancy.
All women who are pregnant or might be pregnant during the influenza season should receive standard-dose influenza vaccination as soon as it becomes available, regardless of the stage of pregnancy.
The most appropriate vaccination is tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis (Tdap) (
Option C

). Primary vaccination against tetanus, diphtheria, and acellular pertussis consists of a five-dose vaccine series administered during childhood. Persons aged 11 to 18 years who have completed the primary series should receive one dose of the Tdap vaccine. Adults aged 19 years or older who did not receive the Tdap vaccine at age 11 years or older should receive one dose of the Tdap vaccine. All adults should receive a tetanus and diphtheria toxoids (Td) or Tdap booster every 10 years. Pregnant women should receive at least one dose of the Tdap vaccine between 27 weeks' and 36 weeks' gestation with every pregnancy. Pregnant women who had not previously been fully vaccinated against tetanus and diphtheria should also receive a Td series.
Patients should be administered the human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine series (
Option A

) at age 11 or 12 years or between the ages of 13 and 26 years if not given previously. In unvaccinated patients aged 27 to 45 years, vaccination can be considered on the basis of risk using a shared decision-making process. Vaccination is not recommended during pregnancy, although no harmful effects have been noted when inadvertently given to pregnant women and pregnancy testing is not necessary before vaccination. This patient is up to date on her immunizations, and repeating HPV vaccination during pregnancy is neither recommended nor necessary.
Influenza revaccination (
Option B

) is necessary each year, owing to frequent genetic changes in the influenza virus (antigenic drift). Annual vaccination is recommended for all individuals aged 6 months or older. All women who are pregnant or might be pregnant during the influenza season should receive standard-dose influenza vaccination as soon as it becomes available, regardless of the stage of pregnancy. Revaccinating this patient who received the vaccine just before conception is not necessary.
No vaccination (
Option D
) for this patient is incorrect. Routine vaccinations for pregnant women include Tdap vaccination and influenza vaccination during influenza season.

objective.__html: Provide tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis vaccination during pregnancy.

references: Freedman MS, Bernstein H, Ault KA; Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices. Recommended adult immunization schedule, United States, 2021.

children: A 77-year-old man is seen for a preoperative medical evaluation before elective aortofemoral bypass. He has exercise-limiting claudication despite participation in supervised exercise programs and pharmacologic intervention. Medical history is also significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus, and aortic stenosis. Medications are atorvastatin, aspirin, metoprolol, benazepril, amlodipine, metformin, liraglutide, and cilostazol.

On physical examination, vital signs are normal. Cardiac examination reveals a grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur at the right upper sternal border that radiates to the right carotid artery. The lower extremities are cool, with no palpable pulses.
Transthoracic echocardiography findings are compatible with severe calcific aortic stenosis with
left ventricular ejection fraction
of 45%, meeting the criteria for valvular intervention.
Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation regarding surgery?

text.__html: Aortic valve replacement prior to aortofemoral bypass
Aortic valve replacement plus aortofemoral bypass
Percutaneous balloon valvuloplasty prior to aortofemoral bypass
Percutaneous balloon valvuloplasty plus aortofemoral bypass

children: When valvular heart disease is diagnosed in patients being considered for elective noncardiac surgery, the first step is to review the standard criteria for intervention of the specific valve lesion.
If a patient meets standard criteria for valvular intervention, it is prudent to defer the elective noncardiac procedure and proceed to valve intervention instead.
The most appropriate recommendation regarding surgery is aortic valve replacement prior to aortofemoral bypass (
Option A

). The 2014 American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association guideline for the management of patients with valvular heart disease recommends that when valvular heart disease is diagnosed in patients being considered for elective noncardiac surgery, the first step is to review the standard criteria for intervention of the specific valve lesion. If the patient meets standard criteria for intervention, it is prudent to defer the elective noncardiac procedure and proceed to valve intervention instead. In patients with significant asymptomatic valve disease who do not meet standard criteria for intervention, the risk of the noncardiac procedure can be minimized by 1) having an accurate diagnosis of the type and severity of valve dysfunction, 2) choosing an anesthetic approach appropriate to the valve lesion, and 3) ensuring a higher level of intraoperative monitoring.
This patient has severe aortic stenosis that meets criteria for surgical intervention, which is a life-prolonging surgery. Aortofemoral bypass (
Option B

) is an effective intervention for improving symptoms, increasing functional capacity, and improving wound healing in patients with intermittent claudication or critical limb ischemia; however, the procedure is not life extending and can be postponed until the patient recovers from his aortic valve replacement.
Aortic valve replacement is the preferred treatment for patients with aortic stenosis meeting the criteria for intervention. Percutaneous balloon aortic valvotomy (
Options C, D

) is not a substitute for valve replacement. It provides only temporary improvement in valve function, has a high rate of complications, and is not lifesaving. Percutaneous balloon aortic valvulotomy might be considered in patients with severe aortic stenosis and pulmonary edema or cardiogenic shock unresponsive to standard therapy. This patient has no indication for percutaneous aortic balloon valvulotomy.

objective.__html: Treat severe aortic stenosis with valve replacement prior to elective noncardiac surgery.

references: Fleisher LA, Fleischmann KE, Auerbach AD, et al; American College of Cardiology. 2014 ACC/AHA guideline on perioperative cardiovascular evaluation and management of patients undergoing noncardiac surgery: a report of the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association Task Force on practice guidelines. J Am Coll Cardiol. 2014;64:e77-137.

title: Question 42

children: A 20-year-old woman is evaluated for a 2-day history of sore throat, nonproductive cough, nasal congestion, headache, and malaise. She has no other medical problems and does not smoke.

On physical examination, vital signs are normal. The nasal mucosa is boggy and inflamed, with clear discharge. The pharynx is erythematous. Tonsils are normal appearing. Tympanic membranes are clear. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable.
A SARS-CoV-2 rapid antigen test result is negative.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
Treatment for the common cold focuses on symptom management.
Antibiotic therapy is ineffective in the treatment for the common cold and not recommended for either shortening duration of symptoms or preventing bacterial superinfection.
The most appropriate treatment is acetaminophen (
Option A

). This patient's presentation of sore throat, cough, headache, nasal congestion, and malaise in the absence of fever, as well as the findings on physical examination, are consistent with an acute upper respiratory tract infection (URI), or the common cold. URIs are caused by a large variety of viruses, most commonly rhinovirus. Virus transmission is via inhalation or direct contact with secretions infected with viral particles. The overproduction of mucosal secretions is caused by infection of epithelial cells responsible for the mucociliary layer within the respiratory tract and oropharynx. Symptoms of an uncomplicated URI may persist for up to 2 weeks after initial infection, and cough may persist even after resolution of the acute illness. Treatment for the common cold focuses on symptom management, including reducing severity of discomfort caused by frequent coughing, sneezing, headache, sore throat, and malaise. Analgesics may help with myalgia and headache, whereas nasal symptoms may respond to intranasal cromolyn, intranasal ipratropium, or combination decongestant/antihistamines.
Antibiotic therapy, such as amoxicillin (
Option B

), is ineffective in the treatment for the common cold and is not recommended for either shortening duration of symptoms or preventing bacterial superinfection. Not prescribing antibiotics is supported by multiple guidelines as a means of decreasing health care costs, antibiotic resistance, and the potential adverse effects of antibiotics.
There is little evidence to support the use of expectorants and mucolytics, such as guaifenesin (
Option C
), in the treatment of the common cold. Although the adverse effects of these agents are minimal, they should not be recommended because of the lack of beneficial effect.
Although there is some evidence that zinc lozenges may decrease the duration of URI symptoms, adverse effects, including nausea and bad taste, are common. Zinc-containing intranasal products (
Option D
) in particular should be avoided owing to the risk for permanent anosmia.

objective.__html: Treat the common cold.

references: Harris AM, Hicks LA, Qaseem A; High Value Care Task Force of the American College of Physicians and for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Appropriate antibiotic use for acute respiratory tract infection in adults: advice for high-value care from the American College of Physicians and the centers for disease control and prevention.

children: Ann Intern Med

title: Question 43

children: A 50-year-old woman is evaluated during a routine wellness visit. Medical and family histories are unremarkable. She is in a long-term monogamous sexual relationship. When tested 10 years ago, she was HIV negative. She takes no medications.
Which of the following is the most appropriate infectious disease screening test for this patient?

text.__html: Nucleic acid amplification test for chlamydia and gonorrhea

children: One-time screening for hepatitis C virus should be completed in all patients aged 18 to 79 years.

Patients with risk factors for hepatitis C, such as individuals who engage in high-risk sexual behavior, practice unhealthy drug use, have been incarcerated, or are receiving hemodialysis, should be retested regardless of age.
The most appropriate infectious disease screening test for this patient is hepatitis C virus (HCV) antibody assay (
Option A

). Patients at highest risk for HCV include individuals who engage in high-risk sexual behavior (such as having multiple partners), practice unhealthy drug use, have been incarcerated, or are receiving hemodialysis. One-time screening for HCV should be completed in all patients aged 18 to 79 years. The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) does not promote screening in patients older than 79 years, although the CDC does not specify an upper age limit. Patients with risk factors should also be retested regardless of age.
