Screening is accomplished by testing for HCV antibody, followed by HCV RNA quantification if results of antibody testing are positive. Conventional liver chemistry testing is not sufficiently sensitive to exclude chronic HCV infection.
According to the USPSTF, screening for chlamydia and gonorrhea (
Option B

) should be performed in all sexually active women aged 24 years or younger because of increased prevalence in this population. The USPSTF believes repeat screening is reasonable in patients whose sexual history reveals new or persistent risk factors since the last negative test result. There is no indication to screen this patient for sexually transmitted infections.
The USPSTF recommends screening for syphilis (
Option C

) in persons who are at increased risk for infection. Men who have sex with men (MSM) and men and women living with HIV have the highest risk for syphilis; 61% of cases of primary and secondary syphilis occurred among MSM, and approximately one half of all MSM diagnosed with syphilis were also coinfected with HIV. Other factors associated with increased risk that clinicians should consider include history of incarceration, history of commercial sex work, and well-described regional variations.
Not screening for HCV infection is inappropriate (
Option D

). HCV is the most common chronic bloodborne pathogen in the United States and is a leading cause of complications from chronic liver disease. HCV infection is associated with more deaths than the top 60 other reportable infectious diseases combined, including HIV. Effective and safe treatment is available for patients with HCV infection, and screening for HCV should be performed and treatment provided to prevent complications of chronic liver disease and premature death.

objective.__html: Screen for hepatitis C virus.

references: Owens DK, Davidson KW, Krist AH, et al; US Preventive Services Task Force. Screening for hepatitis C virus infection in adolescents and adults: US Preventive Services Task Force recommendation statement. JAMA. 2020;323:970-5.

title: Question 44

children: A 58-year-old woman is evaluated for a 5-week history of an itchy rash on the low back. She was recently diagnosed with hepatitis C virus infection, for which she has just initiated ledipasvir-sofosbuvir. Her medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and she takes no other medications.
Skin findings on the low back are
shown
The volar wrists have lesions similar to those on the back. There is no lymphadenopathy.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Lichen planus is a T-cell–mediated disease classically presenting with pruritic purple papules that are often flat topped and characteristically erupt on the low back, volar wrists, elbows, knees, and ankles.
The most likely diagnosis is lichen planus (
Option A

). Some, but not all, studies have shown an increased prevalence of hepatitis C virus infection in patients with lichen planus. Lichen planus is a relatively common T-cell–mediated disease presenting with pruritic purple papules that are often flat topped and have a polygonal appearance. Papules characteristically erupt on the low back, volar wrists, elbows, knees, and ankles. Other variants include nail, genital, bullous, atrophic, and hypertrophic lichen planus. Mucosal lesions have lacy white streaks (Wickham striae), as
shown
in this patient, or erosions and ulcerations.

Lichen planus also exhibits the Koebner phenomenon, which describes its occurrence in areas of trauma, such as those caused by scratching. Lichen planus is typically treated with topical glucocorticoids or ultraviolet light therapy. Lichen planus tends to resolve over the course of 1 to 2 years, although oral and nail lichen planus are more persistent.
Pityriasis rosea (
Option B

) begins as a single annular patch or plaque with fine scaling (the herald patch), typically on the trunk, followed by numerous smaller skin-colored to pink papules and plaques erupting along skin cleavage lines. As a result of the Koebner phenomenon, scratching the lichen planus on the lower back can result in a linear-appearing rash, mimicking the appearance of pityriasis rosea. However, lichen planus is significantly more purple in color than pityriasis rosea and tends to erupt on the lower back, whereas pityriasis rosea tends to erupt on the upper and mid-back. This patient also has rash on her volar wrists, which would be an unusual finding in pityriasis rosea.
Psoriasis (
Option C

) has many clinical presentations, the most common being plaque psoriasis. Plaque psoriasis typically presents with thick, well-demarcated erythematous plaques with overlying silvery scale. Nail psoriasis presents with nail pitting, onycholysis (separation of the nail plate from the nail bed), and “oil spots.” Other less common subtypes include guttate psoriasis (commonly seen in pediatric patients), palmoplantar psoriasis (frequently with pustules as the primary lesion), and inverse psoriasis (often seen without scale in the intertriginous areas). This patient's purple papules do not resemble the red plaques with thick scale of psoriasis.
The rash of secondary syphilis (
Option D

) is more brownish red in color compared with the purple papules of lichen planus. Secondary syphilis also typically involves the trunk and extremities, often including the palms and soles. Involvement of the palms and soles and generalized lymphadenopathy favor the diagnosis of secondary syphilis.

objective.__html: Diagnose lichen planus.

references: Ioannides D, Vakirlis E, Kemeny L, et al. European S1 guidelines on the management of lichen planus: a cooperation of the European Dermatology Forum with the European Academy of Dermatology and Venereology. J Eur Acad Dermatol Venereol. 2020;34:1403-14.

title: Question 45

children: A 39-year-old woman is evaluated for a 6-month history of irregular, heavy menstrual periods. She reports having a menstrual period every 6 to 8 weeks and that her periods now last 9 days and are heavier than usual. She has no other symptoms. She birthed two children. Her last Pap smear was obtained 3 year ago and was normal; human papillomavirus testing was negative. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and she takes no medications.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. BMI is 36. The bimanual pelvic examination shows blood in the cervical os and normal findings.
Laboratory studies reveal a normal complete blood count. A pregnancy test result is negative.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
Risk factors for endometrial cancer include obesity (BMI ≥30); a history of unopposed estrogen (e.g., polycystic ovary syndrome, obesity); or genetic syndromes, such as Lynch or Cowden syndrome.
When presenting with abnormal uterine bleeding, women aged 45 years and older or those younger than 45 years who are at increased risk for endometrial cancer should undergo endometrial biopsy.
The most appropriate management is to obtain an endometrial biopsy (
Option C

). When presenting with abnormal uterine bleeding, premenopausal women aged 45 years or older or those younger than 45 years who are at increased risk for endometrial cancer should undergo endometrial biopsy. Risk factors for endometrial cancer include obesity (BMI ≥30); a history of unopposed estrogen (e.g., polycystic ovary syndrome, obesity); or genetic syndromes, such as Lynch or Cowden syndrome. Failure of medical management for abnormal uterine bleeding is another indication for endometrial biopsy. Because this patient is 39 years old and obese, she is at increased risk for endometrial cancer and should undergo endometrial biopsy to evaluate for hyperplasia or malignancy. In postmenopausal women with abnormal uterine bleeding, transvaginal ultrasonography can be used to evaluate the thickness of the endometrial lining; an endometrial thickness greater than 4 mm may indicate hyperplasia or malignancy and biopsy is indicated. However, in premenopausal women, endometrial thickness is not a reliable indicator because it varies with the menstrual cycle. Although transvaginal ultrasonography may be appropriate to evaluate for structural causes of abnormal bleeding, it does not substitute for an endometrial biopsy and biopsy is usually performed regardless of the ultrasound findings.
Obtaining a follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) level (
Option A

) would not assist in the evaluation of this patient. This patient's changes in menstrual bleeding may be related to perimenopausal hormone changes. However, FSH levels vary during the menstrual cycle in premenopausal women and may not be indicative of perimenopause.
Obtaining a Pap smear (
Option B

) is not appropriate management. Women older than 30 years with a normal Pap smear and a negative human papillomavirus (HPV) test result require screening every 5 years. This patient's last Pap smear was obtained 3 year ago and was normal; HPV testing was negative.
Although oral contraceptive pills (
Option D
) are an option to manage abnormal uterine bleeding, this patient requires further assessment and the exclusion of endometrial cancer before initiating treatment.

objective.__html: Evaluate a patient for endometrial cancer.

references: American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. ACOG committee opinion no. 557: Management of acute abnormal uterine bleeding in nonpregnant reproductive-aged women. Obstet Gynecol. 2013;121:891-6.

title: Question 46

children: A 56-year-old man is evaluated during a follow-up visit for diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. His father had a myocardial infarction before the age of 55 years, as did his younger brother. Has a 35–pack-year smoking history but quit smoking 3 months ago. He is sedentary. He has no other medical problems, including no history of gastrointestinal bleeding, upper gastrointestinal pain, uncontrolled hypertension, chronic kidney disease, NSAID use, or thrombocytopenia. Medications are varenicline, metformin, lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, and atorvastatin.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. BMI is 28. The remainder of the physical examination is normal.
His 10-year atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease risk is 25% using the Pooled Cohort Equations.
The patient receives counseling on therapeutic lifestyle changes, including diet, exercise, and weight control and encouragement regarding continued smoking cessation.
Which of the following is the best advice regarding antithrombotic therapy for this patient?
Aspirin may be considered in adults aged 40 to 70 years who are at higher atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease risk and are not at increased bleeding risk.
The most appropriate antithrombotic therapy for this patient is low-dose aspirin (
Option C

). Daily low-dose aspirin may be considered for primary prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) events, but the potential benefit must be balanced against the increased risk for bleeding. The American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association guidelines recommend that aspirin should be used infrequently in the routine primary prevention of ASCVD because of a lack of net benefit; specifically, low-dose aspirin may be considered for primary prevention of ASCVD in adults aged 40 to 70 years who are at higher ASCVD risk but not at increased bleeding risk. This patient is not at high risk for bleeding but is at high risk for ASCVD, making low-dose aspirin an appropriate choice.
Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT), such as the combination of aspirin and clopidogrel (
Option A

), plays an essential role in the treatment of established ASCVD. It is particularly important after myocardial infarction and in preventing thrombotic events after percutaneous intervention for coronary artery disease. Because of the increased risk for bleeding, however, DAPT does not have a role in the primary prevention of ASCVD events.

In the secondary prevention of ASCVD events, clopidogrel is recommended for patients who are aspirin intolerant. There is no indication that this patient is aspirin intolerant, and there is no recommendation to substitute clopidogrel (
Option B
) for aspirin for the primary prevention of ASCVD.
Anticoagulation has no role in the primary prevention of ASCVD. In patients with peripheral artery disease, the use of low-dose rivaroxaban (
Option D

) plus aspirin compared with aspirin alone has been associated with a significant decrease in cardiovascular mortality (1.7% vs. 2.2%) and stroke (0.7% vs. 1.4%) but a higher incidence of gastrointestinal bleeding. This patient does not have an indication for low-dose rivaroxaban.
Not recommending further management is incorrect (
Option E
). Adding low-dose aspirin to his medication regimen is an appropriate choice for this patient in light of his high risk for ASCVD and acceptable bleeding risk.

objective.__html: Prevent cardiovascular disease with low-dose aspirin.

references: Arnett DK, Blumenthal RS, Albert MA, et al. 2019 ACC/AHA guideline on the primary prevention of cardiovascular disease: a report of the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association task force on clinical practice guidelines. Circulation. 2019;140:e596-646.

title: Question 47

children: A 46-year-old woman is seen for a routine evaluation after Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery 2 months ago. She is doing well and has lost 13.6 kg (30 lb). She recently initiated an exercise program. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Her current medications are metformin, low-dose insulin glargine, chlorthalidone, lisinopril, atorvastatin, vitamin B
, vitamin D, thiamine, calcium, and a multivitamin with iron and folate.
On physical examination, blood pressure is 132/78 mm Hg; the remainder of the physical examination is normal.
Home glucose monitoring data for the previous 7 days show average fasting blood
glucose
of 108 mg/dL (6.0 mmol/L). She has experienced no episodes of hypoglycemia.
Which of the following medications should be discontinued for this patient?
After bariatric surgery, as patients lose weight, frequent reassessment of medications is required.
After bariatric surgery, in patients with diabetes mellitus, preemptive lowering of hypoglycemic agents is recommended to prevent the development of hypoglycemia.
The most appropriate medication to discontinue is insulin glargine (
Option B

). Weight loss is rapid during the first few months after bariatric surgery. Following Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) surgery, patients lose on average 4.5 to 7 kg (10-15 lb) per month, and at 6 months, the average weight loss is as much as 36 kg (80 lb). Weight should be monitored closely in the early postoperative period. As patients lose weight, frequent reassessment of medications is required. In patients with diabetes mellitus, symptoms of hypoglycemia should be sought. Because of the potential harmful effects of hypoglycemia, preemptive lowering or discontinuation of some hypoglycemic agents is recommended to prevent the development of hypoglycemia. Discontinuing this patient's basal insulin now is reasonable considering her near-normal fasting blood glucose levels.

Patients aged 40 to 75 years with diabetes should be started on a moderate-intensity statin. If additional atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk factors are present, the Pooled Cohort Equations can be used to calculate the 10-year ASCVD risk to determine whether high-intensity statin therapy is indicated. Because this patient has diabetes, she should continue therapy with atorvastatin (
Option A
) regardless of weight loss.

The American Diabetes Association hypertension treatment goal for most persons with diabetes is less than 140/90 mm Hg. Those persons with known ASCVD or at high risk (10-year ASCVD risk ≥15%) should have a blood pressure target less than 130/80 mm Hg. Guidelines from the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association advocate for a treatment target below 130/80 mm Hg for most patients with diabetes. This patient is asymptomatic and, although her blood pressure should be carefully monitored, she can continue lisinopril (
Option C
) because her blood pressure remains well controlled on current medications.
Metformin (
Option D
) does not cause hypoglycemia and should be continued, particularly if insulin glargine is to be discontinued.

The primary sites of vitamin D absorption are the jejunum and ileum, and deficiencies of vitamin D and other fat-soluble vitamins occur regularly after RYGB surgery. Calcium absorption is dependent on the presence of vitamin D. Patients require lifelong vitamin D and calcium supplementation (
Option E
) after most bariatric surgical procedures, and they should not be discontinued.

objective.__html: Manage medication for diabetes following bariatric surgery.

references: O'Kane M. Nutritional consequences of bariatric surgery - prevention, detection and management. Curr Opin Gastroenterol. 2021;37:135-44.

title: Question 48

children: A 44-year-old woman is evaluated for a 4-week history of worsening rash. She used clobetasol cream for 1 week, but the rash worsened.
Skin findings on the volar aspect of the wrist are
shown
Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test?

text.__html: Mineral oil preparation of skin scraping
Potassium hydroxide preparation of skin scraping

children: Tinea corporis is characterized by annular erythematous plaques with scale at the border.
Diagnosis of tinea corporis is made by examination of the scale with potassium hydroxide; the presence of branching hyphae is diagnostic.
A potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation of skin scraping (
Option B

) is the most appropriate diagnostic test for this patient with a superficial fungal infection. This patient has an annular erythematous plaque with scale at the border, which is characteristic of tinea corporis. The rash is likely worsening because of the patient's use of clobetasol, a potent topical glucocorticoid. Microscopic examination of skin scrapings using a KOH preparation is inexpensive and results are yielded quickly, typically within the time frame of the patient's visit. The edge of a glass slide or 15 blade is used to scrape the scale onto a glass slide. Two to three drops of KOH are then placed on the scale, and a coverslip is applied. Diagnosis of tinea is confirmed by the presence of branching hyphae under the microscope, typically at 10- or 20-power magnification, as
shown

Scabies presents with an extremely pruritic rash characterized by erythematous papules and burrows, which are commonly on the wrist, interdigital web spaces, axillae, and waistline. Diagnosis is made by microscopic identification of the mites, eggs, or feces in skin scrapings prepared with mineral oil (
Option A
). Scabies does not present as annular plaques with scale as seen in this patient, and testing for scabies is not indicated.
Shave biopsy (
Option C

) is commonly performed to diagnose both neoplastic and inflammatory skin conditions. Shave biopsy can be performed to diagnose tinea infections, but it is more expensive than KOH preparation and it may take 1 to 2 days to receive results. In addition, skin biopsy has potential morbidity, such as scarring and risk for infection. A KOH examination should be performed first and, if negative, a culture (preferred) or shave biopsy could be considered.

A Wood lamp is a handheld ultraviolet light source used to diagnose pigment disorders, such as vitiligo, and may also be used to diagnose the skin fluorescence seen in erythrasma. Although Wood lamp examination (
Option D
) may be useful in diagnosing tinea capitis, it is not helpful in diagnosing tinea corporis.

objective.__html: Diagnose superficial fungal infections using potassium hydroxide preparation.

references: Winsett FT, Patel SG, Kelly BC. Bedside diagnostics for infections: a guide for dermatologists. Am J Clin Dermatol. 2020;21:697-709.

title: Question 49

children: A 28-year-old woman is evaluated for a painless breast lump she noticed 1 week ago. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable. Her grandmother was diagnosed with breast cancer at age 72 years. Her only medication is a combined hormonal contraceptive pill.

Breast examination reveals a 1-cm, nontender, smooth, mobile, round mass on the medial aspect of the right breast. The overlying skin is normal. There is no lymphadenopathy. The left breast is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

text.__html: Repeat clinical breast examination in 6 weeks

children: Ultrasonography is the preferred imaging modality for evaluation of a breast mass in women younger than 30 years.
All women presenting with a breast mass should be evaluated by imaging even if their clinical breast examination is without concerning features.
The most appropriate management is ultrasonography of the right breast (
Option A

). Although breast cancer should be considered in all patients, most breast masses, particularly in women younger than 30 years, are benign conditions, such as cysts, fibroadenomas, fat necrosis, or lipomas. Evaluation requires consideration of breast cancer risk factors, including family history of breast or ovarian cancer; previous breast biopsies; hormonal risk factors; and a detailed history of the mass, including onset, changes with the menstrual cycle, associated symptoms, and overlying skin/nipple changes. Women younger than 30 years who present with a breast mass should first be evaluated with breast ultrasonography. Younger women have increased breast density, which decreases the sensitivity of mammography. Ultrasonography is also the preferred imaging modality in pregnant women to avoid radiation exposure. Breast ultrasound results are categorized by Breast Imaging and Reporting Data System (BI-RADS) criteria. Biopsy is recommended for category 4 and 5 findings. In addition, any suspicious findings, including a hard, fixed, or heterogenous mass on clinical breast examination (CBE), should be evaluated by biopsy, even if imaging is negative.
Diagnostic mammography (
Option B

) is an appropriate first test in a woman aged 30 years or older who presents with a breast mass. Mammography may demonstrate a mass, asymmetric density, or abnormal/pleomorphic calcifications potentially indicating breast cancer. For patients with a focal abnormality noted on mammogram, targeted ultrasonography can clarify the size of the mass, determine whether the mass is solid or cystic, and identify the margins as smooth or irregular. However, this patient is 28 years old, and therefore she should have a breast ultrasonography to evaluate the right breast mass.

All women presenting with a breast mass should be evaluated by imaging even if their CBE lacks concerning features. Findings on CBE may suggest a benign (smooth, mobile, regular) process, such as seen in this patient, or a malignant (fixed, hard, heterogeneous) process. However, the predictive value of CBE is poor, and all women require further evaluation with imaging and/or biopsy. Waiting 6 weeks to perform a repeat CBE is not the best option (
Option C
No further evaluation is inappropriate (
Option D
). Because the patient is younger than 30 years, breast ultrasonography is required to further evaluate the breast mass despite a CBE that is reassuring.

objective.__html: Evaluate a breast mass in a woman younger than 30 years.

references: Moy L, Heller SL, Bailey L, et al; Expert Panel on Breast Imaging. ACR Appropriateness Criteria® palpable breast masses. J Am Coll Radiol. 2017;14:S203-24.

title: Question 50

children: A 27-year-old woman is evaluated for a 2-week history of hives that burn and sting. Individual wheals resolve with darkening of the skin in 1 to 2 days. She also has associated fever and joint pain. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable. Other than acetaminophen for fever and joint pain, she takes no medications.

On physical examination, temperature is 38.3 °C (101 °F); other vital signs are normal. There are 2- to 3-cm wheals with pale red flares on the arms, legs, upper chest, and back. There is faint hyperpigmentation in areas where wheals have resolved. The remainder of the examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Urticarial vasculitis is characterized by urticarial lesions that last longer than 24 hours and that burn and sting rather than itch; wheals that resolve with hyperpigmentation; and associated systemic symptoms, such as fever and joint pain.
If urticarial vasculitis is suspected, skin biopsy is helpful diagnostically.
The most likely diagnosis is urticarial vasculitis (
Option D
), which is characterized by individual urticarial lesions lasting longer than 24 hours; symptoms of burning and stinging more common than itch; wheals that resolve with hyperpigmentation (as
shown
; and associated systemic symptoms, such as fever and joint pain.

When urticarial vasculitis is accompanied by decreased serum complement (C3 or C4), it is classified as hypocomplementemic urticarial vasculitis; these cases are strongly associated with systemic lupus erythematosus and glomerulonephritis. The cause of urticaria is investigated primarily by history and physical examination. Diagnostic evaluation for urticaria is not recommended unless history suggests a specific cause. If symptoms persist, laboratory tests, including a complete blood count with differential, urinalysis, erythrocyte sedimentation rate or C-reactive protein, thyroid-stimulating hormone, and liver chemistry tests, can be considered. If associated with systemic symptoms or suspicion of urticarial vasculitis, skin biopsy is helpful.

Typical urticaria lesions itch and are transient, and wheals appear and disappear within minutes to a few hours. Although individual urticarial lesions should resolve in less than 24 hours, recurrent crops of hives may last for weeks. Most cases of urticaria resolve spontaneously, and the cause is never determined (idiopathic). If the episodes last longer than 6 weeks, the condition is classified as chronic (
Option A

). The features of chronic idiopathic urticaria are inconsistent with this patient's urticarial vasculitis, a small vessel vasculitis, which burn and sting and with individual wheals persisting longer than 24 hours.
Angioedema (
Option B

) is a transient, localized subcutaneous or submucosal form of urticaria caused by extravasation of fluid into interstitial tissues. Angioedema may occur with or without urticaria and can be a component of anaphylaxis. The margins of the affected areas are often indistinct, and the skin may be a normal hue or faintly pink. The localized swelling, indistinct margins, and normal or faint color of angioedema are distinct from the findings in urticaria.
Urticarial drug reaction (
Option C

) is an unlikely diagnosis, given that this patient has no history of new medications with the exception of acetaminophen, which was initiated after she developed systemic symptoms from the urticarial vasculitis.

objective.__html: Diagnose urticarial vasculitis.

references: Davis MD, van der Hilst JC. Mimickers of urticaria: urticarial vasculitis and autoinflammatory diseases. J Allergy Clin Immunol Pract. 2018;6:1162-70.

title: Question 51

children: A 56-year-old man is evaluated for erectile dysfunction that began insidiously 1 year ago. He reports that his libido and mood are good. He is in a monogamous relationship with his wife. He runs on a treadmill for 30 to 45 minutes three to four times weekly, and he has no cardiovascular symptoms. The patient's medical history is also significant for coronary artery bypass graft surgery 4 years ago, hyperlipidemia, and hypertension. Medications are metoprolol, losartan, aspirin, and atorvastatin.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. BMI is 24. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable.
Laboratory studies show an early morning serum
total testosterone
level of 380 ng/dL (13.18 nmol/L).
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

Phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors, such as sildenafil, tadalafil, and vardenafil, are considered first-line pharmacotherapy for erectile dysfunction and can be used by patients with known cardiovascular disease after assessment of cardiovascular risk.
Phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors should not be prescribed to patients on nitrates because of the risk for hypotension and should be used with caution in the setting of concomitant α-blocker therapy.
The most appropriate management is oral sildenafil (
Option D

). This patient with erectile dysfunction (ED) has a history of previously revascularized coronary artery disease. He is currently without cardiovascular symptoms and exercises regularly. According to the Third Princeton Consensus Conference guidelines on the safety of ED treatment in patients with cardiovascular disease, this patient is low risk and can be treated pharmacologically. Phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5) inhibitors, such as sildenafil, tadalafil, and vardenafil, are first-line pharmacotherapy for ED. All PDE-5 inhibitors have similar efficacy and are FDA approved for on-demand use. Tadalafil, which has a long half-life, is also FDA approved for daily use. It is essential to instruct patients who are prescribed PDE-5 inhibitors on proper use: The medication should be taken 30 to 60 minutes before sexual activity, and efficacy may be decreased if taken after consumption of a high-fat meal. PDE-5 inhibitors should not be prescribed to patients on nitrates because of the risk for hypotension. Similarly, they should be used with caution in the setting of concomitant α-blocker therapy. All patients with ED should also be counseled on exercising regularly, minimizing stress, losing weight if overweight, and smoking cessation.
According to the Third Princeton Consensus Conference guidelines, cardiac testing, such as an ECG (
Option A
) or an exercise stress test (
Option B
), is not required for patients at low cardiovascular risk before initiating pharmacologic therapy for ED. This patient has low cardiovascular risk, and cardiac testing is therefore not warranted.
According to the 2018 American Urological Association guideline statement, all patients with ED should have an early morning serum total testosterone measurement (
Option C
). This patient's early morning testosterone level is normal. There is no role for testosterone supplementation in patients with ED who are not androgen deficient.

objective.__html: Treat erectile dysfunction in a patient with coronary artery disease.

references: Burnett AL, Nehra A, Breau RH, et al. Erectile dysfunction: AUA guideline. J Urol. 2018;200:633-41.

title: Question 52

children: A 65-year-old man is evaluated during a follow-up visit for hypertension. He reports that he eats fruits, nuts, and vegetables daily and red meat once weekly. He drinks artificially sweetened soda daily and one alcoholic beverage most evenings with dinner. He does not smoke cigarettes. He lives alone and does not maintain social relationships and describes himself as lonely. Depression screening is negative.
In addition to traditional risk factors, which of the following is also a contributor to cardiovascular risk in this patient?
Evidence supports that loneliness and social isolation are significant risk factors for cardiovascular disease and death.
In addition to the patient's age, sex, and hypertension, a contributing factor for future cardiovascular disease in this patient is social isolation (
Option D

). There is increasing evidence supporting loneliness and specifically social isolation as risk factors for cardiovascular disease and death. A study of over 450,000 patients demonstrated that social isolation was associated with a 1.43 (95% CI, 1.3-1.55) increased risk for incident acute myocardial infarction (AMI) and 1.39 (95% CI, 1.25-1.54) increased risk for stroke. Some, but not all, of these effects were attenuated by correction for traditional risk factors for cardiovascular disease and stroke. Social isolation was also associated with a 25% increase in mortality after AMI and a 32% increase in mortality after stroke.
This patient's level of alcohol consumption (
Option A

) is considered lower risk. The 2020 Dietary Guidelines indicate that adults should limit consumption of alcohol to no more than one drink per day for nonpregnant women and two drinks per day for men. Studies have shown that this amount of alcohol consumption may reduce the risk for MI. However, it is generally agreed that individuals who prefer not to drink alcohol should not initiate alcohol consumption for the purposes of cardiovascular risk reduction.
This patient's consumption of artificially sweetened soda (
Option B

) is unlikely to be a significant contributor to cardiovascular risk. The effect of artificial sweeteners on health is uncertain. Some studies indicate that artificial sweeteners may cause weight gain and have effects on bowel health and the gut microbiome. Although artificial sweeteners have been associated with increased risk for cancer in animal models, the association has not been found in humans. Artificially sweetened beverages are often recommended as a transition from sugar-sweetened beverages to water and can also decrease dental caries in these cases.
This patient's once-weekly consumption of red meat (
Option C

) is unlikely to be a significant contributor to cardiovascular risk. Many studies have shown that frequent consumption of red meat results in a modest increased risk for cancer; diabetes; cardiovascular disease; and, in some studies, mortality. Effect sizes are generally small and inconsistent, and no randomized controlled trial data confirm this. This patient's red meat consumption is quite minimal and is unlikely to contribute to cardiovascular risk.

objective.__html: Evaluate social isolation as risk factor for cardiovascular disease.

references: Hakulinen C, Pulkki-Råback L, Virtanen M, et al. Social isolation and loneliness as risk factors for myocardial infarction, stroke and mortality: UK Biobank cohort study of 479 054 men and women. Heart. 2018;104:1536-42.

title: Question 53

children: A 68-year-old woman is evaluated for reduced vision and flashing lights in her left eye that began this morning. This was preceded by floaters in her left eye, first appearing several days ago and now with increasing frequency. She has no other symptoms. Medical history is significant for myopia. She takes no medications.

On physical examination, she has an inferior visual field defect in her left eye. Visual fields in the right eye are normal. Pupils are equally round and reactive to light and accommodation. Visual acuity is 20/60 in the left eye and 20/20 in the right eye. Nondilated funduscopic examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Retinal detachment is an ocular emergency that causes painless vision loss, unilateral flashing lights, floaters, and visual field defect.
Retinal detachment is confirmed by indirect ophthalmoscopy or wide-field retinal photography by an ophthalmologist.
The most likely diagnosis is retinal detachment (
Option D

), which is causing a painless visual field defect. Her symptoms of visual loss, flashing lights, and floaters should raise suspicion for this diagnosis, which can be confirmed by an ophthalmologist using indirect ophthalmoscopy or wide-field retinal photography. Indirect ophthalmoscopy using a condensing lens provides the ophthalmologist a wide field of vision of the retina and three-dimensional views showing elevation and depth. Because retinal detachment typically occurs far into the periphery, office-based direct ophthalmoscopy will likely be normal or at least nondiagnostic. Floaters may be described by patients as a “cobweb” and represent accompanying posterior vitreous detachment (PVD). This patient likely developed a PVD in the days preceding her presentation, which led to a retinal tear. Flashing lights represent vitreoretinal attachments stimulating retinal depolarization as they pull away from the retina. Larger retinal detachments cause more severe visual disturbances. Risk factors for retinal detachment include increasing age, myopia, and recent cataract surgery. This patient requires immediate ophthalmology referral for diagnosis and treatment to prevent further vision loss.
Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) (
Option A

) is often asymptomatic in its earliest stages. Dry AMD typically presents with gradual onset of vision loss that is most noticeable when driving or with a scotoma (blind spot). Wet AMD can present acutely with change or loss in central vision resulting from subretinal swelling and hemorrhage. Neither is typically associated with flashing lights or floaters.
Patients with central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) (
Option B

) present with abrupt, painless vision loss in one eye. The vision loss is profound, and affected patients can typically visualize only gross movements, although there may be a small area of vision in the temporal field. A complete or relative afferent pupillary defect is present, and funduscopic examination will reveal retinal paleness due to ischemic changes. These findings are absent in this patient. CRAO is most commonly associated with ipsilateral carotid artery atherosclerotic disease.
Patients with central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) (
Option C

) present with sudden onset of unilateral vision loss. On examination, an afferent pupillary defect may be present. The most common funduscopic findings are scattered, diffuse retinal hemorrhages sometimes accompanied by optic disc edema, none of which are present in this patient. Most commonly, CRVO is due to primary thrombus formation. Risk factors include increasing age, hypertension, tobacco use, and diabetes mellitus.

objective.__html: Diagnose retinal detachment.

references: Kwok JM, Yu CW, Christakis PG. Retinal detachment. CMAJ. 2020;192:E312.

title: Question 54

children: A 36-year-old woman is evaluated for a 3-month history of white patches around the eyes, legs, and feet. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and she takes no medications.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. Skin findings are
shown
Which of the following tests should be obtained?

Vitiligo, an autoimmune skin condition characterized by depigmented patches, is associated with autoimmune thyroid disease; thyroid-stimulating hormone measurement should be performed at time of diagnosis.
Thyroid-stimulating hormone measurement (
Option D

) should be obtained next to assess this patient's skin findings. This patient has vitiligo, an autoimmune skin condition characterized by depigmented patches due to loss of function or absence of melanocytes. Its onset is insidious and asymptomatic, starting as smaller macules that gradually enlarge. It tends to be more visible in persons with darker skin types or in sun-exposed areas, as the surrounding skin with preserved and functional melanocytes becomes darker with sun exposure. Vitiligo can be diagnosed clinically and presents as depigmented, well-demarcated symmetric macules or patches without scale that appear most commonly on the hands, extensor surfaces, and periorificial areas. Wood lamp examination showing intense whiteness can help confirm the diagnosis. Skin biopsies are often unnecessary but will show absence of melanocytes. Treatment can be challenging and prolonged, with suboptimal results. Potent topical glucocorticoids, topical calcineurin inhibitors (tacrolimus or pimecrolimus), and phototherapy are common treatments. Repigmentation often occurs first in perifollicular areas (as
shown

Vitiligo is associated with several autoimmune diseases, with autoimmune thyroid disease being the most common, present in about 20% of patients. Both Hashimoto thyroiditis and Graves disease are associated with vitiligo and risk increases with age. Other autoimmune disorders associated with vitiligo include alopecia areata, type 1 diabetes mellitus, pernicious anemia, rheumatoid arthritis, and polyglandular autoimmune syndrome. Additional autoantibody testing may be reasonable based on the patient's personal and family history.
Antinuclear antibody (ANA) tests (
Option A

) are often positive in patients with vitiligo. However, ANA testing should be performed only if the patient's clinical presentation is suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus or other systemic connective tissue disease. This patient has no other symptoms of connective tissue disease, and ANA, even if positive, will not be helpful diagnostically.
Hepatitis C virus infection (
Option B

) is associated with some cutaneous diseases, such as lichen planus, porphyria cutanea tarda, and leukocytoclastic vasculitis; however, it is not associated with vitiligo. Universal screening for hepatitis C is recommended for all adults aged 18 to 79 years.
HIV infection (
Option C

) is associated with conditions such as pruritus, molluscum contagiosum, and seborrheic dermatitis; however, HIV is not associated with vitiligo. Universal screening for HIV infection is recommended for adolescents and adults aged 15 to 65 years.

objective.__html: Evaluate for thyroid disease in a patient with vitiligo.

references: Taieb A, Alomar A, Böhm M, et al; Vitiligo European Task Force (VETF). Guidelines for the management of vitiligo: the European Dermatology Forum consensus. Br J Dermatol. 2013;168:5-19.

title: Question 55

children: A 60-year-old woman is evaluated for bone health during a routine wellness visit. Her mother was treated for a hip fracture after a fall at the age of 65 years. The patient is sedentary and has a 30–pack-year history of cigarette smoking but quit smoking 2 months ago. She has no medical problems and takes no medications.
Physical examination findings, including vital signs, are normal. Her weight is 56 kg (123 lb); BMI is 21.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

text.__html: Assess fracture risk with a clinical assessment tool

children: The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening for osteoporosis in all women aged 65 years or older and in women younger than 65 years who are at increased risk for osteoporosis, as determined by a formal clinical risk assessment tool.
The most appropriate next step is to assess fracture risk with a clinical assessment tool (
Option A

). The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends screening for osteoporosis in all women aged 65 years or older and in women younger than 65 years who are at increased risk for osteoporosis, as determined by a formal clinical risk assessment tool. This patient presents with several risk factors for osteoporosis and, most important, bone fracture. This patient's risk factors include low body weight (BMI of 21), cigarette smoking, and family history of hip fracture. The Fracture Risk Assessment (FRAX) is a commonly used clinical risk assessment tool (available at
www.shef.ac.uk/FRAX

). Women with a 10-year FRAX risk for major osteoporotic fracture equal to or higher than that of a 65-year-old woman without additional risk factors (10-year risk of 8.4%) should undergo screening for osteoporosis. Screening can be accomplished with bone mineral density (BMD) measurement, most commonly with dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry of the hip and lumbar spine.
BMD measurement (
Option B
) is not indicated in this patient unless a fracture risk assessment with a formal risk assessment tool (e.g., FRAX) indicates an increased risk for fracture.

The U.S. National Osteoporosis Foundation recommends pharmacologic treatment for patients with osteoporosis-related hip or spine fractures; those with a BMD T-score of -2.5 or less; and those with a BMD T-score between -1 and -2.5 with a 10-year risk of 3% or greater for hip fracture or 20% risk or greater for major osteoporosis-related fracture as estimated by the FRAX tool. This patient has yet to meet an indication for treatment with a bisphosphonate, such as alendronate (
Option C

The National Academy of Medicine recommends calcium intake of 1000 to 1200 mg/d, ideally from dietary sources. A calcium supplement may be used for patients whose diets are insufficient but should not be recommended independent of dietary assessment and intervention. Routine screening for vitamin D deficiency is not recommended in healthy populations; however, testing for deficiency is appropriate in groups at high risk or in patients presenting with low bone mass, fractures, hypocalcemia, or hyperparathyroidism. This patient has not met an indication for vitamin D measurement (
Option D

objective.__html: Assess fracture risk in a woman at high risk for osteoporosis.

references: Curry SJ, Krist AH, Owens DK, et al; US Preventive Services Task Force. Screening for osteoporosis to prevent fractures: US Preventive Services Task Force recommendation statement. JAMA. 2018;319:2521-31.

title: Question 56

children: A 76-year-old woman is seen for a preoperative medical evaluation before elective cholecystectomy. Medical history is significant for nonvalvular atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus. Medications are warfarin, metoprolol, and metformin.
Which of the following is the most appropriate perioperative management of this patient's warfarin?

text.__html: Withhold warfarin 2 days prior to surgery; restart 2 days after surgery
Withhold warfarin 5 days prior to surgery; bridge with low-molecular-weight heparin
Withhold warfarin 5 days prior to surgery; restart 12 hours after surgery
Withhold warfarin 5 days prior to surgery; restart 5 days after surgery

children: In patients undergoing major surgery, warfarin should be withheld a minimum of 5 days before surgery to normalize the INR.
In patients on chronic warfarin therapy, warfarin should be restarted within 12 to 24 hours of surgery, pending adequate hemostasis.
The most appropriate perioperative management of this patient's warfarin is to withhold warfarin 5 days prior to surgery and to restart in 12 to 24 hours after surgery (
Option C

). Warfarin should be withheld a minimum of 5 days before surgery to normalize the patient's INR. The timing of warfarin discontinuation is based on its 36- to 42-hour half-life and clinical studies documenting the time for the INR to return to normal following discontinuation. In general, 2 to 3 days are required for the INR to drop below 2 and 4 to 6 days for the INR to normalize. Some physicians obtain an INR on day 4 and intervene with vitamin K supplementation if necessary for persistently elevated INRs. Postoperative re-initiation of anticoagulation should be guided by the patient's thrombotic and bleeding risk and determined in collaboration with the surgical team. Owing to its delayed effect, the first dose of warfarin is typically administered 12 to 24 hours after surgery, pending adequate hemostasis and barring any surgical complications that may increase the risk for bleeding. It usually takes 5 to 6 days to achieve a therapeutic INR.
Withholding warfarin for only 2 days prior to surgery (
Option A

) increases the risk for surgical bleeding owing to the long half-life of warfarin. Many patients would have an INR of approximately 2 following only 2 days of warfarin discontinuation. Starting warfarin 2 or 5 days after surgery (
Option D
) is unnecessarily delayed, considering 5 to 6 days are required for full anticoagulation.
Withholding warfarin for 5 days and bridging with low-molecular-weight heparin (
Option B
) is not indicated because this may increase bleeding risk without offering any additional antithrombotic benefits in the perioperative period. This patient has a CHA
DS

-VASc score of 5 (female, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, age) without additional risk factors for bleeding and is at moderate to high risk for stroke with atrial fibrillation over the long term (7.2%-10% annually). Bridging can be considered for patients at highest risk for devastating thromboembolic disease (recent pulmonary embolism, prior stroke, high-thrombotic-risk mechanical heart valve, CHA
DS
-VASc score ≥7).

objective.__html: Manage warfarin anticoagulation in the perioperative period.

references: Lip GY, Banerjee A, Boriani G, et al. Antithrombotic therapy for atrial fibrillation: CHEST guideline and expert panel report. Chest. 2018;154:1121-201.

title: Question 57

children: A 32-year-old woman is evaluated for acute onset of right lower quadrant abdominal pain that began 1 day ago. She reports some vaginal spotting but no discharge, fever, nausea, or vomiting. She is sexually active with her husband and uses a levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine device for contraception. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and she takes no medications.

On physical examination, blood pressure is 102/74 mm Hg and pulse rate is 95/min; other vital signs are normal. Abdominal examination reveals tenderness in the right lower quadrant with no guarding. Pelvic examination reveals a normal-appearing cervix with a small amount of blood in the vault and tenderness in the right adnexa.
Complete blood count is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial diagnostic test?

text.__html: CT of the abdomen and pelvis
Nucleic acid amplification test for chlamydia and gonorrhea

children: A pregnancy test should be obtained for all women of reproductive age presenting with acute pelvic pain to rule out an ectopic pregnancy before considering other diagnoses.
In women with acute pelvic pain, transvaginal ultrasonography can assess for ectopic pregnancy, ovarian cyst, ovarian torsion, and appendicitis.
The most appropriate initial diagnostic test is a pregnancy test (
Option C

). Before considering other diagnoses, a pregnancy test should be obtained for all women of reproductive age, including women using contraception, who present with acute pelvic pain to assess the possibility of an ectopic pregnancy. Although the use of an intrauterine device (IUD) does not increase the risk for ectopic pregnancy, it is the form of failed contraception most associated with ectopic pregnancy. If a woman with acute pelvic pain does have a positive pregnancy test result, quantitative β-human chorionic gonadotropin, type and screen, and transvaginal ultrasonography should be obtained immediately, along with consultation with an obstetrician/gynecologist. Women with ectopic pregnancies may undergo surgical management or medical management with methotrexate, as directed by an obstetrician/gynecologist.
CT of the abdomen and pelvis (
Option A

) may be appropriate in the assessment of acute pelvic pain, particularly if the clinical picture is suggestive of appendicitis, but only after obtaining a negative pregnancy test result. However, CT is a second-line test in the evaluation of acute pelvic pain because ultrasonography provides better visualization to assess the likelihood of ovarian torsion and other pelvic pathology. Although this patient has right lower quadrant pain, which is concerning for appendicitis, she has no other findings, such as nausea, vomiting, or leukocytosis, to suggest the diagnosis.
Testing for sexually transmitted infections (STIs), including nucleic acid amplification test for chlamydia and gonorrhea (
Option B

), may be indicated in women presenting with acute pelvic pain. However, a pregnancy test should be obtained first. In addition, this patient did not report any signs or symptoms suggestive of an STI. She reports no vaginal discharge, and no purulent discharge was seen on pelvic examination.
Although transvaginal ultrasonography (
Option D

) can be valuable in the assessment of acute pelvic pain, a pregnancy test should be obtained first. Transvaginal ultrasonography can assess for ectopic pregnancy, ovarian cyst, ovarian torsion, and appendicitis; CT is more sensitive for appendicitis.

objective.__html: Evaluate acute pelvic pain in a reproductive-age woman.

references: Bhosale PR, Javitt MC, Atri M, et al. ACR Appropriateness Criteria® acute pelvic pain in the reproductive age group. Ultrasound Q. 2016;32:108-15.

title: Question 58

children: A 26-year-old woman is evaluated for a 1-week history of a pruritic rash on the chin. She has no other medical problems and takes no medications.
Skin findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
Nonbullous impetigo, characterized by eroded erythematous papules or plaques with honey-colored crust, can be treated with topical antibiotics, such as mupirocin or retapamulin.
The most appropriate treatment is mupirocin ointment (
Option A

). This patient has typical nonbullous impetigo, characterized by eroded erythematous papules or plaques with honey-colored crust. Impetigo is a superficial infection of the epidermis most commonly caused by
Staphylococcus aureus

or group A streptococci. Impetigo is classified as bullous or nonbullous; ecthyma is a deeper ulcerative form. Impetigo is most commonly seen in children but can present in adults. Bullous impetigo is usually caused by
S. aureus
, which produces exfoliative toxins targeting the adhesion molecule desmoglein-1 between keratinocytes. This results in localized blister formation (as
shown
Nonbullous impetigo is more common and can be caused by
S. aureus

or group A streptococci, or both. Satellite lesions are common. Nonbullous impetigo occurs on normal skin but can appear at areas of inflammatory conditions, such as atopic dermatitis. Impetigo is typically minimally symptomatic but is cosmetically distressing and easily spread to other family members. Treatment consists of washing with soap and water and removal of the crust. Topical antibiotic treatment with mupirocin or retapamulin is effective in most cases of impetigo.

Topical antibiotics are as effective as oral antibiotics in the treatment of impetigo. There is no evidence to support the combined use of a topical and an oral antibiotic for impetigo. Systemic antibiotics, such as cephalexin (
Option B
) and doxycycline (
Option C
), are helpful in cases of widespread bullous impetigo or when methicillin-resistant
S. aureus
is suspected or confirmed. However, this patient has localized nonbullous impetigo, and topical antibiotics, such as mupirocin ointment, are effective.

The classic presentation of cutaneous herpes simplex is a group of painful, small vesicles on an erythematous base, transitioning to pustules and subsequent crusting of the lesions over time. The diagnosis is typically made on clinical grounds. Oral antiviral agents (acyclovir, valacyclovir, or famciclovir) (
Option D
) can be used to treat primary infections and episodic or secondary recurrences, and as suppression or prophylaxis for patients with six or more recurrences per year.
Topical glucocorticoids, such as triamcinolone cream (
Option E

), will most likely cause this localized infection to enlarge. Topical glucocorticoids are used for their anti-inflammatory effects and are most commonly indicated in patients with eczematous dermatosis; they should not be applied to patients with bacterial, viral, or fungal infections.

objective.__html: Treat impetigo.

references: Kosar L, Laubscher T. Management of impetigo and cellulitis: simple considerations for promoting appropriate antibiotic use in skin infections. Can Fam Physician. 2017;63:615-8.

title: Question 59

children: A 49-year-old man is evaluated for influenza immunization. Two weeks ago, he underwent surgical resection for stage III colon cancer. He will begin a 3-month course of adjuvant chemotherapy in 3 weeks. He is doing well postsurgically. All other immunizations are up to date. He has no other medical problems and takes no medications.
Which of the following is the preferred influenza immunization strategy?

text.__html: Defer vaccination until completion of chemotherapy

children: In patients with active cancer, annual vaccination with the standard-dose inactivated influenza vaccine should be administered at least 2 weeks before initiation of chemotherapy or 1 week after administration of chemotherapy if between cycles.
The live attenuated influenza vaccine is contraindicated in immunocompromised patients, including those with active cancer or who are undergoing chemotherapy.
The most appropriate vaccination strategy for this patient is to administer the standard-dose inactivated influenza vaccine (
Option D

). Annual influenza vaccination is recommended for all individuals aged 6 months or older. The influenza vaccine should be administered as soon as it becomes available, preferably by October, but can be given at any time during the influenza season. Immunocompromised patients, including patients with cancer and those undergoing chemotherapy, are at risk for influenza and may be more likely to develop complications. Successful immunization requires a competent immune system to generate antibodies; although this response may be attenuated in immunocompromised patients, vaccination is still indicated. Members of this patient's immediate household should also receive the inactivated influenza vaccine. In patients undergoing chemotherapy, the vaccine should ideally be administered at least 2 weeks before initiation of chemotherapy or 1 week after administration of chemotherapy if between cycles. However, some studies have shown no difference in immunogenic response at different time points during chemotherapeutic cycles.
Deferring influenza vaccination until completion of chemotherapy (
Option A

) is not an appropriate option. Immunocompromised patients are especially prone to severe influenza infection, and a priority must be placed on preventing infections, if possible. Although chemotherapy may potentially blunt the immune response to vaccination, the vaccine should still be administered.
High-dose quadrivalent influenza vaccine (
Option B

) became available in the 2020-2021 influenza season and is an option for people aged 65 years or older. The previous high-dose trivalent vaccine was 24% more effective than its standard-dose counterpart. Estimates of relative efficacy or effectiveness of the quadrivalent high-dose vaccine compared with standard-dose quadrivalent vaccine are not available. This patient is younger than 65 years and would not benefit from the high-dose formulation.
The nasal spray influenza vaccine (
Option C

) is a live attenuated vaccine and should not be given to patients with active cancer or who are undergoing chemotherapy. The live attenuated influenza vaccine is contraindicated in immunocompromised patients and additionally should be used with caution in patients with significant medical conditions, including cardiovascular, pulmonary, or liver disease; dialysis-dependent end-stage kidney disease; or diabetes mellitus. This live attenuated vaccine should not be given to members of this patient's household. The nasal spray vaccination is otherwise an option for some individuals aged 2 through 49 years.

objective.__html: Prevent influenza in patients who are immunocompromised.

references: Freedman MS, Bernstein H, Ault KA; Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices. Recommended adult immunization schedule, United States, 2021.

children: Ann Intern Med

title: Question 60

children: A 65-year-old man is evaluated during a routine wellness examination. He reports no symptoms. Medical problems include atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and hypothyroidism. He has as a 40–pack-year history of smoking. He has one alcoholic drink nightly. Current medications are rivaroxaban, levothyroxine, hydrochlorothiazide, metoprolol, and atorvastatin. The patient also takes β-carotene, fish oil, vitamin E, and large doses of biotin. The patient expresses no desire to quit smoking at this time.
Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation regarding this patient's supplements?

Dietary supplements have questionable efficacy in improving health, and their use is associated with risk for both direct and indirect harms; the physician's role is to inform patients of potential side effects.

In patients taking anticoagulants, vitamin E and fish oil increase the risk for bleeding; β-carotene increases the risk for lung cancer in cigarette smokers; and biotin interferes with several biological assays.
The most appropriate recommendation is to stop all dietary supplements (
Option E

). Dietary supplements, including vitamins, minerals, botanicals, herbals, metabolites, and amino acids, are categorized as foods by the FDA. Therefore, manufacturers are not required to demonstrate efficacy or safety of their products unless the supplement includes ingredients that were introduced after 1994. As a result, the efficacy of most supplements has not been subject to rigorous evaluation. In addition to questionable efficacy, supplement use is associated with risk for both direct and indirect harms. Direct harms include side effects; interactions with other drugs; and harms related to inclusion of unadvertised additives, compounds, or toxins. Indirect harms occur when dietary supplement use replaces or delays standard treatments that have demonstrated efficacy. When counseling patients using supplements, the physician's role is to inform these patients of potential side effects and benefits, if known.
Biotin (
Option A

), a common over-the-counter supplement, has no known toxic effects. However, patients taking thyroid replacement and also taking more than 5 to 10 mg/d of biotin should discontinue it entirely or at least 2 to 5 days before thyroid function testing. Biotin interference causes falsely high levels of free thyroxine (T
), free triiodothyronine (T
), total T
, and total T

and a falsely low thyroid-stimulating hormone level, mimicking thyrotoxicosis. Biotin also interferes with serum troponin testing, resulting in falsely low levels, which could lead to difficulty in the diagnosis of acute coronary syndrome. Depending on the assay used, biotin can also interfere with the measurement of digoxin, ferritin, testosterone, brain natriuretic peptide, and progesterone.
Patients who are smokers and those exposed to asbestos should avoid β-carotene (
Option B

) because evidence has linked β-carotene with increased risk for lung cancer (but not with other cancers) in these populations. For this patient who continues to smoke, discontinuation of β-carotene is recommended.
Both fish oil and vitamin E (
Options C, D

) may increase the risk for bleeding in patients taking anticoagulants. This patient should be advised to stop taking fish oil and vitamin E because he is taking rivaroxaban for atrial fibrillation. Because this patient has contraindications for β-carotene, fish oil, and vitamin E and biotin may compromise the ability to monitor his thyroid disease, all supplements should be discontinued.

objective.__html: Prevent harm in patients using dietary supplements.

references: Incze M. Vitamins and nutritional supplements: what do I need to know? JAMA Intern Med. 2019;179:460.
doi:10.1001/jamainternmed.2018.5880

title: Question 61

children: A 29-year-old woman is evaluated for a 6-month history of acne that worsens during menses. She has been using topical benzoyl peroxide wash and topical tretinoin cream, but there has been no improvement. She reports no hirsutism or virilization symptoms. Menses are regular. She has no other medical problems and takes no additional medications.
Skin findings are
shown
No features of hyperandrogenism are noted.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
Spironolactone and combined oral contraceptives can be used for adult female acne in patients in whom topical therapies have failed.
Topical antibiotics are helpful in inflammatory acne because they target
Cutibacterium acnes
and have anti-inflammatory effects; they should be combined with topical benzoyl peroxide.
The most appropriate management is to start spironolactone (
Option D

). This patient has adult female–type acne, characterized by papules and nodules on the lower half of the face with marked presence on the jawline. Adult acne is more common in women and, when present, results from an abnormal response to physiologic levels of androgens. It typically presents along the jawline and often flares with the menstrual cycle. Although considered second-line therapy, oral contraceptives or spironolactone (aldosterone receptor blocker with antiandrogen activity) can be added to other treatments in women with moderate to severe acne. Spironolactone is an excellent choice for adult female acne for which topical therapies have failed. Spironolactone is a pregnancy category C (risk cannot be ruled out), and contraception is recommended when used in premenopausal women for the treatment of conditions such as hirsutism and acne.
Obtaining hormone measurements (
Option A

), such as follicle-stimulating hormone, luteinizing hormone, and free testosterone levels, is not indicated. The patient has no features that suggest hyperandrogenism, such as hirsutism, muscle mass gain, deepening of the voice, or clitoromegaly. Rapid onset of acne combined with other signs of hyperandrogenism warrants consideration of polycystic ovary syndrome, congenital adrenal hyperplasia, or an underlying adrenal or ovarian tumor.
Pelvic ultrasonography (
Option B

) might be indicated in patients with findings suspicious for polycystic ovary syndrome. However, this patient has no features of polycystic ovary syndrome, such as hirsutism or oligo-/anovulation, and pelvic ultrasonography is not indicated.
Progesterone-eluting intrauterine devices (
Option C

), as well as any other progesterone-based hormonal contraception, can exacerbate acne and would not be recommended. Combined estrogen and progesterone oral contraceptives are effective treatments for inflammatory acne in women without evidence of hyperandrogenism and would be an option for this patient.
Topical antibiotics are helpful in inflammatory acne because they target
Cutibacterium acnes

and have anti-inflammatory effects. It is recommended that topical antibiotics be combined with topical benzoyl peroxide in treatment for mild, moderate, or severe acne to avoid antibiotic resistance. The common topical antibiotics clindamycin and erythromycin are pregnancy category B, whereas topical benzoyl peroxide is pregnancy category C. Topical metronidazole cream (
Option E
) is a first-line treatment for rosacea but not for acne.

objective.__html: Manage acne in an adult woman.

references: Zaenglein AL. Acne vulgaris. N Engl J Med. 2018;379:1343-52.

title: Question 62

children: A 66-year-old woman is seen for a preoperative medical evaluation before total right knee arthroplasty. Medical history is significant for atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and peripheral vascular disease. Medications are rivaroxaban, metoprolol, losartan, and atorvastatin.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. The physical examination documents osteoarthritis of the knee and an irregular heart rhythm.
Laboratory studies show a
serum creatinine
level of 1.0 mg/dL (88.4 µmol/L) and an
estimated glomerular filtration rate
greater than 60 mL/min/1.73 m
Which of the following is the most appropriate perioperative management of the patient's rivaroxaban?

text.__html: Continue rivaroxaban until day of surgery
Withhold rivaroxaban 3 days before surgery; bridge with low-molecular-weight heparin
Withhold rivaroxaban 7 days before surgery; bridge with low-molecular-weight heparin

children: In patients with normal kidney function, withholding a direct oral anticoagulant for four half-lives (2-3 days) reduces anticoagulant levels to approximately 6.25%, resulting in near-normal bleeding risk.
Direct oral anticoagulants have a rapid onset and short half-life; thus, bridging anticoagulation is not needed.
The most appropriate perioperative management of the patient's rivaroxaban is to withhold for 3 days before surgery (
Option B

). Before elective surgery, management decisions about anticoagulant therapy are made on the basis of surgical bleeding risk, thrombotic risk off anticoagulants, kidney function, and type of drug. In this case, the patient is taking rivaroxaban, a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC), for atrial fibrillation. She has a moderate-high CHA
DS

-VASc score of 4 (hypertension, age, vascular disease, female) and normal kidney function and is undergoing a surgery with moderate bleeding risk. Because of the bleeding risk, she should not be anticoagulated at the time of surgery. In patients with normal kidney function, withholding a DOAC for four half-lives (2-3 days) reduces anticoagulant levels to approximately 6.25%, resulting in near-normal bleeding risk. Thus, withholding rivaroxaban 3 days before surgery in this patient is recommended.

Although anticoagulation can be continued until the day of surgery for select minor procedures (e.g., cataract or dental surgery), patients undergoing surgery with significant bleeding risk must have anticoagulation withheld long enough to ensure adequate drug clearance and normalization of coagulation. Continuing rivaroxaban until the day of surgery (
Option A
) places this patient at an unacceptable bleeding risk perioperatively.

Patients who are at especially high risk for thrombosis while off anticoagulants may need a pre- or postoperative anticoagulant bridge with low-molecular-weight heparin to limit time off anticoagulation. This is most relevant for drugs with a delayed onset of action and longer half-life, such as warfarin. DOACs, however, have a rapid onset and short half-life; thus, bridging anticoagulation is not needed. The BRIDGE trial demonstrated no difference in thrombotic events in patients on warfarin with atrial fibrillation who were bridged perioperatively but did observe a higher rate of bleeding in this group. Therefore, bridging anticoagulation is rarely recommended, except in the setting of very high thrombosis risk off warfarin therapy, such as atrial fibrillation with a mechanical heart valve. This patient is not at very high risk for thrombosis and is not on warfarin; therefore, bridging is not warranted (
Options C, E
Withholding rivaroxaban for 7 days before surgery (
Option D
) is unlikely to provide additional benefit from a bleeding standpoint and may increase the risk for thrombosis by lengthening the time the patient is off anticoagulation.

objective.__html: Manage direct oral anticoagulant therapy for an elective surgical procedure.

references: Lip GY, Banerjee A, Boriani G, et al. Antithrombotic therapy for atrial fibrillation: CHEST guideline and expert panel report. Chest. 2018;154:1121-201.

title: Question 63

children: A 37-year-old man is evaluated during a pre-employment examination. He is starting a new job as a medical assistant in a primary care office. Within the past 2 years, he completed his hepatitis B vaccination and the measles, mumps, and rubella vaccine series and received the tetanus and diphtheria toxoids and COVID-19 vaccines. He received the influenza vaccine during the most recent influenza season. He has no medical conditions and takes no medications.
Laboratory studies are positive for the hepatitis B surface antibody and rubella and varicella IgG antibody.
Which of the following is the most appropriate vaccine to administer to this patient?

text.__html: Tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis vaccine

children: Health care workers are at increased risk for pertussis and should receive the tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis vaccine regardless of when they received their last tetanus and diphtheria toxoids vaccine.
In addition to pertussis, health care workers are also at increased risk for influenza, hepatitis B, measles, mumps, rubella, and varicella viruses and should receive the appropriate vaccinations.
The most appropriate vaccine to administer to this health care worker is the tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine (
Option C

). Health care workers are at increased risk for acquiring and transmitting pertussis and should receive a dose of the Tdap vaccine regardless of when they received their last tetanus and diphtheria toxoids (Td) vaccine. Because this patient received only a Td vaccine, a Tdap vaccine is required at this time. Health care workers are also at increased risk for infection with influenza, hepatitis B, measles, mumps, rubella, and varicella viruses; this patient was previously vaccinated for these viruses and has documented immunity to hepatitis B, rubella, and varicella.
Hepatitis A vaccination (
Option A

) is not indicated for this patient because health care workers are not considered to be at increased risk for hepatitis A virus infection unless working in high-risk venues. Hepatitis A vaccination is recommended for adults who request it or those at increased risk for infection or complications of infections, including travelers to endemic areas, individuals with chronic liver disease, men who have sex with men, users of illicit drugs, homeless persons, persons who conduct hepatitis A–related research, household or close contacts of children adopted from endemic areas, and those who work in settings of possible exposure (group homes, nonresidential day-care facilities for developmentally disabled persons, and health care programs serving patients with unhealthy drug use).
Health care workers are not considered to be at increased risk for meningococcal disease, and thus the quadrivalent meningococcal conjugate vaccine (MenACWY) (
Option B

) is not indicated for this patient. The MenACWY vaccine is recommended for adults considered to be at increased risk, including first-year college students living in dormitories; travelers to endemic areas; microbiologists with ongoing exposure to
Neisseria meningitidis
; military recruits; those at increased risk because of an outbreak; and patients with anatomic or functional asplenia, complement deficiencies, or HIV infection.
Because health care workers are considered at increased risk for pertussis, not offering this the Tdap vaccine (
Option D
), regardless of when he received his last Td vaccine, is not the best strategy.

objective.__html: Manage vaccination of a health care worker.

references: Freedman MS, Bernstein H, Ault KA; Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices. Recommended adult immunization schedule, United States, 2021.
