title: Question 64

children: A 32-year-old woman telephones the office to request emergency contraception after an episode of unprotected sexual intercourse 4 days ago. She reports no symptoms. Medical history is unremarkable, and she takes no medications. She is out of town and is unable to come into the office for several days.
Her last recorded BMI is 28, and she reports no change in weight since her last visit 6 months ago.
Which of the following is the most appropriate emergency contraceptive option for this patient?
Oral ulipristal acetate is an effective oral emergency contraception option for women with a BMI greater than 26.
The copper intrauterine device is the most effective form of emergency contraception option and can reduce the risk for pregnancy by 99% if placed within 5 days of unprotected sexual intercourse.
The most appropriate emergency contraceptive option for this patient is the ulipristal acetate oral contraceptive pill (
Option D

). Emergency contraception refers to postcoital contraception using a device or medication to prevent pregnancy after inadequately protected intercourse. All forms of emergency contraception work by disrupting ovulation or preventing fertilization of an egg. Emergency contraceptives are not abortion-inducing interventions. FDA-approved options for emergency contraception include oral ulipristal acetate, oral levonorgestrel, or a copper intrauterine device (IUD). New data suggest that the 52-mg levonorgestrel IUD is noninferior to the copper IUD for emergency contraception, but it is not currently FDA approved for this indication. Ulipristal acetate delays ovulation. It is the preferred oral contraceptive option for women with a BMI greater than 26, such as this patient. A single oral dose of ulipristal acetate is effective for up to 5 days after unprotected sexual intercourse. Although a prescription is required for oral ulipristal acetate, an in-person medical visit is not required to provide this form of emergency contraception. The copper IUD is FDA approved for use as emergency contraception and is the most effective form of emergency contraception; it can reduce the risk for pregnancy by 99% if placed within 5 days of unprotected sexual intercourse. Copper IUDs prevent fertilization by unknown mechanisms and require a clinic visit for insertion.
Emergency contraception can be provided with off-label use of combined oral contraceptive pills (
Option A

) containing ethinyl estradiol or either norgestrel or levonorgestrel, but the dosing schedule is very different from the routine use of oral contraceptives. This method also requires a repeat dose at 12 hours. Combined oral contraceptive pills are less effective and are associated with higher rates of side effects compared with FDA-approved emergency contraceptive methods. Some experts will suggest this method to patients when cost is an issue or when quick access to FDA-approved emergency contraception is limited. Either the copper IUD or oral ulipristal acetate would be recommended as the most appropriate method for this patient.
The levonorgestrel oral contraceptive pill (
Option B

) is available over the counter (without age restriction), and a single dose is effective for emergency contraception within the 3 days after intercourse. Like ulipristal acetate, levonorgestrel delays ovulation. The effectiveness of levonorgestrel declines in women with a BMI greater than 26 and would not be recommended for this patient.
The subdermal contraceptive implant (
Option C
) is not an effective form of emergency contraception and would therefore not be appropriate for this patient.

objective.__html: Provide emergency contraception.

references: Woodhams EJ, Gilliam M. Contraception.

children: Ann Intern Med

title: Question 65

children: A 28-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency department 3 hours after sustaining a burn of the left arm while burning leaves in her backyard.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. Skin findings on the left arm are
shown
The affected area blanches with pressure. Pain is present without application of pressure.
Which of the following is the classification of this patient's burn?
Second-degree, superficial partial-thickness burns present as blisters or weeping wounds that blanch with pressure and are painful to air, temperature, and pressure.
Wound care for second-degree, partial-thickness burns includes cleaning the wound with soap and water and applying a topical antibiotic ointment followed by an appropriate dressing.
The classification of this patient's burn is second-degree, superficial partial-thickness (
Option B

), which involves the entire epidermis and penetrates into, but not through, the dermis. Because the epidermal layer is lost, the wound forms a blister or weeps interstitial fluid. The wound blanches with pressure and is painful to air, temperature, and pressure because the vessels and nerve of the dermis are still intact, unlike the case with second-degree, deep partial-thickness burns and third-degree burns. Healing occurs through re-epithelialization. Wound care for second-degree, partial-thickness burns includes cleaning the wound with soap and water and applying a topical antibiotic ointment. Specialized wound dressing will maintain a moist environment and may remain in place for several days after the injury. Surgical excision and skin grafting should be considered for wounds that do not re-epithelialize after 2 to 3 weeks.
A first-degree, or superficial, burn (
Option A
) does not penetrate through the epidermis and presents with red, tender skin but no blistering or weeping. Minimal or no treatment is required.
A second-degree, deep partial-thickness burn (
Option C

) involves destruction of the epidermis and the dermis. It presents as a wet or dry wound that is painful only to pressure. The wound may be any color, most commonly white, yellow, or red. Healing is less likely to occur with re-epithelialization, and surgical evaluation may be necessary. This patient's burn is painful without pressure, so a deep partial-thickness burn is incorrect.
In a third-degree, or full-thickness, burn (
Option D
), the entire epidermis, dermis, and fat are destroyed. These wounds are dry and often black in color (as
shown
and cause minimal pain because the nerves of the dermis have been destroyed. Excision and skin grafting are required for treatment.

objective.__html: Classify the severity of a burn.

references: Greenhalgh DG. Management of burns. N Engl J Med. 2019;380:2349-59.

title: Question 66

children: A 38-year-old man is evaluated for a 4-day history of bilateral eye redness, watery discharge, and pruritus as well as rhinitis and sneezing. He has no other symptoms. He experiences similar symptoms around the same time each year. He does not wear contact lenses. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and he takes no medications.
On physical examination, there is swelling and erythema of the conjunctiva bilaterally associated with clear, watery discharge. The remainder of the examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate topical treatment?
Perennial allergic conjunctivitis presents with bilateral eye redness, pruritus, and watery discharge.
Topical antihistamines with mast cell–stabilizing effects are first-line therapies for uncomplicated allergic conjunctivitis.
An antihistamine with mast cell–stabilizing properties is the most appropriate topical treatment (
Option B

). This patient presents with bilateral eye redness, pruritus, and watery discharge, which are characteristic of perennial allergic conjunctivitis. Allergic conjunctivitis is due to IgE-mediated mast cell degranulation, with the resultant release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators. In addition to basic eye care, including cold compresses, and avoiding eye rubbing and known allergens, topical pharmacotherapy is indicated for this patient given the degree of his symptoms. Topical agents in this category include olopatadine, alcaftadine, bepotastine, azelastine hydrochloride, cetirizine, epinastine, ketotifen fumarate, and emedastine. Generic ketotifen fumarate does not require a prescription. Although the full effect of these agents may take days, some effect is seen immediately. An advantage of this class of drugs is that it is administered only once or twice daily, depending on the specific formulation. The most common side effect is burning and stinging with application, which may be mitigated by using refrigerated agents.
Topical antibiotics (
Option A

), such as trimethoprim-polymyxin B, have no role in the treatment of uncomplicated allergic conjunctivitis. This class of drug is effective for treating acute bacterial conjunctivitis in patients who do not wear contact lenses. Factors favoring bacterial conjunctivitis include glued eyes in the morning, redness completely obscuring the tarsal vessels, purulent discharge, and a red eye observed at 20 feet. Absence of a purulent discharge makes bacterial conjunctivitis very unlikely.
Topical glucocorticoids (
Option C

), such as prednisolone, are effective for allergic conjunctivitis but are associated with serious potential side effects, including vision loss; glaucoma; corneal damage; and, with prolonged use, cataracts. They should be reserved for patients who have refractory symptoms and administered only under close supervision of an ophthalmologist for short periods. They would therefore be inappropriate to use in this patient.
A mast cell–stabilizing agent (
Option D

), such as cromolyn, is effective therapy for allergic conjunctivitis. However, it needs to be used for up to 14 days before complete efficacy is reached and requires administration four times daily, which may decrease adherence. Therefore, use is reserved for those patients in whom other therapies have failed.
Topical NSAIDs (
Option E

) function by blocking the breakdown of thromboxane. Although topical NSAIDs have some efficacy in the treatment of allergic conjunctivitis compared with placebo, they are less effective than antihistamines and are not a first-line treatment.

objective.__html: Treat allergic conjunctivitis.

references: Bielory L, Delgado L, Katelaris CH, et al. ICON: diagnosis and management of allergic conjunctivitis. Ann Allergy Asthma Immunol. 2020;124:118-34.

title: Question 67

children: A 58-year-old woman is evaluated during a routine wellness visit. She has no symptoms. She has never been screened for colorectal cancer. Family history is negative for colon cancer. She is willing to undergo colorectal cancer screening but does not want colonoscopy.
Which of the following is the most appropriate colorectal screening strategy for this patient?

text.__html: Fecal immunochemical test every 1 to 2 years
Serum circulating methylated SEPT9 DNA measurement every 1 to 2 years

children: Colorectal cancer screening would be most appropriate among adults who (1) are healthy enough to undergo treatment if colorectal cancer is detected and (2) do not have comorbid conditions that would significantly limit their life expectancy.
The preferred colorectal screening strategy is the one most likely to be completed by the patient.
An annual fecal immunochemical test (FIT) (
Option A

) is the most appropriate colorectal screening test for this patient. There is significant variation among colorectal cancer screening guidelines. The American College of Physicians suggests colonoscopy every 10 years, flexible sigmoidoscopy every 10 years plus FIT every 2 years, or FIT or high-sensitivity guaiac-based fecal occult blood testing every 2 years as acceptable screening regimens. In contrast, the U.S. Multi-Society Task Force on Colorectal Cancer (MSTF), an initiative of U.S. gastroenterology societies, has ranked colorectal cancer screening tests in tiers based on the available evidence, cost-effectiveness, test availability, and several other factors. The MSTF recommends colonoscopy every 10 years or annual FIT as first-tier tests; CT colonography every 5 years, FIT-fecal DNA testing every 3 years, or flexible sigmoidoscopy every 5 to 10 years as second-tier tests; and capsule colonography every 5 years as a third-tier test. Screening would be most appropriate among adults who (1) are healthy enough to undergo treatment if colorectal cancer is detected and (2) do not have comorbid conditions that would significantly limit their life expectancy. Because there are no head-to-head comparisons of the various screening modalities for colorectal cancer, the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force makes a practical recommendation that the best screening modality is the one the patient is willing to complete. For this patient, FIT may have certain desirable advantages. FIT has improved accuracy compared with guaiac fecal occult blood test and does not require bowel preparation, anesthesia, or transportation to and from the screening examination.
The recommended interval for CT colonography is every 5 years, not every 10 years (
Option B

). Like colonoscopy, CT colonography requires bowel preparation, and this imaging test is not associated with the ability to remove polyps or biopsy. Extracolonic findings of undetermined significance are common.
The serum circulating methylated SEPT9 DNA test (
Option C

) is an FDA-approved screening strategy that holds promise because blood tests may result in increased adherence. However, this test's sensitivity for detecting colorectal cancer is only 48%, and the MSTF does not recommend its use.
Flexible sigmoidoscopy every 2 years (
Option D

) is not a recommended colorectal screening strategy. Flexible sigmoidoscopy is recommended every 5 to 10 years when used alone, or every 5 years when combined with annual FIT. Although flexible sigmoidoscopy does require bowel preparation, it is limited compared with colonoscopy.

objective.__html: Screen for colorectal cancer in a person who does not prefer colonoscopy.

references: Qaseem A, Crandall CJ, Mustafa RA, et al; Clinical Guidelines Committee of the American College of Physicians. Screening for colorectal cancer in asymptomatic average-risk adults: A guidance statement from the American College of Physicians.

children: Ann Intern Med

title: Question 68

children: A 48-year-old woman is evaluated during a routine examination. She reports that her last menstrual period was more than 12 months ago. She states she has occasional hot flushes. She has no genitourinary symptoms. Medical history is unremarkable, and she takes no medications.
Physical examination findings, including vital signs, are normal.
A pregnancy test result is negative.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
Menopause is a clinical diagnosis made retrospectively when a woman has not experienced a menstrual period for 12 months, and routine laboratory testing for the diagnosis is not recommended.
Patients with possible early menopause (age <40 years) should have pregnancy excluded and undergo measurement of follicle-stimulating hormone, thyroid-stimulating hormone, and prolactin.
The most appropriate management is no further evaluation (
Option D

). Menopause is a clinical diagnosis made retrospectively when a woman has not experienced a menstrual period for 12 months. Menopause occurring in women older than 40 years, such as this patient, requires no additional laboratory or diagnostic evaluation. Menopause occurring in women younger than 40 years should be evaluated for premature ovarian insufficiency and other disorders by obtaining follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), serum thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), and prolactin levels; on the basis of results of these studies, additional evaluation may be required. Symptoms of menopause include vasomotor symptoms (hot flushes, night sweats). Hot flushes generally start in the perimenopausal period and can last for a few years to lifelong. Women may experience other symptoms, such as depression, anxiety, and irritability, but it is unclear whether these symptoms can be attributed to menopause. Genitourinary syndrome of menopause results from estrogen deficiency and is characterized by vaginal symptoms, such as burning or irritation; sexual symptoms, such as dyspareunia or sexual dysfunction; or urinary symptoms, such as dysuria or recurrent urinary infections.
Although serum FSH levels (
Option A

) are elevated in menopausal woman, measurement of FSH levels is not required to diagnosis menopause in this patient. In a woman older than 40 years who has not had a menstrual period in more than 1 year and has a negative result on pregnancy test, the clinical diagnosis of menopause can be made without additional laboratory evaluation.
A serum prolactin level (
Option B
) is appropriate management in the evaluation of early menopause and amenorrhea, but it is not required to diagnose menopause in a patient older than 40 years.
Obtaining a serum TSH level (
Option C
) can be helpful in evaluating a woman younger than 40 years with absent menses or a woman presenting with abnormal uterine bleeding, but it is not required for the routine diagnosis of menopause.

objective.__html: Diagnose menopause.

references: Burger HG. Unpredictable endocrinology of the menopause transition: clinical, diagnostic and management implications. Menopause Int. 2011;17:153-4.

title: Question 69

children: A 36-year-old woman is evaluated for darkening of the cheeks and forehead that began during pregnancy and has persisted. She is 6 months postpartum. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and she takes no medications.
Skin findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
Melasma is a hyperpigmentation disorder that occurs mostly on the sun-exposed areas on the face; it most commonly affects women of childbearing age.
The first-line treatment for melasma is strict sun protection with sun avoidance, sunscreen, and sun-protective clothing.
The most appropriate management is sun protection (
Option D

). This patient has melasma, also known as chloasma, or the mask of pregnancy. Melasma is a hyperpigmentation disorder resulting in tan to dark brown reticulated patches, mostly on the sun-exposed areas on the face (malar, mandibular, and centrofacial regions, including the forehead) and the upper extremities. It is exacerbated with sun exposure. Melasma most commonly affects women of childbearing age; it occurs more frequently and is more noticeable in patients with darker skin. Causes of melasma are hormonal factors (pregnancy, use of oral contraceptives), ultraviolet (UV) light, and genetic predisposition. The most essential element of management of melasma is strict sun protection with sun avoidance, use of sunscreen, and wearing sun-protective clothing. Melasma can occasionally resolve after pregnancy or with cessation of oral contraceptive use but may persist or recur with UV light exposure. Treatment is challenging and, in addition to strict sun protection and avoidance, involves topical depigmenting agents, such as hydroquinone. Laser therapy; chemical peels; and oral agents, such as tranexamic acid, are other treatment options. It may take months to years for pigmentation to normalize.
Hydrocortisone cream (
Option A

) is a low-potency glucocorticoid. When combined with tretinoin and hydroquinone, topical glucocorticoids have shown some efficacy in the treatment of melasma. Monotherapy with topical glucocorticoids for melasma is not recommended and would not be the correct management in this patient. Long-term use of topical glucocorticoids on the face additionally increases the risk for skin atrophy.
Monobenzyl ether of hydroquinone (
Option B

) is a depigmenting topical medication used for the treatment of vitiligo. It may be used for permanent depigmentation in patients with greater than 50% body surface area affected by vitiligo but is not appropriate for treatment of melasma.
Oral tranexamic acid (
Option C

) is an antifibrinolytic approved for the treatment of heavy menstrual bleeding. Tranexamic acid inhibits melanin synthesis and has been used off-label to treat refractory melasma. Because of its potential increased risk for thromboembolic events, tranexamic acid would not be first-line treatment for this patient.
Although an association of melasma with thyroid abnormalities has been reported, routine measurement of thyroid-stimulating hormone level (
Option E
) is not indicated.

objective.__html: Treat melasma with sun avoidance and protection.

references: Ogbechie-Godec OA, Elbuluk N. Melasma: an up-to-date comprehensive review. Dermatol Ther (Heidelb). 2017;7:305-18.

title: Question 70

children: This question has been updated as a result of postpublication analysis and/or new data that are relevant to the question.

A 24-year-old man is evaluated during a routine health examination. He received the tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis vaccine and one dose of the quadrivalent meningococcal conjugate vaccine when he was 18 years old, before starting college. He received the influenza and COVID-19 vaccines during the most recent influenza season and has additionally completed the hepatitis B vaccine series. He has not received the human papillomavirus vaccine series. He does not smoke cigarettes.
Which of the following is the most appropriate vaccination strategy for this patient?

text.__html: Administer a second dose of quadrivalent meningococcal conjugate vaccine
Administer the human papillomavirus vaccine series
No vaccines are indicated at this time

children: Individuals aged 11 to 26 years should receive human papillomavirus vaccination, ideally administered between age 11 and 12 years or between age 13 and 26 years if not given previously.
A history of human papillomavirus infection or an abnormal Pap smear does not change the recommendation for human papillomavirus vaccination.
The most appropriate vaccination strategy for this patient is to administer the human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine series (
Option B

). HPV vaccination prevents persistent HPV infection, which can lead to cervical, anogenital, and nasopharyngeal cancers. The vaccine should be administered between age 11 and 12 years or between the ages of 13 and 26 years if not given previously. Individuals younger than 15 years can receive a two-dose series, whereas those aged 15 years or older, such as this patient, should receive a three-dose series. A history of HPV infection or an abnormal Pap smear does not change the recommendation for vaccination. The HPV vaccine is considered safe for individuals aged 27 to 45 years; unvaccinated individuals in this age group should participate in shared decision making with their physician about the benefits and risks of vaccination. Vaccination is not recommended during pregnancy, although no harmful effects have been noted when inadvertently given to pregnant women and pregnancy testing is not necessary before vaccination.
Administration of a second dose of quadrivalent meningococcal conjugate vaccine (MenACWY) (
Option A

) is not indicated for this patient. The Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices recommends routine vaccination with MenACWY for adolescents aged 11 or 12 years, with a booster dose at age 16 years. Eight weeks should elapse between primary vaccination and booster. If the first dose was administered after age 16 years, such as in this patient, a booster is not required. College freshmen living in resident halls should receive the vaccine within 5 years of enrollment.
For healthy nonsmokers with no high-risk medical conditions, such as this patient, pneumococcal vaccination (
Option C

) is not indicated until age 65 years. In addition, if pneumococcal vaccination were indicated because of a high-risk medical condition, the preferred vaccination options would be the 20-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine alone or the 15-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine followed by the 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine at least 1 year later.
Because individuals between age 11 and 26 years should receive HPV vaccination, not offering the HPV vaccine series to this patient is not the best strategy (
Option D

objective.__html: Prevent human papillomavirus infection with appropriate immunization.

references: Murthy N, Wodi AP, Bernstein H, et al; Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices. Recommended adult immunization schedule, United States, 2022.

title: Question 71

children: An 18-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for severe right-sided scrotal pain that started suddenly 4 hours ago and has progressed. He is nauseated but reports no other symptoms. He has no history of trauma. He has no other medical problems and takes no medications.

On physical examination, the patient is in distress. Temperature is 36.9 °C (98.4 °F), blood pressure is 146/92 mm Hg, pulse rate is 102/min, and respiration rate is 16/min. The right testis is elevated, and the overlying scrotal skin is erythematous and warm. The epididymis cannot be distinguished from the testis owing to severe scrotal swelling and pain. Cremasteric reflex is absent on the right and intact on the left.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
Testicular torsion, a surgical emergency, presents with acute onset of moderate to severe testicular pain.
Patients with testicular torsion have profound testicular tenderness and swelling, elevation of the involved testicle, and an absent cremasteric reflex.
The most appropriate management is immediate surgical exploration (
Option A

). This patient has a classic presentation of testicular torsion, a twisting of the spermatic cord contents resulting in testicular ischemia. Testicular torsion is most common in children and young adults and presents as acute unilateral scrotal pain and swelling. Examination reveals elevation of the involved scrotum and an absent cremasteric reflex (failure of the testis to elevate when the ipsilateral inner thigh is stroked). Decreased blood flow seen on Doppler ultrasound is typical. Testicular torsion is a surgical emergency, and this patient should undergo immediate surgical exploration. The time from symptom onset to surgical exploration is the most important determining factor of testicular viability. If surgical exploration is performed within 6 hours of symptom onset, the testis remains viable in 90% to 100% of cases. Testicular viability drops to 50% if surgery is not performed until 12 hours after presentation and to less than 10% if performed 24 hours or more after presentation. If surgery is not readily available, an attempt to untwist the testicle manually is warranted. Even if successful, follow-up surgery is typically required.
Empiric antimicrobial therapy with intramuscular ceftriaxone and oral doxycycline and scrotal elevation (
Options B, C

) are both appropriate management for epididymitis and epididymo-orchitis in men younger than 35 years, but not for a patient with suspected testicular torsion. Epididymitis and epididymo-orchitis typically have a slower onset and cause less severe pain; on physical examination, there is an intact cremasteric reflex and the involved testicle is not elevated.

Because of the very high likelihood of testicular torsion and the urgency for surgical exploration in testicular torsion, surgery should not be delayed to obtain imaging studies. Although ultrasonography of the scrotum (
Option D

) is highly sensitive (89%) and highly specific (99%) and has a false-negative rate of approximately 1% for diagnosing testicular torsion, it is not mandatory or necessary in patients with a supportive history and unequivocal physical examination findings, as exemplified by this patient. Scrotal ultrasonography is of most value when the diagnosis is in doubt owing to equivocal physical examination findings.

objective.__html: Treat testicular torsion.

references: Bourke MM, Silverberg JZ. Acute scrotal emergencies. Emerg Med Clin North Am. 2019;37:593-610.

title: Question 72

children: A 68-year-old man is seen for a preoperative medical evaluation before elective cervical laminectomy for chronic radicular pain without neurologic deficits. Medical history is significant for hyperlipidemia and hypertension. He had a cerebrovascular accident 3 weeks ago due to small-vessel atherosclerosis. Medications are rosuvastatin, lisinopril, atenolol, aspirin, and dipyridamole.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. BMI is 31. Neurologic examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation regarding surgery?
Patients at the highest risk for perioperative stroke include those with a history of prior stroke or transient ischemic attack.
Elective surgery should ideally be delayed at least 6 months after a prior stroke, and possibly as long as 9 months following stroke or transient ischemic attack.
The most appropriate recommendation is to delay surgery for at least 9 months following this patient's stroke (
Option C

). Prior stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a significant risk factor for recurrent stroke in general and during the perioperative period and also increases the risk for a major adverse cardiac event. Historically, it has been recommended to delay elective noncardiac surgery for a minimum of 3 months following stroke or TIA owing to unacceptably high risk for recurrent stroke and impaired cerebral autoregulation during that time frame. However, more recent data show that this exceedingly high risk for recurrent stroke persists longer than 3 months, gradually returning to a new baseline 9 to 12 months after the event, at which point it still remains elevated compared with persons who never had a stroke or TIA. Although surgeries deemed more time sensitive or urgent may proceed after 3 months, it is most prudent to wait at least 6 months after a prior stroke, and possibly as long as 9 months prior to elective procedures. It is also important to note that secondary stroke prophylaxis with antiplatelet agents is often held for prolonged periods before and after spine surgery owing to bleeding risks, rendering the patient at even greater risk for recurrent stroke.
Waiting 9 to 12 months for the risk for perioperative stroke to reduce to baseline is ideal, although the risk for recurrent stroke remains elevated. Avoiding surgery (
Option A
) is not absolutely necessary, and after the benefits and risks have been weighed, surgery can be planned with appropriate risk mitigation after an appropriate interval after stroke or TIA.
Stroke or TIA within 30 days of planned surgery (
Options B, D

) significantly increases the risk for perioperative stroke; during this period, elective surgeries should be avoided. Patients with stroke involving a large brain volume or with a recent hemorrhagic stroke also are at risk for cerebral hemorrhage if placed on cardiopulmonary bypass and/or anticoagulation. If possible, nonemergency major cardiac procedures should be avoided.

objective.__html: Recommend timing of surgery following a stroke.

references: Benesch C, Glance LG, Derdeyn CP, et al; American Heart Association Stroke Council; Council on Arteriosclerosis, Thrombosis and Vascular Biology; Council on Cardiovascular and Stroke Nursing; Council on Clinical Cardiology; Council on Epidemiology and Prevention. Perioperative neurological evaluation and management to lower the risk of acute stroke in patients undergoing noncardiac, nonneurological surgery: a scientific statement from the American Heart Association/American Stroke Association. Circulation. 2021:CIR0000000000000968.

title: Question 73

children: A 38-year-old woman is evaluated for a 3-week history of pruritic rash on several areas, including the hands. There is no facial involvement.
Skin findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Scabies is a skin infestation with
Sarcoptes scabiei

characterized by papules and burrows on the fingers and web spaces, breasts, wrists, axillae, waistline, genitalia, and ankles; it is transmitted by skin-to-skin contact and can be treated with topical permethrin or oral ivermectin.
Crusted scabies is a form of scabies with a high mite load that presents with widespread psoriasiform and hyperkeratotic lesions; it is more common in immunocompromised patients.
The most likely diagnosis is scabies (
Option D

), an intensely pruritic skin condition that presents with papules and burrows on the fingers and web spaces. Other common areas of involvement are the breasts, wrists, axillae, waistline, genitalia, and ankles. Scabies typically spares the face and scalp in adults. Pruritus is usually worse at night. Scabies is caused by
Sarcoptes scabiei

, which lives in the human epidermis. Skin-to-skin contact, including sexual transmission, is the primary mode of transmission. Outbreaks are common in families, institutional settings, and the homeless population due to its highly contagious nature. Crusted scabies, a form of scabies with a significantly higher mite load (thousands versus 5-15 mites in typical scabies), presents with widespread psoriasiform and hyperkeratotic lesions; it is more common in immunocompromised patients. The skin findings of crusted scabies are
shown
Diagnosis of scabies is confirmed using a mineral oil preparation of skin scraping for microscopic identification of mites, eggs, or feces under the microscope, as
shown

Because of the lower mite burden in the typical presentation of scabies, the scabies preparation may be negative; diagnosis, however, can be made on the basis of the history (itch, close contact with individuals with similar lesions or itch) and distribution of lesions. Treatment is topical permethrin or oral ivermectin.
Bed bug bites (
Option A
) present as erythematous papules, typically in a linear pattern, on exposed areas of the skin. Bites occur at night when the bed bug,
Cimex lectularius

, typically feeds. Bites have characteristically linearly arranged urticarial papules (“breakfast, lunch, and dinner”) and are usually fewer in number than seen in this patient. Bed bug bites are not consistent with this patient's skin findings.
Dyshidrosis (
Option B

), or dyshidrotic eczema, is a form of hand dermatitis characterized by vesicles on the hands and fingers; it is also common on the feet. Dyshidrosis is often exacerbated by irritants, such as water and detergents, and is more common in patients with atopic dermatitis. It does not present with burrows, as seen in this patient.
Impetigo (
Option C
) is a bacterial infection of the skin most commonly caused by
Staphylococcus aureus
, group A streptococci, or both
Impetigo presents as honey-colored crusted erosions or bullae, commonly on the face. This patient's skin findings are not consistent with impetigo.

objective.__html: Diagnose scabies.

references: Thomas C, Coates SJ, Engelman D, et al. Ectoparasites: scabies. J Am Acad Dermatol. 2020;82:533-48.

title: Question 74

children: A 65-year-old man is seen for a preoperative medical evaluation prior to total knee arthroplasty. He has compensated alcoholic cirrhosis without a history of variceal hemorrhage, ascites, and encephalopathy. He has been abstinent from alcohol for 9 months. His only medication is topical diclofenac.

On physical examination, vital signs are normal. Scattered spider angiomas are noted on the shoulders. There is no evidence of ascites. The right knee has evidence of osteoarthritis, with restricted range of motion. Mental status examination is normal.
His calculated Model for End-stage Liver Disease score is 14.
Laboratory studies:
Hemoglobin
Platelet count
INR
Total bilirubin
2.0 mg/dL (34.2 µmol/L)
Creatinine
1.2 mg/dL (106.1 µmol/L)
Which of the following is the most appropriate perioperative management?

text.__html: Counsel patient on increased surgical risk due to cirrhosis

children: A progressive increase in perioperative mortality for all procedures is observed as Model for End-stage Liver Disease scores rise.

Patients with compensated cirrhosis who have Model for End-stage Liver Disease (MELD) scores below 8 to 10 may proceed with most surgeries with optimal medical management; a MELD score greater than 20 precludes all but the most urgent surgeries for life-threatening illness.
The most appropriate perioperative management is to counsel the patient on increased surgical risk as it relates to his diagnosis of cirrhosis (
Option A

). During the perioperative period, patients with cirrhosis are at significantly greater risk for electrolyte abnormalities, fluid imbalance, delirium, kidney failure, worsening liver dysfunction, impaired clearance of medications, infection, bleeding, clotting, and death. The likelihood of poor outcomes increases with the extent of liver disease as measured by Model for End-stage Liver Disease (MELD) or Child-Turcotte-Pugh score. The MELD score incorporates the INR, serum total bilirubin level, and serum creatinine levels. A progressive increase in perioperative mortality for all procedures is observed as MELD scores rise. Patients who have MELD scores below 8 to 10 generally do well perioperatively provided that their liver disease is stable and compensated, and it is reasonable to proceed with most surgeries with optimal medical management. When a MELD score is greater than 20, mortality rates increase to a degree that precludes all but the most urgent surgeries for life-threatening illness. A MELD score of 14 (as this patient has) indicates intermediate risk for surgery-related complications, and the risks and benefits of the anticipated elective surgery should be discussed with the patient after the perioperative evaluation.
In patients with cirrhosis and asymptomatic elevation of the prothrombin time or INR, prophylactic treatment with either plasma or cryoprecipitate (
Option B

) is not indicated. There is no evidence of benefit with these interventions and there is evidence of harm, particularly the risks for transfusion reactions and volume overload. Patients with cirrhosis and platelet counts of 50,000/µL (50 × 10
/L) or greater do not require platelet transfusions prior to surgery.
In the absence of decompensated liver disease (variceal hemorrhage, ascites, encephalopathy) a MELD score less than 15 does not meet criteria for liver transplantation (
Option C

This patient is at increased risk for surgery-related complications. Before proceeding with surgery in such patients, it is important to discuss with them the potential risks and benefits of hip arthroplasty (
Option D
), including alternative therapies that do not involve surgical intervention.

objective.__html: Assess risk in a patient with cirrhosis before elective surgery.

references: Northup PG, Friedman LS, Kamath PS. AGA clinical practice update on surgical risk assessment and perioperative management in cirrhosis: expert review. Clin Gastroenterol Hepatol. 2019;17:595-606.

title: Question 75

children: A 38-year-old woman is seen in the office to discuss pharmacotherapy for obesity. She has not lost significant weight over the past 6 months despite dietary counseling, commercial weight loss programs, and exercise. Medical history is significant for nephrolithiasis, insomnia, hypertension, and irritable bowel syndrome with diarrhea. Medications are hydrochlorothiazide and loperamide.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. BMI is 39. The remainder of the examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

Pharmacotherapy is an option in the treatment of obesity and overweight for patients with BMI of 30 or greater or for those with BMI of 27 or greater and at least one obesity-associated comorbid condition who have not achieved weight loss goals with a trial of at least 3 to 6 months of lifestyle modification.
The most appropriate management is liraglutide (
Option A

), a glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonist. Pharmacotherapy is an option in the treatment of obesity and overweight for patients with BMI of 30 or greater or for those with BMI of 27 or greater and at least one obesity-associated comorbid condition (such as diabetes, hypertension, or obstructive sleep apnea) who have not achieved weight loss goals with a trial of at least 3 to 6 months of lifestyle modification. Pharmacotherapy is contraindicated in pregnancy, and women of childbearing age should be advised to avoid pregnancy while using these medications. The goal of pharmacotherapy is weight loss of 5% or more during the first 3 to 6 months. If this target is not reached, use of the medication should be discontinued. Weight is typically regained once pharmacotherapy is discontinued, which underscores the importance of concomitant lifestyle changes. The potential weight loss benefit of pharmacotherapy should be balanced against risk for adverse events and cost. Liraglutide in an injectable agent that acts to decrease gastric emptying, thereby increasing satiety, and has been associated with weight loss of 5.2 kg (11.6 lb) compared with placebo. Contraindications include a history of medullary thyroid carcinoma and family history of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2, and it should be used cautiously in patients with pancreatitis. Of the pharmacologic treatment options, liraglutide is the weight loss medication most likely to be well tolerated in this patient.
Naltrexone-bupropion (
Option B

) is an opioid antagonist and norepinephrine-dopamine uptake inhibitor that suppresses appetite. It has a higher discontinuation rate compared with other pharmacologic options. The most common adverse effects include nausea, dizziness, changes in bowel habits, and insomnia. Contraindications include seizure disorders, eating disorders, any current opiate use or withdrawal, or any risky alcohol use. Because this patient has insomnia, this drug combination would be a poor choice.
Orlistat (
Option C

) is an intraluminal lipase inhibitor that induces weight loss by decreasing triglyceride absorption. Although safe, it causes gastrointestinal side effects, including oily stools, increased defecation, and fecal urgency or incontinence in as many as 30% of patients. Contraindications include malabsorption syndromes and cholestasis. This patient has irritable bowel syndrome with diarrhea, and it is unlikely that she will tolerate the gastrointestinal side effects of orlistat.
Phentermine-topiramate (
Option D

) is a noradrenergic γ-aminobutyric acid receptor activator and AMPA glutamate receptor inhibitor. Contraindications include glaucoma, hyperthyroidism, and nephrolithiasis. Caution is advised in patients with hypertension or resting tachycardia. Because this patient has a history of nephrolithiasis, phentermine-topiramate is contraindicated.

objective.__html: Treat obesity with pharmacotherapy.

references: Khera R, Murad MH, Chandar AK, et al. Association of pharmacological treatments for obesity with weight loss and adverse events: a systematic review and meta-analysis. JAMA. 2016;315:2424-34.

title: Question 76

children: A 56-year-old man is evaluated for worsening erythema and pruritus that began 3 days ago. Ten days ago, bacitracin ointment was used following excision of a dysplastic nevus on his upper back; it was stopped 3 days ago. Two weeks ago, he was treated with amoxicillin for community-acquired pneumonia. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and he takes no medications.
Skin findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

Contact dermatitis is an eczematous eruption that occurs at the site of allergen contact with the skin and is characterized by pruritic, erythematous patches or plaques that may show vesicles and weeping acutely, or dry scaling and lichenification at later stages.
Bacitracin, polymyxin B, and neomycin are common topical antibiotics used to treat or prevent wound infections and are commonly associated with allergic contact dermatitis.
The most appropriate treatment is to add triamcinolone cream (
Option D

). This patient developed allergic contact dermatitis to bacitracin ointment. Contact dermatitis is an eczematous eruption that occurs at the site of allergen contact with the skin and is characterized by pruritic, erythematous patches or plaques that may show vesicles and weeping acutely, or dry scaling and lichenification at later stages. Although the patient discontinued using bacitracin 3 days before presenting, erythema and pruritus persist and would be best treated with a topical glucocorticoid, such as triamcinolone cream. Bacitracin, polymyxin B, and neomycin are common topical antibiotics used to treat or prevent wound infections and are frequently associated with allergic contact dermatitis. For clean wounds, such as a skin surgical site, the application of plain petrolatum is recommended over the use of topical antibiotics.
Candida
infections are rare in clean surgical wounds, and treatment with ketoconazole cream (
Option A
) is not indicated for this patient.
Candida
infections occur more commonly in intertriginous areas and are characterized by erythema with satellite papules or pustules. This patient's skin findings have no features of
Candida
infection.
Although mupirocin ointment (
Option B

) is less likely than bacitracin to cause allergic contact dermatitis, there is no indication of wound infection in this patient. Wound infections have more significant erythema, tenderness, and often exudative drainage. This patient has pruritus and a classic presentation of allergic contact dermatitis, and thus mupirocin is not the best treatment option.
Prednisone (
Option C

) can be used for severe systemic drug reactions, such as a systemic reaction to an antibiotic, but it would not be appropriate for treating this localized contact dermatitis. Systemic drug reactions are typically morbilliform, widespread, and symmetric. This patient has no indication of a systemic drug reaction to the course of amoxicillin he had received, and prednisone is not warranted.

objective.__html: Treat allergic contact dermatitis.

references: Bonamonte D, De Marco A, Giuffrida R, et al. Topical antibiotics in the dermatological clinical practice: indications, efficacy, and adverse effects. Dermatol Ther. 2020;33:e13824.

title: Question 77

children: A 65-year-old man is evaluated during a follow-up visit for type 2 diabetes mellitus. He feels well. He reports no chest pain or shortness of breath. Medical history is also significant for atrial fibrillation, dyslipidemia, and hypertension. Medications are metformin, liraglutide, lisinopril, metoprolol, rivaroxaban, and atorvastatin.
Physical examination findings, including vital signs, are normal.
His 10-year atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease risk is 24% using the Pooled Cohort Equations.
Which of the following is the best advice regarding aspirin therapy for this patient?
Aspirin should be used infrequently in primary prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease but should not be used in patients at increased risk for bleeding.

Low-dose aspirin may be considered for primary prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) in some individuals aged 40 to 70 years who are at high risk for ASCVD and do not have an increased bleeding risk.
Aspirin is not recommended (
Option D

) for patients at higher risk for bleeding, such as this patient taking rivaroxaban. The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends low-dose aspirin for the primary prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) and colorectal cancer in willing adults aged 50 to 59 years with a 10-year ASCVD risk of 10% or higher, a life expectancy of at least 10 years, and no increased risk for bleeding. This patient has a 10-year ASCVD risk greater than 10% and may be considered for aspirin therapy for primary prevention of ASCVD. Tempering the recommendation for primary prevention of ASCVD with aspirin are multiple trials, including ASCEND, ARRIVE, and ASPREE, and a 2019 meta-analysis showing no net mortality benefit with aspirin; reductions in nonfatal myocardial infarction and ischemic stroke were offset by an increased risk for major bleeding, including intracranial hemorrhage. Factors that increase risk for bleeding include increasing age, male sex, concurrent anticoagulant or NSAID use, history of gastrointestinal bleeding, upper gastrointestinal pain, uncontrolled hypertension, chronic kidney disease, and thrombocytopenia. Because of these data, the American College of Cardiology and the American Heart Association recommended that aspirin should be used infrequently in primary prevention of ASCVD and that low-dose (81 mg/d) aspirin (
Option A
) might be considered for primary prevention of ASCVD only in some individuals aged 40 to 70 years who are at high risk for ASCVD but do not have an increased bleeding risk.
The addition of a proton pump inhibitor, such as omeprazole (
Option B

), is recommended by the American College of Cardiology for patients with established ASCVD disease who require treatment with two or more antithrombotic agents. These patients should also avoid NSAIDs. However, this patient should not take aspirin and therefore does not need to take a proton pump inhibitor.
Higher doses of aspirin, such as 325 mg (
Option C

), have not been shown to be more effective in primary prevention of ASCVD than low-dose aspirin and are associated with increased risk for bleeding. If aspirin were indicated as a primary prevention measure in this patient, low-dose aspirin would be appropriate.

objective.__html: Avoid aspirin for primary prevention in patients on anticoagulation.

references: Arnett DK, Blumenthal RS, Albert MA, et al. 2019 ACC/AHA guideline on the primary prevention of cardiovascular disease: a report of the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association task force on clinical practice guidelines. Circulation. 2019;140:e596-646.

title: Question 78

children: A 50-year-old man is evaluated during a follow-up visit 1 month after being hospitalized for deep venous thrombosis of the right leg. He is no longer taking apixaban because he received only a 14-day supply after leaving the hospital and his symptoms had improved after finishing the supply. He thought he had finished a course of therapy.
On physical examination, vital signs and the remainder of the physical examination are normal.
Which of the following steps should be taken now to promote medication adherence?

text.__html: Select an anticoagulant with the lowest copayment

children: The factors most strongly associated with medication adherence include strong provider-patient relationships and patients' understanding of their medical conditions.
Patient education (
Option A

) at this visit is important to promote medication adherence. This patient did not understand the need to continue his anticoagulant medication beyond the 14-day course he was provided. If patients do not comprehend medical instructions, as in the case of this patient, nonadherence with resultant adverse events, such as rehospitalization or mortality, may occur. Medication adherence is defined as the degree to which a patient adheres to the dosage and interval of their prescribed pharmacologic regimen. Nonadherence, typically defined as failure to take at least 80% of a prescribed medication regimen, has been associated with increased health care utilization, poor outcomes, and increased costs. Medication adherence is a complex behavior that is influenced by the patient, system, and provider. The factors most strongly associated with medication adherence include strong provider-patient relationships and a patient's understanding of their medical conditions.
Recommending a pill box (
Option B
) and selecting an anticoagulant with the lowest copayment (
Option D

) are recognized strategies to increase medication adherence. Both methods are usually acceptable to patients. Selecting a medication with the lowest copayment is challenging because it requires physicians to maintain knowledge of various and shifting copayments with a large number of insurance companies and is time intensive, and its impact is unknown. More important, it appears that the primary reason for this patient's nonadherence was lack of understanding of the prolonged treatment duration for deep venous thrombosis. Patient education is more likely to increase medication adherence than either a pill box or lowest copayment.
Screening for low health literacy (
Option C

) may uncover health literacy problems but will not improve adherence to the required anticoagulation plan. Clinicians can address low health literacy by using techniques to improve patient understanding, such as repeating information and supplying the patient with educational materials written in plain language. The teach-back method, wherein the clinician asks patients to describe their understanding of instructions in their own words, is especially helpful in rapidly identifying a potential health literacy problem before a patient leaves a medical setting. The teach-back method coupled with education about the patient's medical problem and need for prolonged treatment is more likely to increase medication adherence than is screening for low health literacy alone.

objective.__html: Provide patient education to promote medication adherence.

references: Yen PH, Leasure AR. Use and effectiveness of the teach-back method in patient education and health outcomes. Fed Pract. 2019;36:284-9.

title: Question 79

children: A 62-year-old woman is evaluated in the hospital for venous thromboembolism (VTE) prophylaxis. The patient has locally invasive ovarian cancer and will undergo total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. She has no personal or family history of VTE. She is otherwise well and takes no medication.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. BMI is 33. Ascites is present. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable.
Intermittent pneumatic compression is initiated.
Which of the following is the most appropriate additional VTE prophylaxis for this patient?

text.__html: Insertion of an inferior vena cava filter

children: Pharmacologic venous thromboembolism prophylaxis is recommended for hospitalized patients with active cancer in the absence of bleeding or other contraindications.

Extended venous thromboembolism (VTE) prophylaxis with low-molecular-weight heparin for up to 4 weeks postoperatively is recommended for patients undergoing major open or laparoscopic abdominal or pelvic surgery for cancer who have high-risk features, such as restricted mobility, obesity, or history of VTE, or who have additional risk factors.
The most appropriate additional venous thromboembolism (VTE) prophylaxis for this patient is administration of subcutaneous low-molecular weight heparin (LMWH) for 30 days (
Option C

). The 2019 American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) guideline for VTE prophylaxis in patients with cancer recommends pharmacologic prophylaxis for hospitalized patients with active cancer in the absence of bleeding or other contraindications. Patients should be offered pharmacologic thromboprophylaxis with either unfractionated heparin or LMWH. Prophylaxis should commence in the hours immediately preceding surgery and may be combined with mechanical methods, such as intermittent pneumatic compression. A combined regimen of pharmacologic and mechanical prophylaxis may be superior, especially in the highest-risk patients. Pharmacologic thromboprophylaxis for patients undergoing major surgery for cancer should be continued for at least 7 to 10 days. Extended prophylaxis with LMWH for up to 4 weeks postoperatively is recommended for patients undergoing major open or laparoscopic abdominal or pelvic surgery for cancer who have high-risk features, such as restricted mobility, obesity, or history of VTE, or who have additional risk factors. This patient is undergoing high-risk surgery and has obesity as an additional risk for VTE, and extended prophylaxis is warranted.
The ASCO and other guidelines assert that there is no role for inferior vena cava (IVC) filter insertion (
Option A

) for VTE prophylaxis owing to concerns about its long-term harm. IVC filter placement may be considered in patients with absolute contraindications to anticoagulant therapy in the acute treatment setting of VTE if the thrombus burden is considered life-threatening.
Prophylaxis with LMWH for 7 days (
Option B

) is unlikely to provide adequate prophylaxis for this patient with cancer undergoing major surgery. Registry data have documented that postoperative VTE is detected after hospital discharge in 54% of cases, with the highest risk corresponding to colorectal and genitourinary cancer surgery. Studies have demonstrated that administration of LMWH for 30 days after the day of surgery reduces the risk for VTE without increasing the risk for bleeding complications.
No additional prophylaxis is not appropriate therapy (
Option D

). The 2019 ASCO guideline for VTE prophylaxis in patients with cancer recommends pharmacologic prophylaxis for hospitalized patients with active cancer in the absence of bleeding or other contraindications.

objective.__html: Prevent deep venous thromboembolism in a patient with cancer undergoing major surgery.

references: Key NS, Khorana AA, Kuderer NM, et al. Venous thromboembolism prophylaxis and treatment in patients with cancer: ASCO clinical practice guideline update. J Clin Oncol. 2020;38:496-520.

title: Question 80

children: A 66-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for sudden onset of perineal pain that began 1 day ago. He also reports urinary frequency, urgency, and hesitancy, and fever and chills. He is not sexually active. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and he takes no medications.

On physical examination, temperature is 38.7 °C (101.8 °F); other vital signs are normal. On digital rectal examination, the prostate is tender, enlarged, and boggy. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next management step?

text.__html: Prostatic massage followed by urine culture

children: Bacterial prostatitis is associated with acute onset of local symptoms (dysuria, urinary frequency and urgency, suprapubic and/or perineal pain) and systemic symptoms (fevers, chills, nausea/vomiting, malaise).
Oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole or an oral fluoroquinolone (ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin) is an appropriate empiric antibiotic for acute bacterial prostatitis.
The most appropriate next step in management is empiric trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (
Option D

). This patient has acute bacterial prostatitis. These patients typically present with acute onset of local symptoms (dysuria, urinary frequency and urgency, suprapubic and/or perineal pain) and systemic symptoms (fevers, chills, nausea/vomiting, malaise). Most cases of acute bacterial prostatitis are caused by gram-negative bacteria, including
Escherichia coli
and
Klebsiella
Enterobacter
Proteus
, and
Serratia

species. Oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole has both excellent coverage of gram-negative bacteria and prostatic tissue penetration. It is a reasonable empiric antibiotic choice in patients able to tolerate oral intake. A fluoroquinolone antibiotic (ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin) is also an appropriate empiric antibiotic choice. Antibiotic therapy should be initiated after a urine sample is obtained for analysis and culture and should be continued for 2 to 4 weeks; some experts recommend up to 6 weeks. Treatment can be modified on the basis of results of the urine culture.
CT or MRI of the prostate (
Option A

) is not indicated for patients with symptoms and physical examination findings of acute bacterial prostatitis. CT can be obtained if there is diagnostic uncertainty or if the patient does not improve after appropriate antibiotic therapy, because antibiotic failure raises the suspicion for prostate abscess.
Although nitrofurantoin (
Option B
) is appropriate for uncomplicated cystitis, it has poor penetration into prostatic tissue. It is not indicated for a patient with acute bacterial prostatitis.
Although prostatic massage followed by urine culture (
Option C
) has a role in patients with suspected chronic bacterial prostatitis, it should be avoided in patients with acute bacterial prostatitis because it can potentially cause bacteremia and sepsis.
Placement of a urinary catheter (
Option E

) is necessary in patients with prostatitis experiencing acute urinary retention. Acute urinary retention is usually associated with inability to urinate and lower abdominal and/or suprapubic discomfort. Although this patient has obstructive urinary symptoms, he has no evidence of acute urinary retention.

objective.__html: Treat acute bacterial prostatitis.

references: Gill BC, Shoskes DA. Bacterial prostatitis. Curr Opin Infect Dis. 2016;29:86-91.

title: Question 81

children: A 64-year-old man is evaluated for a 1-month history of a pruritic and irritated wart-like growth on his back. The warty lesion has been present for over a year, but the irritation and redness are new.
There are scattered seborrheic keratoses throughout trunk. Skin findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

Seborrheic keratoses, the most common benign skin tumors in adults, present as “stuck-on” papules or plaques; removal, most commonly with cryotherapy, is considered if the keratoses are irritated or pruritic, or for cosmetic reasons.
The most appropriate treatment is cryotherapy (
Option A

). This patient has seborrheic keratoses, the most common benign skin tumors in adults. Typically occurring after middle age, seborrheic keratoses present as warty, “stuck-on” papules or plaques, most commonly on the trunk; they involve only the epidermis. Seborrheic keratoses range in size from a few millimeters to several centimeters, are usually hyperpigmented, and range in color from tan to brown or black. The sign of Leser–Trélat is the sudden eruption of numerous seborrheic keratoses and is associated with an internal malignancy. Diagnosis of seborrheic keratoses can usually be made clinically, but shave biopsy can be confirmatory when there is concern for melanoma or squamous cell carcinoma. Reassurance is typically the appropriate management, but seborrheic keratoses are often treated if irritated or pruritic, such as in this patient, or for cosmetic reasons. Seborrheic keratosis usually become irritated and inflamed owing to chronic friction from clothing, but inflammation of seborrheic keratoses may occur during chemotherapy; cytarabine and docetaxel are the most implicated drugs. When indicated, the most common treatment is cryotherapy with liquid nitrogen, but only if the diagnosis is certain. Otherwise, a shave removal and submission for histologic evaluation is most appropriate. Other destructive therapies include curettage, electrodessication, or laser therapy.
Mupirocin ointment (
Option B

) is effective in treating superficial skin infections typically caused by gram-positive bacteria (staphylococci and streptococci). There is no indication of infection in this patient, and mupirocin is not appropriate treatment.
Topical 5-fluorouracil (
Option C

) is an approved treatment for actinic keratoses. It can also be used to treat superficial basal cell carcinomas and squamous cell carcinoma in situ. Topical 5-fluorauracil would not be appropriate management for a seborrheic keratosis.
Topical glucocorticoids, such as triamcinolone acetonide (
Option D
), have no role in the treatment of seborrheic keratoses because they are ineffective and over time may thin the normal surrounding skin.

objective.__html: Treat inflamed seborrheic keratoses.

title: Question 82

children: A 34-year-old woman is evaluated for preconception counseling. She received two doses of the human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine before 15 years of age; the tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine 5 years ago; and the influenza and COVID-19 vaccines during the most recent influenza season. She has no medical problems and takes no medications.
Laboratory studies reveal a negative rubella antibody titer and a positive varicella antibody titer. A pregnancy test result is negative.
Which of the following is the most appropriate vaccination strategy for this patient?

text.__html: No vaccines are indicated at this time

children: Women who are planning pregnancy and do not have immunity to rubella should receive the measles, mumps, and rubella vaccine before conceiving and should wait at least 4 weeks after vaccination to conceive.
The measles, mumps, and rubella vaccine is a live virus vaccine and should not be administered to immunocompromised individuals or pregnant women.
The measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine (
Option B

) is the most appropriate vaccine for this patient who lacks immunity to rubella. All women in the preconception period should be tested for rubella immunity, and those who lack immunity should be offered the MMR vaccine; women should avoid conceiving for at least 4 weeks after vaccination. If a woman lacks immunity to rubella but is already pregnant, she should receive the MMR vaccine after delivery but before leaving the hospital or at the time of pregnancy termination. The MMR vaccine is a live virus vaccine and should not be administered to immunocompromised individuals or pregnant women.
Patients should be administered the human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine series (
Option A

) at age 11 or 12 years or between 13 and 26 years of age if not given previously. In unvaccinated patients aged 27 to 45 years, vaccination can be considered on the basis of risk using a shared decision-making process. If administered before 15 years of age, a two-dose series is recommended, whereas a three-dose series is recommended in older individuals. Vaccination is not recommended during pregnancy, although no harmful effects have been noted when inadvertently given to pregnant women and pregnancy testing is not necessary before vaccination. This patient received two doses of the HPV vaccine before 15 years of age and does not need a third dose.
All pregnant women should receive the tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine (
Option C

) during each pregnancy between 27 weeks' and 36 weeks' gestation. This patient is currently not pregnant and her Tdap vaccination is up to date. In patients who have previously received the Tdap vaccine, booster vaccination with either tetanus and diphtheria toxoids (Td) or Tdap booster is recommended every 10 years. Patients who have not yet received the Tdap vaccine can receive it as one of the scheduled booster vaccinations. This patient should wait until the appropriate time interval to receive the Tdap or Td vaccine.
Because the patient is planning pregnancy and does not have immunity to rubella, not offering the MMR vaccine is not the best strategy (
