title: Question 83

children: A 26-year-old man is evaluated for a 2-month history of hair loss with no erythema, scaling, or pruritus. Medical history is unremarkable, and he takes no medication.
Skin findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Alopecia areata is nonscarring hair loss that results in smooth, hairless patches of skin, most commonly appearing on the scalp.
“Exclamation point” hairs, which are small broken hairs at the edges of the hair loss that are thicker at the top and thinner near the scalp, are pathognomonic of alopecia areata.
This patient has alopecia areata (
Option A

), which results in well-circumscribed patches of nonscarring hair loss without scale. Alopecia areata affects men and women equally and most commonly presents before the age of 30 years. It can progress to complete loss of scalp hair (alopecia totalis) and all of the body (alopecia universalis). Other than the hair loss, alopecia areata is usually asymptomatic. On examination, “exclamation point” hairs, which are small broken hairs at the edges of the hair loss that are thicker at the top and thinner near the scalp, can be observed; these are a pathognomonic indicator of alopecia areata. The pathogenesis of alopecia areata is not fully understood, but an autoimmune process is postulated. Alopecia areata can be associated with atopic dermatitis, asthma, thyroid disease, and type 1 diabetes mellitus. Patients with mild disease will often have spontaneous hair regrowth. More extensive involvement at onset has a poorer prognosis. Treatment includes potent topical or intralesional glucocorticoids for limited disease.
Androgenic alopecia (
Option B

), or patterned baldness, is due to the postpubertal terminal hair replacement, first with miniaturized follicles and eventually with atrophic follicles. It is seen in both men and women. The onset begins after puberty and can be gradual. In men, it presents as bitemporal hairline recession, followed by vertex thinning and then baldness (as
shown
. This patient's circumscribed hair loss is not compatible with androgenic alopecia.
Discoid lupus erythematosus (DLE) (
Option C

) is a scarring alopecia that presents with erythematous plaques with areas of scarring; it often occurs in the absence of systemic disease. The conchal bowls of the ears and other areas of the face are often involved. The absence of erythema and scarring in this patient is inconsistent with DLE.
Tinea capitis (
Option D
) is most commonly caused by
Trichophyton
and
Microsporum

species and typically presents with pruritic single or multiple scaly patches. It is a common cause of hair loss in children but a less common cause in adults. Severe cases may present with a kerion, an inflammatory plaque with pustules and drainage. Cervical lymphadenopathy is common. The age of this patient and lack of pruritus or scaling make tinea capitis an unlikely diagnosis.

objective.__html: Diagnose alopecia areata.

references: Strazzulla LC, Wang EH, Avila L, et al. Alopecia areata: disease characteristics, clinical evaluation, and new perspectives on pathogenesis. J Am Acad Dermatol. 2018;78:1-12.

title: Question 84

children: A 45-year-old man is seen for a preoperative medical evaluation before undergoing an elective hernia repair. He is otherwise well. History and physical examination are performed. Complete blood count, coagulation studies, chest radiography, and electrocardiography are not obtained.
This preoperative evaluation strategy is most in keeping with which of the following?
The aim of high value care is to improve health, avoid harms, and eliminate wasteful practices.

The practice of defensive medicine, the ordering of excessive tests and procedures by physicians to avoid malpractice litigation, is the antithesis of high value care and leads to waste and potential harm through unnecessary testing and treatment.
The American College of Physicians (ACP) High Value Care initiative (
Option B

) aims to improve health, avoid harms, and eliminate wasteful practices. This initiative addresses high value care broadly, offering learning resources for clinicians and medical educators, curricula, clinical guidelines, best practice advice, case studies, and patient resources on a wide variety of related topics. ACP believes that it is the responsibility of the medical profession to become cost-conscious and decrease unnecessary care that does not benefit patients. ACP has developed a five-step framework to assist physicians in delivering high value care: (1) understand the benefits, harms, and relative costs of the interventions that being considered; (2) decrease or eliminate the use of interventions that provide no benefits and/or may be harmful; (3) choose interventions and care settings that maximize benefits, minimize harms, and reduce costs (using comparative-effectiveness and cost-effectiveness data); (4) customize a care plan with the patient that incorporates their values and addresses their concerns; and (5) identify system-level opportunities to improve outcomes, minimize harms, and reduce health care waste. Not performing unnecessary testing, as shown in this case, is an example of high value care.
The practice of defensive medicine (
Option A

), the ordering of excessive tests and procedures by physicians to avoid malpractice litigation, is the antithesis of high value care. The prevalence of defensive medicine is a challenge to the provision of high value care. Remedies that include emphasizing patient safety, promoting a culture of quality improvement and coordinated care, and training physicians in best practices to avoid errors and reduce risk will prevent harm and reduce the waste associated with defensive medicine.
Lean is a quality improvement model (
Option C

) that aims to maximize value and minimize waste by closely examining a system's processes and eliminating non–value-added activities within the system. High value care may be an outcome of the Lean quality improvement process, but this physician's appropriate decision to forgo unnecessary testing is more indicative of high value care.
Medical rationing (
Option D

), defined by the allocation of scarce medical resources to a selected group of patients, leads to underuse of potentially appropriate care. High value care advocates for rational care that is characterized by care that is clinically effective, thus avoiding overuse or misuse of care that is inappropriate and wasteful.

objective.__html: Identify high value care.

references: Carroll AE. The high costs of unnecessary care. JAMA. 2017;318:1748-9.

title: Question 85

children: A 46-year-old woman is evaluated for a 2-week history of vaginal discharge and itching. She reports no other vaginal or urinary symptoms. She is sexually active with one male partner. She has a levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine device for contraception. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and she takes no medications.
Speculum examination shows gray frothy discharge. The cervix is normal appearing, without purulent discharge. Bimanual examination is unremarkable.

Laboratory studies reveal a vaginal pH of 5.0. There are no hyphae on potassium hydroxide preparation. Trichomonad nucleic acid amplification test result is positive. A pregnancy test result is negative.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
The recommended regimen for trichomoniasis for women is metronidazole, 500 mg orally twice daily for 7 days; metronidazole, 2 g orally in a single dose, is the recommended regimen for men.
Women treated for trichomoniasis should be retested in 3 months with a nucleic acid amplification test.
The most appropriate treatment is metronidazole, 500 mg orally twice daily for 7 days (
Option C

). Vaginal trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection (STI). Patients can be asymptomatic or present with pale yellow, green, or gray frothy vaginal discharge with itching and burning. Although trichomoniasis can be diagnosed with microscopy when motile trichomonads are noted on wet mount, nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) is recommended because it can be difficult to establish the diagnosis with a wet mount. Because trichomoniasis is sexually transmitted, patients should be screened for other STIs, including chlamydia, gonorrhea, HIV, and syphilis. It is also important to treat the patient's partner to help prevent reinfection and spread of infection to other sexual contacts. For women, the recommended regimen for trichomoniasis is metronidazole, 500 mg orally twice daily for 7 days. For men, the recommended treatment is metronidazole, 2 g orally in a single dose. Patients should also be retested for
Trichomonas
in 3 months with NAAT because of high reinfection rates.
A single 1-g dose of oral azithromycin (
Option A

) is appropriate treatment for chlamydia but does not treat trichomoniasis. Testing for chlamydia is appropriate in this setting because trichomoniasis is a STI, but treatment should be limited to patients with established chlamydia infection.
Fluconazole (
Option B

), 150 mg orally, is an appropriate treatment for vulvovaginal candidiasis but is not appropriate for the treatment of trichomoniasis. Vulvovaginal candidiasis is typically characterized by vaginal itching, irritation, and discharge. Examination reveals vulvar edema and excoriation, with thick, white, curdy vaginal discharge. Diagnostic testing involves 10% potassium hydroxide wet mount of the discharge showing yeast, hyphae, or pseudohyphae or a positive NAAT. Vulvovaginal candidiasis is not an STI; there is no need to treat partners of women diagnosed with vulvovaginal candidiasis.
Topical metronidazole vaginal gel (
Option D

), 5 g daily for 5 days, is an effective option for the treatment of bacterial vaginosis. This form of metronidazole, however, is not curative and is inferior to a single 2-g dose of oral metronidazole or tinidazole for the treatment of trichomoniasis.

objective.__html: Treat trichomoniasis.

references: Workowski KA, Bachmann LH, Chan PA, et al. Sexually transmitted infections treatment guidelines, 2021. MMWR Recomm Rep. 2021;70:1-187.

title: Question 86

children: An 82-year-old woman is seen for a preoperative medical evaluation before undergoing cataract surgery. The patient is wheelchair bound. She reports stable shortness of breath with minimal to moderate exertion. Medical history is significant for hypertension, chronic kidney disease, COPD, and degenerative joint disease. Medications are albuterol, ipratropium, and beclomethasone inhalers; lisinopril; metoprolol; and oxygen by nasal cannula, 2 L/min continuously.
On physical examination, blood pressure is 150/85 mm Hg, pulse rate is 97/min, respiration rate is 24/min, and

children.referenceRange: Blood gases, Oxygen saturation, arterial (ambient air)
children: oxygen saturation
is 94% on 2 L/min of oxygen by nasal cannula. Breath sounds are distant, with an occasional wheeze.
Which of the following is the most appropriate preoperative testing for this patient
In patients undergoing low-risk surgery, preoperative screening tests seldom predict perioperative complications and are not indicated even in patients with substantial comorbidities.
No testing is indicated (
Option D

) for this patient before cataract surgery. Preoperative testing can help define risks before undergoing a procedure and is intended to guide management. However, there is considerable overuse of preoperative testing, particularly in low-risk procedures. When determining appropriate preoperative testing for elective procedures, the first branch-point is determining the risk of surgery. In general, low-risk surgeries (such as skin surgeries, hernia repair, cataract surgery, and arthroscopy) are of shorter duration, involve local anesthetics, incur minimal blood loss, and are associated with few complications (<1% major adverse cardiac events). Multiple studies have shown that preoperative testing has little value in low-risk procedures. Even when patients have substantial comorbidities, such as this patient, chest radiography, echocardiography, and ECG do not predict cardiac complications. Therefore, provided medical issues are stable, preoperative testing is not recommended for low-risk procedures.
Although this patient has cardiopulmonary disease, including COPD, her symptoms are stable and chest radiography (
Option A

) results will not change perioperative management. Preoperative chest radiography in nonthoracic surgery is indicated only in patients with new signs or symptoms of pulmonary illness or underlying cardiac or pulmonary disease with new or unstable symptoms.
Given the low rates of cardiovascular complications and minimal predictive value they provide, screening ECG (
Option B

) is not helpful prior to low-risk procedures. Cardiac testing prior to low-risk surgery should be obtained only if the patient has new symptoms suggestive of cardiac disease (palpitations, chest pain, shortness of breath).
Echocardiography (
Option C

) should not be routinely performed preoperatively and certainly not before low-risk surgery. Specific indications for echocardiography before surgery that is other than low risk include the presence of dyspnea of unknown origin, heart failure with worsening dyspnea or change in clinical status, known left ventricular dysfunction without echocardiographic assessment in the last year, and known or suspected moderate to severe valvular stenosis or regurgitation without echocardiographic assessment in the past year or with a change in clinical status.

objective.__html: Avoid preoperative testing for low-risk surgery.

references: Cohn SL. Preoperative evaluation for noncardiac surgery.

title: Question 87

children: An 18-year-old man is evaluated during a preparticipation physical examination for his college soccer team. He is asymptomatic. He describes no limitation in his exercise capacity, palpitations, syncope, presyncope, dyspnea, or chest discomfort. He has exercise-induced bronchospasm. His only medication is a budesonide-formoterol inhaler that he uses before exercise. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use any drugs. There is no family history of cardiac disease or sudden death.
Physical examination findings, including vital signs and cardiac auscultation, are normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate test to perform?
Routine testing beyond the history and physical examination is not necessary in the preparticipation physical examination unless concerning symptoms and physical findings are uncovered.
Mandatory components of the preparticipation physical examination include evaluating for exertional symptoms, family history of premature or sudden cardiac death, and presence of a heart murmur.
There is no indication for testing (
Option D

). Preparticipation physical examination is often required for adolescents and young adults before participation in organized sports. The goal of a preparticipation physical evaluation is to determine an individual's safe participation in sports, although studies have not found that the preparticipation screening examination prevents morbidity and mortality associated with sports. Advocates claim that it may detect conditions that predispose the athlete to injury or illness, which then may guide advice or intervention. The examination should not be a barrier to competitive sports participation, and unnecessary testing should be avoided owing to its attendant costs and unintended consequences, such as downstream testing for incidental findings. Mandatory components include evaluating for exertional symptoms, family history of premature or sudden cardiac death, and presence of a heart murmur. Routine testing beyond the history and physical examination is not necessary unless concerning symptoms and physical findings are uncovered. This patient has exercise-induced bronchospasm but an unlimited exercise capacity and no other concerning symptoms or physical findings. There is no indication for testing.
Chest radiography and spirometry (
Options A, C

) are not indicated for a preparticipation physical examination in a patient with either well-controlled asthma or exercise-induced bronchospasm, as is the case for this patient. The indications for these tests are the same as those in other patients, specifically a suspicion of pulmonary disease on the basis of symptoms or abnormal findings on pulmonary examination.
Echocardiography (
Option B

) is not indicated as a component of the preparticipation physical examination unless there is known or suspected cardiac disease. Although hypertrophic cardiomyopathy may very rarely present as sudden death in the young athlete, the prevalence of the disease is so low that routine echocardiography is not an effective screening strategy. Findings that would prompt echocardiography include exertional syncope; family history of sudden death; and physical findings suggestive of cardiac disease, including an unexplained murmur. This patient has none of these findings, and echocardiography is not necessary. An ECG is clearly indicated if the patient has unexplained syncope; palpitations; or a family history of sudden death that is suggestive of a congenital abnormality, such as long QT syndrome. Although some guidelines suggest routine ECG, the American College of Cardiology and American Heart Association do not.

objective.__html: Evaluate a patient for preparticipation physical examination.

references: Mirabelli MH, Devine MJ, Singh J, et al. The preparticipation sports evaluation. Am Fam Physician. 2015;92:371-6.

title: Question 88

children: A 72-year-old man is evaluated for a 6-month history of a painful lesion on the left ear that is increasing in size. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable.
Skin findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma presents as pink, scaly, indurated plaques, papules, or nodules that can ulcerate, bleed, or become crusty.
Squamous cell carcinoma on the central face, lips, or ear is considered high risk and should be treated with Mohs micrographic surgery.
Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) (
Option D

), the second most common skin cancer, is a malignant neoplasm of keratinocytes. It usually presents as pink, scaly, indurated plaques, papules, or nodules that can ulcerate, bleed, or become crusty. SCCs tend to retain their surface scale, and as an SCC accumulates a large amount of scale, it is called a cutaneous horn. Risk factors are exposure to UV light, ionizing radiation, or chemical carcinogens (coal tar, soot, and arsenic); viruses (human papillomavirus); and immunosuppression (organ transplant, hematologic malignancies, HIV infection). SCC on the central face, lips, or ear, as seen in this patient, is considered high risk and should be treated with Mohs micrographic surgery. Mohs micrographic surgery is a highly specialized surgical technique that combines pathology and surgery for complete margin control and tissue conservation. It is appropriately used for cancers in the head and neck region, those that are large or recurrent, or those in areas where tissue-sparing is critical for function.
Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) (
Option A

) is the most common skin cancer. It commonly presents as a pink, pearly papule with rolled borders and arborizing telangiectasias. Patients commonly report bleeding of BCCs with any manipulation, such as shaving or washing the face. BCC does not present as hyperkeratotic lesions, as seen in this patient. Similar to SCC, BCC is usually treated with surgical excision. Mohs micrographic surgery is appropriate for BCC in the head and neck region.
SCC in situ is referred to as Bowen disease (
Option B

). In this condition, malignant keratinocytes are confined to the epidermis. Bowen disease appears as larger scaly pink and tan plaques with well-defined borders and does not resemble this patient's hyperkeratotic nodule. Small lesions can be excised for cure; larger lesions may be more amenable to destructive therapies, such as curettage and electrodesiccation or cryotherapy.
Seborrheic keratoses (
Option C

) are benign pigmented neoplasms of keratinocyte origin that are common in adults. They are “stuck-on” papules and plaques that occur anywhere on the body but are most common on the trunk and spare the palms, soles, and mucous membranes. Usually they are brown, but they can range in color from tan to black. When seborrheic keratoses are symptomatic, they may be treated with cryotherapy or shave removal. This patient's hyperkeratotic nodule on the ear is most consistent with SCC.

objective.__html: Diagnose squamous cell carcinoma.

references: Kim JY, Kozlow JH, Mittal B, et al; Work Group. Guidelines of care for the management of cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma. J Am Acad Dermatol. 2018;78:560-78.

title: Question 89

children: A 19-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency department for a 3-day history of progressively severe sore throat. She cannot swallow liquids due to pain and has drooling.

On physical examination, temperature is 38.5 °C (101.3 °F), blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, pulse rate is 110/min, and respiration rate is 25/min. There is no stridor. She is drooling. The oropharynx is hyperemic, and the patient has difficulty opening her mouth fully. The uvula is engorged.
Antibiotics are initiated.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
Patients with epiglottitis typically appear seriously ill, with excessive salivation and drooling, tachypnea, stridor, and severe pharyngitis and dysphagia.
If severe acute epiglottitis is suspected and airway obstruction seems imminent, airway control should precede diagnostic evaluation.
The most appropriate next step in management is admission to the ICU (
Option A

). This patient likely has acute epiglottitis. Epiglottitis is a severe and rare inflammatory response to a respiratory infection that requires emergent identification and treatment, with close attention to airway management. Although viral causes are common, epiglottitis may also be caused by
Streptococcus pneumoniae
and other bacterial respiratory pathogens. Before universal vaccination,
Haemophilus influenzae

type B accounted for most infections. Patients with epiglottitis may present with findings of sepsis, including fever, tachycardia, severe sore throat, drooling that suggests difficulty managing normal secretions, stridor, and inability to open the mouth. Although adults with acute epiglottitis are less likely than children to progress to airway obstruction, if acute epiglottitis is suspected and airway obstruction is a consideration, airway management is a priority. Patients rarely require intubation or tracheostomy; however, hospital admission is recommended, often to an ICU setting and with surgical consultation, to ensure close monitoring of the airway. Parenteral antibiotic therapy directed toward common respiratory pathogens is additionally indicated. Typical choices for empiric therapy include ceftriaxone or cefotaxime and vancomycin.
Although parenteral glucocorticoids, such methylprednisolone (
Option B

), are sometimes used to minimize airway inflammation in acute epiglottis, there is little evidence supporting effectiveness. Other measures, including airway management and initiation of parenteral antibiotics, are of far greater urgency.
Fusobacterium necrophorum

infection can cause Lemierre syndrome, a rare suppurative complication of pharyngitis caused by local spread of infection with resultant septic thrombosis of the internal jugular vein. Clinicians should suspect Lemierre syndrome in patients with severe pharyngitis and neck pain that do not respond to appropriate antibiotics. Diagnosis is made with neck CT with contrast (
Option C

). In patients with suspected epiglottitis, radiographic imaging with ultrasonography or plain radiography may be helpful in gauging the severity of neck tissue inflammation and predicting likelihood of progression. For this patient, CT of the neck is unwarranted and would delay her transfer to the ICU for careful airway monitoring and intervention if required.
Although a rapid antigen detection test (RADT) (
Option D
) is a reasonable test for group A streptococcal pharyngitis, this patient has acute epiglottitis with possible airway compromise and there is no role for RADT.

objective.__html: Manage a patient with suspected epiglottitis.

references: Klein MR. Infections of the oropharynx. Emerg Med Clin North Am. 2019;37:69-80.

title: Question 90

children: A 33-year-old woman is evaluated for a 6-month history of bilateral breast pain that begins before her menstrual period and resolves after the onset of menstruation. She reports no other breast symptoms, masses, or nipple discharge. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable. Family history is significant for breast cancer in her grandmother at age 67 years. Her only medication is a combined hormonal oral contraceptive pill.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. Bilateral breast examination results are normal, with no masses or nipple discharge. There is no lymphadenopathy.
A pregnancy test result is negative.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

If a clinical breast examination is normal, management of bilateral cyclic breast pain is conservative and includes education, reassurance regarding the absence of malignancy, wearing a supportive and well-fitting bra, and topical NSAID therapy.
Danazol is the only FDA-approved agent for cyclic breast pain but should be considered only in women with severe pain in whom conservative management has failed.
The most appropriate management is patient education and reassurance (
Option D

). This patient has bilateral cyclic breast pain. Most common in women aged 20 to 39 years, cyclic breast pain is often diffuse and bilateral, occurs during the premenstrual phase, and resolves with onset of menstruation; it is usually associated with hormonal changes and is typically benign. If findings on clinical breast examination (CBE) are normal, additional screening for malignancy beyond age-appropriate screening is not required. Cyclic breast pain should be managed conservatively with education, reassurance regarding the absence of malignancy, and wearing a supportive and well-fitting bra. Although some patients benefit from topical NSAID therapy, pain resolves spontaneously for most women. There is a lack of evidence to support limiting caffeine intake or using vitamin E as a means of mitigating the pain.
Breast ultrasonography (
Option A

) is not indicated for this patient. Women with cyclic diffuse breast pain and a normal CBE do not require additional imaging. For women younger than 30 years who have focal breast pain or an abnormal CBE, breast ultrasonography is appropriate for further evaluation. This patient is 33 years old; if indicated, mammography would be the appropriate diagnostic modality.
Danazol (
Option B

) is the only FDA-approved agent for cyclic breast pain, but its use is limited because of side effects, including amenorrhea, hirsutism, and adverse changes in lipid profile. It should be considered only in women with severe pain in whom conservative management has failed.
Mammography (
Option C

) is not indicated. Given this patient's age, she does not qualify for routine screening mammography, and her family history does not suggest a hereditary cancer syndrome that would qualify for early screening. Mammography would be the most appropriate management in patients older than 30 years who present with noncyclic focal breast pain or have an abnormal CBE. Noncyclic breast pain is often caused by medication use (contraceptive agents, hormone replacement therapy, psychiatric medications), underlying breast disease (fibrocystic disease, infection, trauma, cancer), or stretching of the Cooper ligaments (connective tissue that maintains breast structural integrity).

objective.__html: Manage cyclic breast pain.

references: Salzman B, Collins E, Hersh L. Common breast problems. Am Fam Physician. 2019;99:505-14.

title: Question 91

children: A 55-year-old woman is evaluated for 3-month history of mildly pruritic rash on her feet, with thickening and discoloration of several toenails. She states that she is not concerned about the toenails because polish covers them. She has no other medical problems.
Skin findings are
shown
Upon removing the toenail polish, several nails are dystrophic, with subungual keratosis and discoloration.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's rash?

The chronic form of tinea pedis presents as mildly pruritic scaly patches involving most of the soles in a “moccasin” distribution; the interdigital variant of tinea pedis shows fissures and maceration in the folds.
Recommended treatment of localized tinea on non–hair-bearing skin is terbinafine or imidazole creams, such as miconazole, clotrimazole, and ketoconazole.
The most appropriate treatment for this patient's rash is terbinafine cream (
Option E

). This patient has tinea pedis. The chronic form of tinea pedis presents as mildly pruritic scaly patches involving most of the soles in a “moccasin” distribution. “Two feet-one hand” tinea is a characteristic pattern of involvement. Tinea pedis can have a more acute form, with 1- to 2-mm vesicles, and can be extremely pruritic. The interdigital variant of tinea pedis shows fissures and maceration in the folds (as
shown

This patient's plaques with serpiginous and arcuate scaly borders in a moccasin distribution should raise suspicion for dermatophyte infection. Tinea should be treated to prevent skin breakdown, which can be an entry port for bacterial infection. Dermatophytosis of non–hair-bearing skin with limited involvement can be treated topically with the use of topical terbinafine or imidazole creams, such as miconazole, clotrimazole, and ketoconazole, applied once to twice daily for 2 to 4 weeks, ensuring that the application extends a few centimeters beyond the advancing border. Combined antifungals and topical glucocorticoids should be avoided because they can lead to increased recurrences and treatment failures.
Adalimumab (
Option A
) and clobetasol (
Option B

) are not helpful in the treatment of dermatophytosis but are effective in the treatment of psoriasis, which can affect the soles of the feet and nails. Psoriasis appears as discrete, sharply marginated red plaques with silvery lamellar scale. The arcuate and serpiginous scale and the dull brown-red color of this patient's skin findings are not consistent with the presentation of psoriasis.
Topical nystatin cream (
Option C
) is beneficial in the treatment of cutaneous candidiasis, but it is not effective in the treatment of dermatophyte infections, such as tinea pedis.
Although systemic antifungal agents, such as itraconazole (
Option D

), can be beneficial in the treatment of onychomycosis, this patient reports she is not concerned with treating her toenails. Furthermore, itraconazole is rarely used for the treatment of onychomycosis due to its side effect profile. Systemic terbinafine or fluconazole are more commonly utilized.

objective.__html: Treat tinea pedis.

references: Aizenberg DJ. Common complaints of the hands and feet. Med Clin North Am. 2021;105:187-97.

title: Question 92

children: A 59-year-old woman is evaluated in the hospital for postoperative ileus following a hysterectomy. She reports worsening nausea and abdominal fullness. Her last bowel movement was on the morning of surgery. She has been using hydrocodone for pain. Her only other medication is prophylactic low-molecular-weight heparin.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. There is a healing hysterectomy incision. The abdomen is diffusely tender without guarding; bowel sounds are decreased.
Comprehensive metabolic profile is normal.
Plain abdominal radiograph shows mildly dilated loops of small and large bowel with air fluid levels and air throughout the colon.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
Treatment of postoperative ileus consists of minimizing the use of opioids, hydration, bowel rest, electrolyte repletion, postoperative ambulation, and use of chewing gum.
Minimally invasive surgical approaches, multimodal analgesia techniques, prophylactic bowel regimens, and early ambulation may help to prevent postoperative ileus.
The most appropriate management is to decrease the patient's opioid use (
Option B

). This patient likely has a postoperative ileus (POI). POI is common after both intra-abdominal and nonabdominal surgery. It is caused by a combination of intraperitoneal inflammation, neuroinhibition of the sympathetic nervous system, and medications (such as opioids and anesthesia). There is no specific therapy for postoperative ileus other than supportive. Supportive therapy consists of minimizing the use of opioids, hydration, bowel rest, electrolyte repletion, postoperative ambulation, and use of chewing gum. Minimally invasive surgical approaches, multimodal analgesia techniques, prophylactic bowel regimens, and early ambulation may help to prevent POI.
Plain radiography is usually adequate to diagnose POI and to distinguish it from small-bowel obstruction. CT of the abdomen (
Option A
) is indicated if any suspicion for small-bowel obstruction remains, particularly if the ileus is prolonged beyond 3 to 4 days. There is no indication for CT for this patient at this time.

In patients receiving long-standing opioid therapy and who have severe constipation, a peripherally acting µ-opioid receptor antagonist, such as methylnaltrexone, can be effective in improving bowel motility. Although opioids may be contributing to this patient's POI, they are unlikely to be the only cause and methylnaltrexone therapy (
Option C
) is unlikely to be successful in reversing the ileus.
Gastric decompression with a nasogastric tube (
Option D
) is indicated for patients with significant vomiting, bowel distention, or abdominal pain. These indications are not present.

Acute colonic pseudo-obstruction (Ogilvie syndrome) is characterized by acute dilatation of the colon in the absence of a mechanical obstruction. This condition is usually found in severely ill hospitalized patients or after surgery that is complicated by a metabolic disturbance or medications that inhibit peristalsis. Patients have abdominal distention with pain, anorexia, nausea, and vomiting. Plain radiography documents a dilated colon. The initial management is supportive care, but treatment with neostigmine is often attempted in patients in whom conservative therapy has failed. On the basis of findings on this patient's radiograph, she does not have acute colonic pseudo-obstruction and does not require neostigmine (
Option E

objective.__html: Manage postoperative ileus.

references: Vilz TO, Stoffels B, Strassburg C, et al. Ileus in adults. Dtsch Arztebl Int. 2017;114:508-18.

title: Question 93

children: A randomized controlled screening trial for prostate cancer is reviewed. Men who were screened with a prostate-specific antigen blood test were compared with men who were not screened. Results were analyzed according to their original group assignment. Approximately 1.3 deaths from prostate cancer were prevented over 13 years per 1000 men screened. Overall mortality was not reduced by screening. Men in the screened population were more likely to undergo repeated biopsies and report higher levels of anxiety, and they had greater rates of infection and bleeding complications.
Which of the following is most likely responsible for these results?
Overdiagnosis is finding and treating illness that otherwise would not have become clinically apparent or caused harm in the patient's lifetime and is often associated with patient harm.
Lead-time bias occurs when early detection artificially results in an increase in measured survival.
Overdiagnosis (
Option C

) is most likely responsible for the small reduction in cancer-related deaths and increase in harm. Length-time bias occurs when screening detects more cases of disease with a prolonged asymptomatic phase than aggressive cases of disease with a short asymptomatic phase. Slowly progressive disease is more likely than aggressive disease to be detected with screening, leading to an overestimation of survival benefit in patients with screen-detected disease. Overdiagnosis, or finding and treating illness that otherwise would not have become clinically apparent or caused harm in the patient's lifetime, is an extreme example of length-time bias. Overdiagnosis not uncommonly leads to harm due to overtesting and unnecessary treatments.
All-cause mortality (
Option A

) rather than cancer-specific mortality has been proposed as a preferable end point in randomized controlled trials on the basis of possible biases in assignment of cause of death. Misassignment can falsely elevate or decrease cancer-related deaths. All-cause mortality is a less ambiguous assignment and reduces bias and does not account for the results of this study.
Lead-time bias (
Option B

) occurs when early detection artificially results in an increase in measured survival. The time between early detection and clinical diagnosis is mistakenly counted as survival time; however, only the measured time with diagnosed disease, not survival time, has increased. Using mortality rates rather than survival time as the primary outcome in studies of screening tests in randomized controlled trials can help minimize lead-time bias. This randomized controlled trial used a specific disease-related end point as well as overall mortality. The risk for lead-time bias is low in this study and cannot account for the results.
Selection bias (
Option D

) occurs when patients who undergo screening tests are healthier and more interested in their health than the general population. Intention-to-treat analyses, in which patients are analyzed according to their original group assignment in randomized clinical trials regardless of intervention received, reduce the risk for selection bias. Participants in this study were randomized into the two arms of the study and the results were analyzed according to their original group assignment; risk for selection bias was thus reduced, and such bias cannot account for the results.

objective.__html: Identify overdiagnosis as a cause of harm due to screening.

references: Berry DA. Failure of researchers, reviewers, editors, and the media to understand flaws in cancer screening studies: application to an article in Cancer. Cancer. 2014;120:2784-91.

title: Question 94

children: A 58-year-old man is evaluated for a 2-day history of nonradiating, right-sided scrotal pain and swelling. The pain began insidiously and has slowly worsened in intensity. He also reports dysuria and frequency but no fever or hematuria. He has no previous history of scrotal pain, trauma, or urologic procedures. He is sexually active only with his wife and has no history of sexually transmitted infections. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and he takes no medications.

On physical examination, vital signs are normal. Tenderness is limited to the posterior aspect of the right testicle. Scrotal pain is relieved with elevation of the scrotum. Cremasteric reflex is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
Enteric bacteria are the most commonly implicated pathogens causing epididymitis in men older than 35 years and at low risk for sexually transmitted infections.
Chlamydia trachomatis
and
Neisseria gonorrhoeae
are the most commonly implicated pathogens causing epididymitis in patients aged 35 years or younger and in those at high risk for sexually transmitted infections.
The most appropriate management is oral levofloxacin (
Option D

). This patient has acute epididymitis characterized by unilateral scrotal pain of gradual onset that worsens over a period of days. In men older than 35 years and in those who are at low risk for sexually transmitted infections (STIs), the most likely pathogen is an enteric bacterium, such as
Escherichia coli

. The most appropriate therapy is an empiric 10-day course of oral levofloxacin. Other important management measures include rest, NSAIDs, and scrotal support. At the time of presentation, urinalysis should be obtained; if results are abnormal, urine culture should be performed. However, antimicrobial therapy should not be delayed while awaiting culture results.
Acute epididymitis is a clinical diagnosis. Doppler ultrasonography of the scrotum (
Option A

) is not indicated in patients who present with both historical and examination findings consistent with acute epididymitis (as is the case for this patient). Doppler ultrasonography is helpful when there is diagnostic uncertainty; Doppler findings suggestive of acute epididymitis include increased epididymal blood flow and swelling. Lack of blood flow would indicate a urologic emergency, such as testicular torsion, which is unlikely in the presence of an intact cremasteric reflex.
A single dose of intramuscular ceftriaxone and a 10-day course of oral doxycycline (
Option B

) is appropriate empiric antimicrobial therapy in patients with acute epididymitis who are 35 years of age or younger and in men are at high risk for STIs. In these cases, common causative organisms include
Neisseria gonorrhoeae
and
Chlamydia trachomatis
; nucleic acid amplification testing for these organisms should be obtained. This regimen is not indicated for patients who are older than 35 years and in those at low risk for STIs.
A single dose of intramuscular ceftriaxone and a 10-day course of oral levofloxacin (
Option C
) is appropriate empiric therapy for patients with acute epididymitis who practice insertive anal intercourse because it provides coverage against coliform bacteria,
N. gonorrhoeae,
and
C. trachomatis.
This regimen is not indicated for this patient who is sexually active only with his wife.

objective.__html: Manage acute epididymitis in an older man.

references: McConaghy JR, Panchal B. Epididymitis: an overview. Am Fam Physician. 2016;94:723-6.

title: Question 95

children: An 18-year-old woman is evaluated for sunburn of the dorsal hands and dorsal feet with burning and pruritus that began 6 hours after walking on the beach. Medical history is significant for acne. Medications are drospirenone-ethinyl estradiol oral contraceptive, doxycycline, and tretinoin cream.
Skin findings on the feet are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Phototoxic reactions present as exaggerated sunburn within minutes to hours of sun exposure; tetracyclines are a common inciting agent.
The most likely diagnosis is phototoxic drug reaction (
Option C

). This patient presents with the characteristic erythema and blistering of a phototoxic drug reaction. Phototoxic drug reactions usually present as exaggerated sunburn due to direct cellular injury. Unlike photoallergic reactions, they are not immunologically mediated and do not require prior sensitization; reactions occur minutes to hours after sun exposure. Tetracyclines, including doxycycline, are one of the most common causes of phototoxic drug reactions. In addition to exaggerated sunburn, tetracycline-induced phototoxicity may present with photo-onycholysis (separation of the nail from the nail bed) and pseudoporphyria. Minocycline may cause less photosensitization than other tetracyclines. Other common causes of phototoxic reactions include sulfonamides, hydrochlorothiazide, fluoroquinolones, antimalarials, amiodarone, and voriconazole. Discontinuation of the photosensitizing drug and sun avoidance measures will lead to resolution of the reaction. Topical glucocorticoids can be used for symptomatic treatment.
Bullous pemphigoid (
Option A
) is a pruritic autoimmune blistering disorder that presents most commonly in elderly persons. It does not present acutely after sun exposure and is a very unlikely diagnosis in this young patient.
A photoallergic drug reaction (
Option B

) is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction that is less common than phototoxic drug reactions and occurs in patients with prior sensitization to the offending drug. This type of drug reaction typically presents more than 24 hours after exposure. It clinically presents as eczematous dermatitis and less commonly as exaggerated sunburn. Although many drugs can cause both a phototoxic and photoallergic drug reaction, doxycycline is not known to cause a photoallergic drug reaction.
Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT) (
Option D

) is a blistering disorder that presents most commonly in persons older than 40 years, usually on the dorsal hands. It is associated with hepatitis C virus infection, alcohol-related liver disease, hemochromatosis, and HIV infection. Although PCT is a photosensitive blistering disorder, it is not the most likely diagnosis in this young woman taking doxycycline.

objective.__html: Diagnose phototoxic reaction to doxycycline.

references: Monteiro AF, Rato M, Martins C. Drug-induced photosensitivity: photoallergic and phototoxic reactions. Clin Dermatol. 2016;34:571-81.
doi:10.1016/j.clindermatol.2016.05.006

title: Question 96

children: A 24-year-old woman is evaluated for a 2-year history of painful menstrual periods, causing her to miss work once or twice a month. She reports no abnormal vaginal bleeding or discharge. Her last menstrual period was 1 week ago. She is sexually active with men and uses condoms for contraception. Her last sexual intercourse was 2 months ago. She does not desire pregnancy at this time. Her last Pap smear obtained 1 year ago was normal. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and she takes no medications.
Physical examination, including pelvic examination, is normal.
A pregnancy test result and chlamydia screening are negative.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
Management options for primary or secondary dysmenorrhea include empiric treatment with either combined hormonal contraceptives or progesterone-only methods.
NSAIDs are an effective treatment for dysmenorrhea, acting by reducing the release of prostaglandins and thereby helping to reduce cramping and menstrual blood loss.
The most appropriate management is a combined hormonal oral contraceptive pill (
Option B

). Dysmenorrhea is characterized by pain and cramping during menstruation and can be associated with low back pain, nausea, headache, and gastrointestinal symptoms. Dysmenorrhea is classified as either primary, when there is no identified cause, or secondary, for which endometriosis is the most common cause. Many women with dysmenorrhea have symptoms severe enough to result in missed school, work, or other activities. Whether primary or secondary dysmenorrhea, empiric treatment with either combined hormonal contraceptives (pill, patch, or ring) or progesterone-only methods (pill, injection, implant, or intrauterine device [IUD]) are appropriate options. Before prescribing a combined hormonal contraceptive, it is important to assess for contraindications to estrogen, including a history of venous thromboembolism or migraine with aura. In this patient without contraindications and a need for more effective contraceptive therapy, a combined hormonal oral contraceptive pill is a reasonable option.
Acetaminophen (
Option A

) is often used for the treatment of dysmenorrhea; it may be more effective than placebo but is not as effective as NSAIDs. NSAIDs reduce the release of prostaglandins and thereby help reduce cramps and menstrual blood loss. Because of this patient's need for more effective contraception, a combined hormonal oral contraceptive is a more attractive option than either acetaminophen or NSAIDs.
A copper IUD (
Option C

) would not improve the patient's dysmenorrhea. Some women report heavier menstrual bleeding and increased cramping with use of the copper IUD. Levonorgestrel-releasing IUDs, however, are an effective treatment modality for women with dysmenorrhea who are interested in long-acting contraceptive options.
Transvaginal ultrasonography (
Option D

) is not required to diagnose or treat dysmenorrhea in the setting of a normal physical examination. Even if there is a concern for a secondary cause of dysmenorrhea, such as endometriosis, empiric treatment is recommended before initiating diagnostic studies.

objective.__html: Treat dysmenorrhea.

references: Kho KA, Shields JK. Diagnosis and management of primary dysmenorrhea. JAMA. 2020;323:268-9.

title: Question 97

children: A 65-year old man is evaluated during a wellness visit. He has a 50–pack-year smoking history but quit smoking 7 years ago. He is up to date on colorectal and lung cancer screening. He prefers not to be screened for prostate cancer. He has not been screened for abdominal aortic aneurysm.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. BMI is 35.
Which of the following is the most appropriate screening test?

text.__html: Magnetic resonance angiography of the abdomen

children: According to the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force, one-time abdominal ultrasonography is the preferred screening modality for abdominal aortic aneurysm in men aged 65 to 75 years who have smoked at least five packs of cigarettes in their lifetime.
The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force specifically recommends against routine screening for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) in women who have never smoked and who have no family history of AAA.
The most appropriate screening test is abdominal ultrasonography (
Option C

). This patient has a 50–pack-year smoking history. According to the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF), one-time abdominal ultrasonography is the preferred screening modality for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) in men aged 65 to 75 years who have smoked at least five packs of cigarettes in their lifetime (grade B). Screening with ultrasonography is noninvasive, is simple to perform, has high sensitivity (94%-100%) and specificity (98%-100%) for detecting AAA, and does not expose patients to radiation. Abdominal ultrasonography screening can also be performed selectively in men in the same age range who have not smoked but are at increased risk for peripheral vascular disease or who have a first-degree relative who had an AAA (grade C). The USPSTF assessed the benefits of screening for AAA in women aged 65 to 75 years who have ever smoked as uncertain and makes no recommendation regarding screening in this population (I statement). The USPSTF specifically recommends against routine screening in women who have never smoked and who have no family history of AAA (grade D). Smoking cessation and treatment of hypertension can prevent the development of aneurysmal disease.
Auscultation of the abdomen for bruits and palpation (
Option A

) to detect pulsatile enlargement of the aorta have low sensitivity (39%-68%) and specificity (75%) for AAA and are not recommended for screening, especially in patients with obesity, such as this patient with a BMI of 35.
Abdominal CT (
Option B

) is an accurate tool for identifying AAA; however, it is not recommended as a screening method because of the expense and potential for harms from radiation exposure. Once an AAA is identified, CT can provide precise information on its size and location, which is needed to plan surgery.
Although magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) (
Option D
) of the abdomen would detect an AAA, it is expensive and time consuming compared with ultrasonography. Like CT, MRA is typically reserved for surgical planning, if indicated.

objective.__html: Screen for abdominal aortic aneurysm.

references: Owens DK, Davidson KW, Krist AH, et al; US Preventive Services Task Force. Screening for abdominal aortic aneurysm: US Preventive Services Task Force recommendation statement. JAMA. 2019;322:2211-8.

title: Question 98

children: A 40-year-old man is evaluated for a 5-day history of sore throat and fever. He has no cough or nasal congestion. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable. He does not smoke.

On physical examination, temperature is 38.5 °C (101.3 °F). The oropharynx is erythematous, with enlarged tonsils with purulent exudate. The anterior cervical lymph nodes are tender and enlarged. The remainder of the physical examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

text.__html: Rapid antigen detection test for group A Streptococcus

children: The Centor criteria (fever, tonsillar exudates, tender anterior cervical lymphadenopathy, and absence of cough) can used to guide the need for testing (rapid antigen detection test) for group A streptococcal pharyngitis.
Patients presenting with acute pharyngitis and two or fewer Centor criteria do not need to be tested for group A
Streptococcus.
The most appropriate next step in management is a rapid antigen detection test (RADT) for group A
Streptococcus
(GAS) (
Option B

). Acute pharyngitis symptoms typically last less than 1 week. Most cases are viral in etiology, and only 5% to 15% of pharyngitis cases are caused by bacteria, most frequently GAS. The Centor criteria (fever, tonsillar exudates, tender anterior cervical lymphadenopathy, and absence of cough) can help guide the need for testing for bacterial pharyngitis. The Centor criteria have a low positive predictive value for determining the presence of GAS infection and are best used to exclude infection. Patients with two or fewer Centor criteria are very unlikely to have GAS pharyngitis and do not need to be tested or treated with antibiotics. Patients with three or more Centor criteria should be tested by using a RADT for GAS pharyngitis. This patient presents with four Centor criteria, placing him at risk for streptococcal pharyngitis, and a RADT is needed to guide therapy.
Antibiotic therapy with penicillin (
Option A

) or amoxicillin is indicated for GAS pharyngitis to reduce the likelihood of cardiac complications, such as valvular damage from rheumatic fever; lower the risk for pharyngeal abscess; and reduce the duration of symptoms and transmission of infection. Even with multiple findings suggestive of a bacterial etiology, a viral cause is still reasonably likely, and RADT should be completed to confirm GAS pharyngitis before antibiotic treatment. No guideline recommends empiric treatment without testing.
RADT has comparable sensitivity and specificity to throat culture (
Option C

). In patients who are at high risk for complications (immunocompromised, high-risk contacts or environment), a negative RADT result should be confirmed by throat culture; otherwise, it is unnecessary. Results of throat culture generally take 24 to 48 hours. Empiric treatment with antibiotics while results are pending is not recommended because short delays in therapy have not been associated with higher complication rates.
No testing or therapy is inappropriate (
Option D
). Because this patient meets four Centor criteria, placing him at risk for streptococcal pharyngitis, RADT is needed to guide therapy.

objective.__html: Evaluate a patient with acute pharyngitis.

references: Mustafa Z, Ghaffari M. Diagnostic methods, clinical guidelines, and antibiotic treatment for group A streptococcal pharyngitis: a narrative review. Front Cell Infect Microbiol. 2020;10:563627.

title: Question 99

children: A 34-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency department for fever and a painful rash that began 2 days ago. The rash now involves her face, neck, trunk, and arms. She is on day 6 of a 7-day course of sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim for treatment of a recently incised and drained abscess on her left leg.

On physical examination, the patient appears ill and in pain. Temperature is 40 °C (104 °F), blood pressure is 117/62 mm Hg, pulse rate is 122/min, and respiration rate is 16/min. Representative skin findings of her right arm and hand are
shown
The rash is noted on her face, neck, back, trunk, and proximal legs, involving 25% of her body surface area. The abscess site on the left leg is healing without signs of infection.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
The most important first step in preventing progression of Stevens-Johnson syndrome/toxic epidermal necrolysis is to immediately discontinue any potential inciting medications.
The most appropriate management is to discontinue sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim (
Option C

). This patient likely has Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) that is secondary to sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim. SJS and TEN are a spectrum of severe mucocutaneous reactions defined by the extent of affected BSA involved with immune-mediated cutaneous necrosis. If 10% to 30% body surface area is affected, as in this patient, the reaction is termed SJS/TEN overlap syndrome. Symptoms of SJS/TEN usually begin within 1 to 3 weeks of exposure to the inciting agent. Fever, malaise, and symptoms of upper respiratory infection are followed by skin pain, grittiness or sand-like irritation of the eyes, and odynophagia. Within several days of symptom onset, patients develop red or purple dusky macules on the trunk that progress to vesicles, erosions, and ulceration. Painful erosions develop in the mouth, eyes, or genitals in as many as 95% of patients. When SJS/TEN is considered to be a possible diagnosis, the most important first step is to immediately discontinue all nonessential medications because continued exposure to the offending agent can worsen outcomes. The importance of immediate drug withdrawal in patients with SJS/TEN was highlighted in a 10-year observational study that suggested drug withdrawal reduced mortality by 30% for each day the drug was absent before the development of blisters and erosions. This observation did not hold true for drugs with prolonged half-lives.
Treatment for SJS/TEN overlap syndrome remains controversial. Intravenous glucocorticoids (
Option A
) or intravenous immunoglobulin (
Option B

) are likely the most commonly used treatments, but neither is supported by strong evidence. Regardless, initiating therapy with either intravenous glucocorticoids or intravenous immune globulins is secondary in importance to discontinuing the potential offending agent.
Skin biopsy (
Option D

) may be indicated in the evaluation of possible SJS/TEN overlap syndrome if the diagnosis is not conclusive based on clinical findings. When the possibility of SJS/TEN is present, however, skin biopsy is secondary in importance to immediate discontinuation of the possible offending agent.

objective.__html: Treat Stevens-Johnson syndrome/toxic epidermal necrolysis.

references: Mustafa SS, Ostrov D, Yerly D. Severe cutaneous adverse drug reactions: presentation, risk factors, and management. Curr Allergy Asthma Rep. 2018;18:26.

title: Question 100

children: A 72-year-old woman is seen for a preoperative medical evaluation prior to a hemicolectomy for newly diagnosed stage II colon cancer. Five months ago, she underwent drug-eluting coronary artery stent placement for stable ischemic heart disease and is now asymptomatic. Medications are metoprolol, aspirin, clopidogrel, benazepril, and atorvastatin.
Physical examination findings, including vital signs, are normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate preoperative management of this patient's dual antiplatelet therapy?

In patients with coronary stents, guidelines recommend that dual antiplatelet therapy should be continued uninterrupted for 14 to 30 days after bare metal stent placement and a minimum of 3 to 6 months after drug-eluting stent placement.
In patients with an urgent need for surgery, discontinuation of a P2Y
inhibitor can be considered after a minimum of 3 months in patients with a drug-eluting stent; aspirin should be continued if at all possible.
The most appropriate preoperative management of this patient's dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) is to continue aspirin and withhold clopidogrel (
Option B

). In patients with coronary stents, guidelines recommend that DAPT should be continued uninterrupted for 14 to 30 days after bare metal stent placement and 3 to 6 months after drug-eluting stent placement. Elective surgery should be postponed during these time frames. However, if the risk of surgical delay exceeds the risk for stent thrombosis, discontinuation of the P2Y

inhibitor can be considered after a minimum of 3 months in patients with a drug-eluting stent. Low-dose aspirin should be continued if at all possible, and DAPT should be restarted as soon as bleeding risk has sufficiently diminished. Clopidogrel should be withheld 5 days before surgery.

Precise data on the risk for serious DAPT-related bleeding are lacking except in patients undergoing coronary artery bypass graft surgery. Studies have shown that DAPT in these patients increases the incidence of bleeding, reoperation, and transfusion. On the basis of these data, experts recommend discontinuation of P2Y
receptor blockers at least 5 days before surgery for clopidogrel, 7 days for prasugrel, and 3 to 5 days for ticagrelor. Continuing both aspirin and a P2Y
inhibitor (
Option A
) is not recommended.

Decisions regarding perioperative antiplatelet therapy are informed in part by a randomized controlled study of patients with previous coronary artery stenting who subsequently had surgery. The data suggested that patients who continued aspirin throughout the perioperative period had the lowest rate of a major cardiac adverse event. Withholding perioperative aspirin either with or without a P2Y
inhibitor (
Options C, D
) is not recommended. Withholding both aspirin and clopidogrel may be reasonable if the risk for bleeding is extreme or the consequences catastrophic, such as those associated with neurosurgery.
Surgery is associated with proinflammatory effects that may increase the risk for thrombosis, particularly coronary artery thrombosis and stent thrombosis. Aspirin, clopidogrel, and other P2Y

inhibitors are antiplatelet agents, which can mitigate this risk. Balancing the risk for bleeding and thrombosis is key, and continuation of both agents may lead to unacceptable bleeding risk. In general, bleeding risk with aspirin is lower than that with clopidogrel in the perioperative period, so continuing aspirin alone is recommended during this time frame.

objective.__html: Manage perioperative dual antiplatelet therapy for a patient undergoing urgent noncardiac surgery.

references: Banerjee S, Angiolillo DJ, Boden WE, et al. Use of antiplatelet therapy/DAPT for post-PCI patients undergoing noncardiac surgery. J Am Coll Cardiol. 2017;69:1861-70.

title: Question 101

children: A 56-year-old woman is evaluated for a 2-year history of worsening hot flashes and night sweats. She reports that the night sweats awaken her several times nightly, resulting in fatigue and missed work. History is significant for hypertension and hysterectomy at age 48 years for uterine fibroids. She has no history of venous thromboembolism. Findings on screening mammography 1 year ago were negative. Family history is significant for breast cancer in her grandmother, diagnosed at age 75 years. The patient's only medication is amlodipine.
On physical examination, blood pressure is 134/82 mm Hg; other vital signs are normal. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
Hormone therapy is the most effective treatment for vasomotor symptoms associated with menopause.

Transdermal estrogen is recommended for patients with moderate risk for coronary artery disease, increased risk for venous thromboembolism, hypertriglyceridemia, or high or intermediate risk for breast cancer.
The most appropriate treatment is transdermal estrogen (
Option C

). Although associated with risk, hormone therapy is the most effective medication for vasomotor symptoms associated with menopause (hot flashes, night sweats). This patient is experiencing symptoms severe enough to result in missed work, which warrants hormone therapy. Before initiating therapy, patients should be assessed for contraindications, including unexplained vaginal bleeding, liver disease, coronary artery disease, stroke, thromboembolic disease, and breast or endometrial cancer. This patient has no risk factors for complications of hormonal therapy. Her only other health condition is controlled hypertension, and her mammogram obtained 1 year ago was negative. The lowest dose of estrogen therapy needed to manage symptoms should be used, and vasomotor symptoms and risk factors should be assessed annually. All women receiving hormone therapy should also receive individualized breast cancer risk assessments. This patient does not have a first-degree relative with breast cancer or other markers of elevated risk for breast cancer, but she should be advised that hormone therapy is associated with an increased risk for breast cancer in a dose-dependent fashion; estrogen therapy alone is lower risk than estrogen plus progesterone (
Option A

). When hormonal therapy is indicated, transdermal estrogen may be preferable to oral estrogen because it is associated with less thromboembolic risk. However, this is based on limited observational data, and head-to-head comparisons are lacking. Guidelines are in general agreement in recommending transdermal estrogen in patients with moderate risk for coronary artery disease, increased risk for venous thromboembolism, hypertriglyceridemia, or high or intermediate risk for breast cancer.
Oral gabapentin (
Option B

) taken nightly can be an effective nonhormonal option for the management of vasomotor symptoms of menopause. However, it is less effective than hormonal therapy, and given the severity of this patient's symptoms and the absence of contraindications, she should be offered transdermal estrogen.
Transdermal or oral estrogen plus oral progesterone (
Option D

) is not appropriate treatment. A progestin is only needed for patients with a uterus to prevent estrogen-related endometrial proliferation and hyperplasia. This patient previously underwent hysterectomy. When used, progestins can be dosed either continuously or cyclically. Women receiving progestins cyclically may experience withdrawal bleeding.

objective.__html: Manage vasomotor symptoms of menopause with hormone therapy.

references: The NAMS 2017 Hormone Therapy Position Statement Advisory Panel. The 2017 hormone therapy position statement of the North American Menopause Society. Menopause. 2017;24:728-53.

title: Question 102

children: A 44-year-old woman is evaluated for redness, tearing, and irritation of the right eye that began 1 day ago. She reports no eye pain, photophobia, or change in vision. Her left eye is uninvolved. She has no other symptoms. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and she takes no medications.
On physical examination, visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes. Pupils are equally round and reactive to light and accommodation. The right eye is
shown.
There is no preauricular lymphadenopathy.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The classic presentation of episcleritis is an abrupt onset of unilateral eye redness due to dilated episcleral blood vessels, irritation, and tearing, with no pain, photophobia, or change in vision.

The cardinal sign of scleritis is edema of the sclera often associated with an underlying violaceous discoloration of the sclera and intense dilation of the episcleral blood vessels, accounting for the red eye.
The most likely diagnosis is episcleritis (
Option A

), or inflammation of the episclera, the highly vascularized connective tissue layer that lies between the conjunctiva and sclera. This patient has a classic presentation of episcleritis, with abrupt onset of unilateral eye redness, irritation, and tearing. Pain, photophobia, and vision changes are typically absent. Examination shows dilation of superficial episcleral blood vessels, with normal sclera visualized between the blood vessels. Redness can be localized or diffuse; involvement is more commonly unilateral than bilateral. Nodular variants of episcleritis also occur. Although most causes of episcleritis are idiopathic, it can be associated with systemic conditions, including rheumatoid arthritis, vasculitis, and inflammatory bowel disease. Women are more commonly affected than men, with most cases occurring in those who are young or middle aged. Use of a topical vasoconstrictor, such as phenylephrine, results in improvement in eye redness and can help confirm the diagnosis.
Although herpes simplex keratitis (
Option B

) is in the differential diagnosis of red eye, it typically causes significant eye pain, photophobia, and visual blurring, which are not present in this patient. Herpes simplex keratitis can lead to vision loss due to corneal damage and, when suspected, should prompt immediate referral to an ophthalmologist.
Scleritis (
Option C

), inflammation of the sclera, is an unlikely diagnosis for this patient because it causes intense, boring eye pain and photophobia. The cardinal sign of scleritis is edema of the sclera often associated with a violaceous discoloration of the underlying sclera and intense dilation of the episcleral blood vessels accounting for the red eye.
Uveitis (
Option D

) is a potentially vision-threatening condition that typically causes severe ocular pain and photophobia, both of which are absent in this patient. In addition, the eye redness observed with uveitis is most prominent at the boundary between the iris and sclera, a pattern termed ciliary flush. In some patients, a collection of leukocytes (hypopyon) is seen pooling in the inferior aspect of the anterior chamber.
Viral conjunctivitis (
Option E

) is an unlikely diagnosis because it causes diffuse eye redness, as opposed to the localized redness seen in this patient. Symptoms of viral conjunctivitis classically start in one eye before spreading to the other eye. Eye redness is typically accompanied by watery discharge, and the tarsal conjunctiva may appear bumpy. Preauricular lymphadenopathy is commonly present.

objective.__html: Diagnose episcleritis.

references: Tarff A, Behrens A. Ocular emergencies: red eye. Med Clin North Am. 2017;101:615-39.

title: Question 103

children: A 44-year-old man is evaluated for a 6-week history of a mildly itchy rash in his armpits.
The rash is confined to the axillae. There is some fine scale. Skin findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test?

text.__html: Mineral oil preparation of skin scraping
Potassium hydroxide preparation of skin scraping

children: Erythrasma, a superficial skin infection, manifests as thin, atrophic, finely wrinkled pink-brown plaques in the intertriginous areas; Wood lamp evaluation reveals a soft coral-red or pink fluorescence.
Symptoms of erythrasma are limited to mild pruritus, and treatment for localized disease is topical erythromycin.
Wood lamp evaluation (
Option D
) is the most appropriate diagnostic test to perform next. This patient has erythrasma, a superficial skin infection secondary to
Corynebacterium minutissimum

infection. Symptoms, limited to pruritus, are minimal in most patients. Erythrasma manifests as thin, atrophic, finely wrinkled pink-brown plaques in the intertriginous areas, such as the axillae or inguinal or gluteal folds, or less commonly in the interdigital or inframammary regions. The skin is often described as having “cigarette paper” appearance. A Wood lamp evaluation reveals a soft coral-red or pink fluorescence, as
shown
in this patient with interdigital erythrasma.

Treatment is with oral or topical erythromycin (preferred for localized disease). Typical skin findings plus fluorescence with Wood lamp illumination confirms the diagnosis; additional testing is not needed.
Acanthosis nigricans can appear in the axillae as thickened, hypertrophic velvety hyperpigmented plaques. In patients with acanthosis nigricans, it is important to obtain a hemoglobin A
1c
measurement (
Option A

) to evaluate for the presence of diabetes mellitus or glucose intolerance. The plaques on this patient are atrophic rather than hypertrophic; a Wood lamp evaluation is the most appropriate initial test.
Examination of a potassium hydroxide preparation of skin scrapings (
Option B
) can show fungal elements in the case of dermatophytes or yeast, whereas mineral oil preparation (
Option C
) can highlight ectoparasites, such as
Sarcoptes scabiei
or
Demodex

species. However, the characteristic clinical presentation of tinea corporis is annular scaly patches with central clearing and varying degrees of inflammation; microscopic examination of a potassium hydroxide preparation will show branching hyphae in the scale. Intertrigo is an inflammatory skin disease that involves the axillae, inframammary, and inguinal folds.
Candida

is the most common secondary infection in intertrigo, with obesity being an important risk factor. It presents as erythematous patches with satellite pustules that are often macerated. Diagnosis is frequently made on clinical grounds alone, but a potassium hydroxide preparation can show spores and pseudohyphae. Scabies infestation is characterized by intensely pruritic, crusted papules, nodules, and burrows that develop in the interdigital spaces, wrists, ankles, breasts, periumbilical area, and genitals. Diagnosis is performed by microscopic identification of the mites, eggs, or feces in skin scrapings prepared with mineral oil. The patient's presentation is not typical for dermatophytes,
Candida
, or scabies.

objective.__html: Diagnose erythrasma.

references: Forouzan P, Cohen PR. Erythrasma revisited: diagnosis, differential diagnoses, and comprehensive review of treatment. Cureus. 2020;12:e10733.

title: Question 104

children: A 68-year-old man undergoes a preoperative medical evaluation before total knee arthroplasty. Medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, degenerative joint disease, and psoriasis. Medications are amlodipine, metoprolol, methotrexate, folic acid, and atorvastatin.

On physical examination, vital signs are normal. Small, scattered psoriatic plaques are noted on the elbows, knees, and sacrum. Examination of the left knee shows limited range of motion. The remainder of the physical examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate perioperative medication management?

text.__html: Withhold metoprolol and atorvastatin on day of surgery
Withhold metoprolol and methotrexate on day of surgery

children: Nonbiologic disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) can be continued throughout the perioperative period; biologic DMARDs should be discontinued and restarted after evidence of wound healing.
Patients on β-blocker and statin medications should continue therapy in the perioperative period.
The most appropriate perioperative medication management is to continue all medications (
Option D

). High-quality evidence to guide perioperative medication management is lacking. Recommendations are largely derived from theoretical drug interactions and expert consensus. Although most medications are tolerated throughout the perioperative period, there are some important exceptions. For example, the American College of Rheumatology recommends that biologic medications should be withheld as close to one dosing cycle as scheduling permits before elective hip and knee arthroplasty and restarted after evidence of wound healing, typically 14 days. Nonbiologic disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) (methotrexate, sulfasalazine, hydroxychloroquine, leflunomide) may be continued throughout the perioperative period. Methotrexate is administered once weekly, most commonly by oral or subcutaneous routes. Studies in patients with rheumatoid arthritis have demonstrated that continuing DMARDs, including methotrexate, through the perioperative period is safe without an increase in infection rate (
Option A
), even with prosthetic implantation, and reduces the risk for disease flares.

According to the 2014 American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association perioperative cardiovascular guideline, patients on β-blocker therapy, such as metoprolol, should continue therapy in the perioperative period (
Options B, C

). Cessation of these agents may cause rebound tachycardia and promote dysrhythmias in the perioperative period because of the elevated adrenergic tone from pain, stress, and volume shifts. Preoperative initiation of β-blockers is generally reserved for patients with a Revised Cardiac Risk Index score of 3 or more without contraindications (such as resting bradycardia or hypotension) and who have enough time before surgery to trial medications (>1 week) to ensure safety and tolerability.

Sufficient evidence has demonstrated benefits of statin agents, such as atorvastatin, during the perioperative period. Pleiotropic effects of these agents are believed to be responsible for numerous benefits in major surgeries, presumably due to anti-inflammatory properties. Statins have been consistently associated with lower risk for cardiovascular complications in both cardiac and noncardiac surgery. In surgeries with highest cardiovascular risk (major vascular, cardiothoracic), it is reasonable to start a statin preoperatively if the patient is not already taking one. This recommendation does not apply for patients undergoing noncardiac surgery, as is this case for this patient; if a patient has been on long-term statin therapy, it should be continued.

objective.__html: Manage perioperative medications.

references: Goodman SM, Springer B, Guyatt G, et al. 2017 American College of Rheumatology/American Association of Hip and Knee Surgeons guideline for the perioperative management of antirheumatic medication in patients with rheumatic diseases undergoing elective total hip or total knee arthroplasty. Arthritis Care Res (Hoboken). 2017;69:1111-24.

title: Question 105

children: A 28-year-old man is evaluated during a follow-up visit for hypertension and diabetes mellitus. He works two jobs and eats fast food for most meals. He reports that he does not have time to exercise. He states that he is unhappy with his lifestyle. Medications are amlodipine and hydrochlorothiazide.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

text.__html: Review benefits of a healthy diet

children: The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends behavioral counseling to promote a healthy diet and physical activity for adults aged 18 years or older who are at increased risk for cardiovascular disease.
The most appropriate management is counseling for behavioral change (
Option A

). Behavioral counseling is an integral part of helping patients attain a healthy lifestyle. The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends behavioral counseling to promote a healthy diet and physical activity for adults aged 18 years or older who are at increased risk for cardiovascular disease (CVD). Patients at increased risk for CVD are identified by the USPSTF as patients with hypertension or elevated blood pressure; dyslipidemia; or mixed or multiple risk factors, such as the metabolic syndrome or an estimated 10-year atherosclerotic CVD risk of 7.5% or higher.
