The USPSTF provides suggestions for behavioral change implementation, including a median of 12 contacts, with an estimated 6 hours of contact over 12 months; some one-on-one time with an interventionist; and use of motivational interviewing and behavioral change techniques, such as goal setting, active use of self-monitoring, and addressing barriers related to diet, physical activity, or weight change. The USPSTF suggests that counseling for behavioral change can be done in person or referred to outside counseling services, or patients can be informed about media-based interventions.
Reviewing the benefits of a healthy diet and exercise (
Options B, C

) is necessary but not sufficient to help this patient achieve healthy lifestyle goals. Behavioral change counseling that includes motivational interviewing and introduction to behavioral change techniques as well as goal setting is more likely to achieve the desired end than solely providing information about the benefits of diet and exercise. The USPSTF notes that there is adequate evidence that counseling interventions reduce overall CVD events (myocardial infarction and stroke); improve blood pressure, lipid and fasting blood glucose levels, and body weight/adiposity; and improve healthy eating habits.
Although it is important that patients understand the long-term complications of their diseases (
Option D
), providing a stronger means of supporting behavioral change, such as a behavioral counseling program, is more likely to make a significant impact.

objective.__html: Provide counseling for behavioral change.

references: Krist AH, Davidson KW, Mangione CM, et al; US Preventive Services Task Force. Behavioral counseling interventions to promote a healthy diet and physical activity for cardiovascular disease prevention in adults with cardiovascular risk factors: US Preventive Services Task Force recommendation statement. JAMA. 2020;324:2069-75.

title: Question 106

children: A 50-year-old man is evaluated during a routine wellness visit. He has no medical problems and takes no medications. The patient is engaged in a discussion about the benefits and harms of prostate cancer screening, after which he expresses no preference for or against prostate cancer screening.
According to the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force, which of the following is the most appropriate prostate screening strategy for this patient?

text.__html: Digital rectal examination and prostate-specific antigen (PSA) testing

children: For men aged 55 to 69 years, the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends that clinicians engage in a discussion of the potential benefits versus harms of screening for prostate cancer before ordering testing.
The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends that clinicians should not screen men for prostate cancer unless they express a preference for screening.
The most appropriate prostate cancer screening strategy for this patient is no screening (
Option D

). Screening for prostate cancer in asymptomatic, average-risk men has been controversial, and recommendations among professional organizations continue to evolve. The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends that for men aged 55 to 69 years, the decision to undergo periodic prostate-specific antigen (PSA)–based screening for prostate cancer should be an individual decision. Before deciding whether to be screened, men should have an opportunity to discuss the potential benefits and harms of screening with their clinician and to incorporate their values and preferences in the decision. Screening offers a small potential benefit of reducing the chance of death from prostate cancer in some men that is estimated to be a reduction in one prostate cancer–related death for every 1000 men screened for 10 years. However, many men will experience potential harms of screening, including false-positive results that require additional testing and possible prostate biopsy; overdiagnosis and overtreatment; and treatment complications, such as incontinence and erectile dysfunction. In determining whether this service is appropriate in individual cases, patients and clinicians should consider the balance of benefits and harms on the basis of family history, comorbid medical conditions, patient values about the benefits and harms of screening and treatment-specific outcomes, and other health needs. Clinicians should not screen men who do not express a preference for screening.
Conducting a digital rectal examination (
Options A, B
) as part of prostate cancer screening is not recommended by the USPSTF because there is no evidence that it adds benefit to the PSA assay.
Because the patient has not expressed a preference for screening, obtaining a PSA measurement (
Option C

) is not indicated. If the decision is made to proceed with screening, the American Urological Association (AUA) recommends choosing less frequent screening intervals (≥2 years), which may reduce overdiagnosis and the number of false-positive results while preserving most of the screening benefit. The AUA also recommends that the interval for rescreening may be based on the baseline PSA level. Screening is not recommended for men with less than a 10- to 15-year life expectancy.

objective.__html: Avoid prostate cancer screening in a patient who does not express a preference for screening.

references: Grossman DC, Curry SJ, Owens DK, et al; US Preventive Services Task Force. Screening for prostate cancer: US Preventive Services Task Force recommendation statement. JAMA. 2018;319:1901-13.

title: Question 107

children: A 37-year-old woman is evaluated for a 2-month history of a persistent facial skin rash that becomes more prominent and stings, burns, and itches within a few minutes of sunlight exposure, exercise, drinking alcohol, or eating spicy foods.
Skin findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
Topical metronidazole cream is a reasonable first-line option for patients with predominant papulopustular variant of rosacea.
Most patients with rosacea will benefit from avoidance of identified triggers, proper use of sun protection, and use of gentle skin cleansers.
The most appropriate treatment is topical metronidazole cream (
Option C

). This patient's rash consists of red macules with pustules and telangiectasias within the rash, which after exposure to certain triggers becomes more prominent with stinging, burning, and itching. These findings are most consistent with rosacea. This condition is defined by chronic inflammation of the pilosebaceous units with increased vascular reactivity; it is most common among patients of Irish and English descent with light complexions, usually in the third to sixth decades of life. There are a variety of clinical presentations of rosacea, including erythrotelangiectatic (as
shown
, papulopustular, phymatous, and ocular rosacea.

The papulopustular variant of rosacea can be confused with acne, but rosacea does not present with comedonal lesions. Telangiectasias are seen in the erythrotelangiectatic subtype. Most patients also have frequent flushing in response to triggers, such as stress, alcohol consumption, heat, and excessive sunlight. The erythema of the cheeks can mimic the malar rash of systemic lupus erythematosus. Unlike lupus, however, the erythema of rosacea includes the nasolabial folds. Ocular rosacea may present in isolation or with associated skin findings. In ocular rosacea, the conjunctiva appears injected, and patients often describe a “gritty sensation.” In phymatous rosacea, severe sebaceous hyperplasia and chronic inflammation lead to fibrous overgrowth of the skin, creating a nodular, tumor-like deformation of the facial structures. Rhinophyma is the form most frequently encountered, and it is almost exclusively found in men. Treatment for rosacea is targeted toward the most prominent signs and symptoms in each patient. Topical metronidazole is a reasonable first-line option for patients with predominant papulopustular variant of rosacea as seen in this patient. Other effective topical agents include sodium sulfacetamide/sulfur, azelaic acid, topical calcineurin inhibitors (pimecrolimus, tacrolimus), and ivermectin. Oral antibiotics, such as low-dose doxycycline, have been shown to help control inflammation in ocular and papulopustular rosacea. Most patients will also benefit from avoidance of identified triggers, proper use of sun protection, and use of gentle skin cleansers.
Chloroquine (
Option A
) can be very helpful in the treatment of cutaneous and systemic lupus erythematosus. However, this patient has rosacea and chloroquine is not indicated.
Topical clobetasol cream (
Option B
) is a glucocorticoid and may exacerbate existing rosacea or cause rosacea de novo on the face. It is not a treatment for rosacea.
Although topical tacrolimus cream (
Option D
) can treat inflammatory variants of rosacea, such as periorificial dermatitis, topical metronidazole cream is a first-line agent for rosacea.

objective.__html: Treat rosacea.

references: Marson JW, Baldwin HE. Rosacea: a wholistic review and update from pathogenesis to diagnosis and therapy. Int J Dermatol. 2020;59:e175-82.

title: Question 108

children: A 52-year-old woman is evaluated during a follow-up visit for type 2 diabetes mellitus. She reports that she is unable to lose weight. She has implemented a healthier diet and exercise. Medical history is also significant for depression and epilepsy, both well controlled. Medications are metformin, glimepiride, bupropion, and topiramate.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. BMI is 36.
Which of the following medication changes is most likely to promote weight loss in this patient?
Insulin, sulfonylureas, thiazolidinediones, and meglitinides are associated with weight gain.
Glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonists, sodium-glucose transporter-2 inhibitors, and amylin mimetics are associated with weight loss.
The medication change most likely to promote weight loss in this patient is to switch glimepiride to liraglutide (
Option C

). For this patient with an inability to lose weight despite pursuing healthy lifestyle choices, a thorough medication review is necessary to identify medications that may contribute to weight gain. Many medications are associated with weight gain, including some antidepressants, anticonvulsants, lithium, clozapine, olanzapine, depot progesterone, depot leuprolide acetate, glucocorticoids, and antiretroviral therapies. Medications used to treat diabetes mellitus have differing effects on weight. Sulfonylureas, insulin, thiazolidinediones (rosiglitazone, pioglitazone), and meglitinides (repaglinide, nateglinide) typically cause weight gain, whereas glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonists (liraglutide, exenatide, albiglutide, lixisenatide, dulaglutide, semaglutide), sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 (SGLT-2) inhibitors (canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, empagliflozin, ertugliflozin), and amylin mimetics (pramlintide) have been associated with weight loss. These agents produce weight loss by various mechanisms. GLP-1 receptor agonists and amylin mimetics slow gastric emptying and increase satiety. SGLT-2 inhibitors increase kidney excretion of glucose. In this patient's case, replacing glimepiride, a sulfonylurea, with liraglutide will result in weight loss.
Switching bupropion to either paroxetine or venlafaxine (
Options A, B

) will not result in weight loss. Bupropion is the antidepressant medication most associated with weight loss and should be continued, especially because the patient's depression is currently well controlled. Among other antidepressants, venlafaxine, nefazodone, and fluoxetine are weight neutral. Paroxetine, however, has been associated with weight gain, as have citalopram, escitalopram, sertraline, duloxetine, mirtazapine, and amitriptyline.
Switching glimepiride to sitagliptin (
Option D

) will not be as effective in reducing weight as switching to liraglutide. Sitagliptin, a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 inhibitor, is weight neutral and unlikely to result in significant weight loss. Saxagliptin, linagliptin, and alogliptin are other drugs within this class. Other pharmacologic agents for diabetes that are weight neutral include metformin and the α-glucosidases (acarbose, miglitol).
This patient's seizures are well controlled on topiramate (
Option E

), a medication that does not promote weight gain, and thus her antiseizure regimen should not be changed. Many other anticonvulsant medications, including carbamazepine, valproate, and gabapentin, are associated with weight gain, whereas topiramate and zonisamide typically cause weight loss. Phenytoin is weight neutral.

objective.__html: Manage medications that promote weight loss and weight gain.

references: Tsai AG, Bessesen DH. Obesity.

children: Ann Intern Med

title: Question 109

children: A 26-year-old woman is evaluated during a routine examination. She had gestational diabetes during a pregnancy 4 years ago, but her 12-week postpartum oral glucose tolerance test was normal. A copper intrauterine device (IUD) for contraception was placed at that time. A Pap smear obtained 1 year ago was normal. She received the human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine as a child. She is sexually active with her husband and has no sexual or vaginal concerns. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and she takes no medications.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. BMI is 20. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

text.__html: Nucleic acid amplification test for chlamydia

children: Women with a history of gestational diabetes are at high risk for developing diabetes in the future.

Women with a history of gestational diabetes require screening with either a fasting blood glucose level or 2-hour, 75-g oral glucose tolerance test between 6 to 12 weeks postpartum, followed by screening every 1 to 3 years with hemoglobin A1
c
measurement.
The most appropriate management is a hemoglobin A
1c
test (
Option B

). Women with a history of gestational diabetes, such as this patient, are at high risk for developing diabetes in the future. These patients should be screened with either a fasting blood glucose level or 2-hour, 75-g oral glucose tolerance test between 6 and 12 weeks postpartum and then screened every 1 to 3 years with a hemoglobin A
1c
measurement. These patients should also be counseled on the importance of achieving a healthy weight and dietary and exercise interventions to prevent diabetes.
Cervical cytology and human papillomavirus (HPV) testing (
Option A

) are not indicated. This patient had a normal Pap smear 1 year ago; she does not need additional screening at this time. According to the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force, women younger than 30 years require a Pap smear every 3 years but do not require co-testing for HPV. Women aged 30 years or older should be screened every 5 years with a Pap smear and HPV co-testing. If HPV co-testing is unavailable, patients can be screened every 3 years with Pap testing only. The American Cancer Society recommends that individuals with a cervix initiate cervical cancer screening at age 25 years and undergo HPV testing every 5 years through age 65 years; if primary HPV testing is not available, then individuals aged 25 to 65 years should be screened with co-testing (HPV testing in combination with cytology) every 5 years or cytology alone every 3 years.
Because this patient has no vaginal concerns, a nucleic acid amplification test for chlamydia (
Option C

) is not indicated. The CDC recommends annual screening for chlamydia in women aged 25 years or younger or those with risk factors, such as having multiple sexual partners. Any woman reporting symptoms or requesting screening for sexually transmitted infections should be offered testing.
The copper intrauterine device (IUD) (
Option D
) is approved for 10 years of use, and thus the patient does not need her IUD replaced at this time. Levonorgestrel-releasing IUDs are FDA approved for 3 to 5 years of use, depending on the brand.

objective.__html: Screen for diabetes in women with a history of gestational diabetes.

references: ACOG committee opinion no. 736: optimizing postpartum care. Obstet Gynecol. 2018;131:e140-e150.

title: Question 110

children: A 55-year-old man is evaluated for a painless spot on his back that his wife noticed. He is unaware how long the spot has been there. Medical history is unremarkable, and he takes no medications.
Skin findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Dysplastic nevi are melanocytic nevi that are often asymmetric, irregularly bordered, and multicolored, and may be large in diameter (>6 mm); biopsy is used to differentiate between a dysplastic nevus and a melanoma.
Patients with multiple dysplastic nevi are at risk for developing melanoma and should be monitored closely.
The most likely diagnosis is a dysplastic nevus (
Option A

). Dysplastic nevi are melanocytic nevi that are often asymmetric, irregularly bordered, have more than one shade of brown, and may be quite large in diameter. Many have a “fried egg” appearance, with an eccentric dark brown papular center and surrounding light brown ring. Dysplastic nevi can display one or more of the identifying characteristics of melanoma (asymmetry, irregular border, multiple colors, diameter >6 mm, evolution over time), making an accurate clinical diagnosis impossible; excisional skin biopsy to remove the entire lesion should be performed for diagnosis. The lesion seen on this patient shows minimal color variability, so the most likely diagnosis is a dysplastic nevus. Although the potential for an individual dysplastic nevus to develop into melanoma is low, patients with dysplastic nevi are at increased risk for developing a melanoma. Patients with multiple dysplastic nevi are also at risk for developing melanoma and should be monitored closely. Some of these patients have dysplastic nevus syndrome. Criteria for this syndrome include a history of melanoma in one or more first- or second-degree relatives; the presence of a large number of nevi (>50), as
shown

; multiple nevi having atypical clinical features; and multiple nevi that have atypical histologic features. These patients are at increased risk for melanoma and should have yearly full-skin examinations.
Pigmented actinic keratoses (
Option B

) are a rare skin condition that can have a similar presentation as dysplastic nevi, but they may have erythema and scale and occur more commonly in patients with darker skin. There is no scale or erythema in this patient's lesion.
Pigmented basal cell carcinoma (BCC) (
Option C

) is a subtype of BCC that typically presents with features of a nodular BCC, including a translucent, rolled border with overlying telangiectasias. Pigmented BCC also has pigment deposition, ranging from dark brown to black. This patient's lesion is pigmented, but it is a macular lesion with irregular borders, making it distinctly different than a pigmented BCC.
Seborrheic keratosis (
Option D
) is a benign skin growth, often occurring on the trunk in older adults. Unlike this patient's lesion, seborrheic keratosis presents as a well-circumscribed, keratotic, “stuck-on” papule.

objective.__html: Diagnose a dysplastic nevus.

references: Farber MJ, Heilman ER, Friedman RJ. Dysplastic nevi. Dermatol Clin. 2012;30:389-404.

title: Question 111

children: A 64-year-old man is seen for a preoperative evaluation before a complex open ventral hernia repair. Medical history is significant for COPD. He stopped smoking 9 months ago. He has dyspnea when walking rapidly on a flat surface. His symptoms are currently stable, with minimal cough and sputum production. Medications include inhaled tiotropium and as-needed albuterol. Spirometry results from 4 months ago show an
FVC
FEV
ratio of 0.5 and an
FEV
of 60% of predicted. Screening for obstructive sleep apnea is negative.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal.

children.referenceRange: Blood gases, Oxygen saturation, arterial (ambient air)
children: Oxygen saturation
is 94% breathing ambient air. Chest shows diminished breath sounds without wheezes. Other than a large ventral hernia, the remainder of the physical examination is normal.
Which of the following is mostly likely to reduce postoperative pulmonary complications in this patient?

Perioperative prophylactic respiratory physiotherapy that includes increased mobility, sputum clearance, deep breathing exercise, and inspiratory muscle training reduces the incidence of postoperative pulmonary complications.
There is no benefit of incentive spirometry, with or without deep breathing exercises, in preventing postoperative pulmonary complications.
Perioperative prophylactic respiratory physiotherapy (
Option A

) that includes increased mobility, sputum clearance, deep breathing exercise, and inspiratory muscle training is consistently shown to reduce pulmonary complications after surgery. A 2020 systematic review and meta-analysis evaluated interventions to reduce the incidence of postoperative pulmonary complications in patients undergoing noncardiac surgery. Postoperative pulmonary complications were defined as a composite of respiratory infection, respiratory failure, pleural effusion, atelectasis, or pneumothorax. Perioperative (either before or after surgery, or both) prophylactic respiratory physiotherapy showed an overall benefit (risk ratio, 0.55; 95% CI, 0.32-0.93) in reducing the development of postoperative pulmonary complications. Other interventions associated with a reduced risk for postoperative pulmonary complications included lung-protective intraoperative ventilation, goal-directed hemodynamic therapies, epidural analgesia (replacing opioid analgesia), prophylactic mucolytics, and postoperative continuous positive pressure ventilation. All interventions showing benefit were associated with low-quality evidence.
Although incentive spirometry (
Option B

) is often included in postoperative management, moderate-quality evidence shows no benefit in preventing postoperative pulmonary complications (risk ratio, 1.06; 95% CI, 0.85-1.34). Other recent systematic reviews concur with this finding.
Routine use of nasogastric tubes (
Option C

) is not recommended for the prevention of postoperative pulmonary complications. Systematic reviews and meta-analysis have concluded that the routine use of a nasogastric tube to decompress the stomach following abdominal surgery is associated with an increased risk for pulmonary complications, including pneumonia and atelectasis. Nasogastric tubes do have a role in patients with postoperative gastric distention or in the treatment of nausea and vomiting, but routine use following abdominal surgery is not recommended.
Maximizing oral hygiene with preoperative use of chlorhexidine mouthwash (
Option D
) reduces the risk for postoperative pneumonia in patients undergoing cardiac surgery; the efficacy in patients undergoing noncardiac thoracic surgery or abdominal surgery is less clear.

objective.__html: Prevent postoperative pulmonary complications.

references: Odor PM, Bampoe S, Gilhooly D, et al. Perioperative interventions for prevention of postoperative pulmonary complications: systematic review and meta-analysis. BMJ. 2020;368:m540.

title: Question 112

children: A 23-year-old man is evaluated at an urgent care center for a 5-day history of right ear pain associated with otorrhea, pruritus, and diminished hearing. He reports no rash or other symptoms. He has no other medical problems and takes no medications.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. There is discomfort when pulling on the right ear pinna. Findings on otoscopy are
shown
Using an otoscope and a wire ear loop, debris is removed from the canal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate additional treatment?
The classic sign of acute otitis externa is tenderness with pushing on the tragus or pulling on the pinna.
First-line treatment of acute otitis externa includes topical antibiotics, glucocorticoids, antiseptics (acetic acid), and combination therapies.
The most appropriate additional treatment for this patient with moderate-severity acute otitis externa (AOE) (swimmer's ear) is ciprofloxacin-dexamethasone otic drops (
Option A
). AOE is diffuse inflammation of the external ear canal and may involve the pinna and tragus. In 98% of cases of AOE, the cause is bacterial infection, most commonly with
Pseudomonas
or
Staphylococcus aureus

. Symptoms include otalgia, pruritus, and ear fullness. The history should include assessment for risk factors, including swimming/water activities, trauma/injury, associated skin conditions (including contact dermatitis, eczema, and psoriasis), immunocompromising conditions (such as diabetes mellitus, HIV infection, or cancer chemotherapy), history of radiation, and tympanostomy tubes or perforation of the tympanic membrane, which may alter choice of treatment. On physical examination, the classic sign of AOE is tenderness with pushing on the tragus or pulling on the pinna. Topical treatments, including antibiotics, glucocorticoids, antiseptics (acetic acid), and combination therapies, are first-line management for uncomplicated AOE. In this patient with moderate-severity disease characterized by pain and occlusion of the ear canal with debris (cerumen, desquamated cells, purulent material), a topical antibiotic/glucocorticoid combination is reasonable after cleaning out the debris from the ear canal. Patients should be instructed on proper technique for instillation of ear drops, including cleaning excess debris before instilling the drops and then lying down with the affected ear facing upward, remaining in this position for 3 to 5 minutes.
In most patients with AOE, systemic antibiotics, such as intravenous ceftriaxone (
Option B

), are ineffective and should be avoided. However, immunocompromised patients require topical and systemic therapy and are at increased risk for deeper infections, including bone involvement (malignant otitis externa), which if present requires urgent referral to an otolaryngologist and intravenous antibiotics.

Fungal infection of the external ear canal is uncommon and is usually suspected when appropriate treatment for AOE fails. The use of topical antibiotics can be a predisposing factor for fungal external otitis. Treatment includes meticulous cleaning of the external ear canal and application of a topical antifungal agent, such as clotrimazole (
Option C

Herpes zoster infection involving the ear may present with vesicles around the external ear canal and may be complicated by peripheral facial nerve paralysis and auditory/vestibular symptoms (Ramsay Hunt syndrome). These patients require antiviral therapy, such as valacyclovir (
Option D
), and referral to an otolaryngologist. Inspection of this patient's ear and ear canal does not suggest the presence of vesicles, and treatment for herpes zoster with valacyclovir is not indicated.

objective.__html: Treat acute otitis externa.

references: Hajioff D, MacKeith S. Otitis externa. BMJ Clin Evid. 2015;2015.

title: Question 113

children: A 58-year-old man is evaluated for decreased libido and erectile dysfunction that began insidiously over the past 6 months. He is not having nocturnal or early morning erections. His medical history is otherwise unremarkable.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. BMI is 24. There is no gynecomastia. Distribution of pubic hair is normal. Testes are normal sized.
Laboratory studies show an 8:00
AM
serum
total testosterone
level of 200 ng/dL (6.94 nmol/L) and a
thyroid-stimulating hormone
level of 3.6 µU/mL (3.6 mU/L).
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
The diagnosis of androgen deficiency should be made only when a patient has two separate early morning (8:00
AM
) serum total testosterone levels less than 300 ng/dL (10.41 nmol/dL) combined with suggestive symptoms and/or signs.

Free and bioavailable testosterone measurements should be reserved for patients with total testosterone levels in the low-normal range and for patients suspected of having alterations in sex hormone–binding globulin levels.
The most appropriate management is repeat measurement of the 8:00
AM
serum total testosterone level (
Option C
). The diagnosis of androgen deficiency should be made only when a patient has two separate early morning (8:00
AM
) serum total testosterone levels less than 300 ng/dL (10.41 nmol/dL) combined with suggestive symptoms and/or signs. This patient has an 8:00
AM

serum total testosterone level of 200 ng/dL (6.94 nmol/L) and symptoms of sexual dysfunction (decreased libido and erectile dysfunction), suggesting androgen deficiency. The most appropriate management at this time is to repeat the 8:00
AM
serum total testosterone measurement to confirm this diagnosis.
Obtaining a serum free testosterone level (
Option A

) can be helpful when alterations in sex hormone–binding globulin (SHBG) levels may be causing serum total testosterone levels to be unreliable. Alterations in SHBG levels occur in older men with obesity; men with advanced liver disease, diabetes, or insulin resistance; and men who use glucocorticoids. There is no concern that this patient has an alteration in his SHBG level, and obtaining a serum free testosterone level is not indicated.
An elevated luteinizing hormone (LH) level (
Option B

) with simultaneous low testosterone indicates primary (testicular) hypogonadism. A low or normal LH level with simultaneous low testosterone indicates secondary hypogonadism. Confirming the presence of hypogonadism is necessary before assessment with LH measurement.
Starting intramuscular testosterone therapy (
Option D
) before obtaining a second, confirmatory 8:00
AM

serum total testosterone level is not recommended. If the second serum total testosterone level is low, intramuscular testosterone therapy can be considered. Intramuscular testosterone is less costly than transdermal formulations and has similar efficacy and safety.
Oral phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5) inhibitors, such as sildenafil (
Option E

), are first-line medical therapy for erectile dysfunction and are safe and effective in most patients. Testosterone therapy may also be indicated in cases of confirmed androgen deficiency. When prescribed for hypogonadal men with erectile dysfunction, testosterone therapy will enhance the efficacy of PDE-5 inhibitors. However, neither PDE-5 inhibitors nor testosterone therapy is indicated until the patient is fully evaluated for hypogonadism.

objective.__html: Diagnose androgen deficiency.

references: Al-Sharefi A, Quinton R. Current national and international guidelines for the management of male hypogonadism: helping clinicians to navigate variation in diagnostic criteria and treatment recommendations. Endocrinol Metab (Seoul). 2020;35:526-40.

title: Question 114

children: A 58-year-old woman comes to the office for a routine follow-up visit. Medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes mellitus. She remains asymptomatic and active. Medications are metformin, empagliflozin, chlorthalidone, and atorvastatin. She consumes a heart-healthy diet, exercises 150 minutes weekly, and does not smoke. She drinks one glass of red wine nightly. She recently began taking vitamins A, C, E, and D with calcium for primary prevention of cardiovascular disease.
Physical examination findings, including vital signs, are normal.
Which of the following supplements can be recommended as most likely to help the patient meet her therapeutic goal?
No vitamin or supplement can be recommended to prevent cardiovascular disease due to lack of evidence for efficacy.

The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends against the use of β-carotene or vitamin E supplements for the prevention of cardiovascular disease because of evidence demonstrating lack of efficacy.
No vitamin or supplement (
Option E

) can be recommended to prevent cardiovascular disease. Overall, the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) found inadequate evidence on the benefits of supplementation with multivitamins to reduce the risk for cardiovascular disease. In addition, the USPSTF found inadequate evidence on the benefits of supplementation with individual vitamins or minerals or functional pairs in healthy populations without known nutritional deficiencies to reduce the risk for cardiovascular disease. Although these interventions lack proof of efficacy in the prevention of cardiovascular disease, they appear to be without harm if taken in recommended doses.
The USPSTF reviewed five studies of vitamin A (
Option A

) supplementation in healthy patients without deficiencies. None of the studies reported cardiovascular disease incidence. Two trials reported all-cause mortality, but no significant difference was observed between the intervention and control groups.
The USPSTF cited two studies that reported the effects of vitamin C (
Option B
), either alone or in combination with other supplements, and found no statistically significant effect on cardiovascular disease or all-cause mortality.

The USPSTF reported on two trials that studied the effects of vitamin D on cardiovascular disease and found no effect on disease incidence or mortality. The USPSTF found only one trial that reported cardiovascular disease incidence and mortality and all-cause mortality with combined use of vitamin D and calcium (
Option C
), and it found no effect after 7 years of follow-up.
The USPSTF found adequate evidence that supplementation with β-carotene or vitamin E (
Option D

) in healthy populations without known nutritional deficiencies does not reduce the risk for cardiovascular disease. The USPSTF recommends against the use of β-carotene or vitamin E supplements for the prevention of cardiovascular disease.

objective.__html: Avoid recommending vitamins for the prevention of cardiovascular disease.

references: Moyer VA; U.S. Preventive Services Task Force. Vitamin, mineral, and multivitamin supplements for the primary prevention of cardiovascular disease and cancer: U.S. Preventive services Task Force recommendation statement.

title: Question 115

children: A 24-year-old woman is evaluated for a 5-year history of atopic dermatitis. She continues to have mild flares every few weeks on her arms. Her only medication is topical clobetasol cream.
Skin findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

text.__html: Replace clobetasol cream with ketoconazole cream
Replace clobetasol cream with tacrolimus ointment
Replace clobetasol cream with triamcinolone cream

children: Topical tacrolimus and pimecrolimus are immunomodulators (calcineurin inhibitors) that can be effective in treating atopic dermatitis without the risk for skin atrophy, striae, and telangiectasias that can occur with topical glucocorticoid use.
The most appropriate treatment is to replace clobetasol cream with tacrolimus ointment (
Option C

). This patient has signs of skin atrophy, telangiectasias, and striae caused by overuse of clobetasol cream, a high-potency topical glucocorticoid. Side effects are most frequently seen when higher potencies are used for longer periods or when used under occlusion, and they can appear as soon as 2 weeks after initiation of therapy. Use of glucocorticoids around the eyes can exacerbate glaucoma and cause cataracts. Skin atrophy is more likely to occur in intertriginous areas, the face, and often in the popliteal or antecubital fossa. Topical glucocorticoids may also cause easy bruising. Although this patient has signs of skin atrophy, she continues to have flares of her atopic dermatitis requiring treatment. Topical tacrolimus and pimecrolimus are immunomodulators (calcineurin inhibitors) that can be effective in treating atopic dermatitis, having similar efficacy to low- to medium-potency glucocorticoids. Topical calcineurin inhibitors can be used on the face and intertriginous areas without the risk for skin atrophy, telangiectasias, and striae that can occur with topical glucocorticoid use. The most common side effect of topical calcineurin inhibitors is stinging or burning after application. Both drugs have been associated with an increased risk for viral skin infections, such as herpes simplex and varicella zoster. These medications have a black box warning for the rare development of skin cancer and cutaneous lymphoma. Replacing clobetasol cream with tacrolimus ointment is the most appropriate choice to continue to treat this patient's atopic dermatitis in the setting of glucocorticoid atrophy.
Calcipotriene cream (
Option A

) is a vitamin D analogue used for the treatment of psoriasis. Although adding calcipotriene cream would not worsen this patient's skin atrophy, it is not effective for treating atopic dermatitis. Regardless, this patient should discontinue clobetasol cream, which is the cause of her skin atrophy.
Ketoconazole cream (
Option B

) is effective for treating superficial fungal infections. However, the annular plaques and scale of tinea are not seen in this patient, and ketoconazole would not be effective in treating this patient's skin atrophy, striae, and telangiectasias.
Triamcinolone cream (
Option D

) is a mid-potency topical glucocorticoid. Although it is effective in treating atopic dermatitis and is less potent than clobetasol cream, it can potentially exacerbate the current atrophy, striae, and telangiectasias seen in this patient's skin. Topical glucocorticoids are frequently commercially combined with topical antifungal agents (clotrimazole-betamethasone). These combinations should also be avoided. The use of a combination drug can worsen some tinea infections and when used in the groin area has a high risk for causing striae.

objective.__html: Treat inflammatory skin disorders with topical immunomodulators.

references: Drugs for atopic dermatitis. Med Lett Drugs Ther. 2020;62:89-96.

title: Question 116

children: A 72-year-old man is admitted to the hospital with cellulitis of the right lower extremity. He has no other medical problems and takes no medications.

On physical examination, temperature is 38.7 °C (101.8 °F), blood pressure is 150/80 mm Hg, pulse rate is 111/min, and respiration rate is 22/min. There is extensive erythema, warmth, swelling and tenderness extending from the midcalf to the left medial malleolus and dorsomedial aspect of the right foot. There is no fluctuance or drainage.
Doppler ultrasound of the right lower extremity shows no evidence of deep venous thrombosis or fluid collection. Intravenous cefazolin is initiated.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management for preventing venous thromboembolism?
In acutely ill medical patients, parenteral anticoagulation using low-molecular-weight heparin, unfractionated heparin, or fondaparinux is suggested to prevent venous thromboembolism.
In acutely ill medical patients, parenteral anticoagulation to prevent venous thromboembolism is suggested over oral anticoagulants and over mechanical prophylaxis.
The most appropriate management for preventing venous thromboembolism (VTE) in this hospitalized patient is low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) (
Option E

). Rates of VTE (both pulmonary embolism and deep venous thrombosis) are elevated in acutely ill medical patients. Acutely ill medical patients are patients hospitalized for a medical illness. In acutely ill medical patients, the 2018 American Society of Hematology (ASH) guideline suggests parenteral anticoagulation using LMWH, unfractionated heparin (UFH), or fondaparinux to prevent VTE. In critically ill patients, the ASH guideline prefers LMWH to UFH.
In acutely ill medical patients requiring VTE chemoprophylaxis, the ASH and other guidelines recommend use of parenteral anticoagulants over oral anticoagulants. Direct oral anticoagulants (
Option A

) are increasingly used as the agent of choice for postsurgical VTE prophylaxis, and in the 2019 ASH VTE guideline, direct oral anticoagulants are preferred over LMWH for postoperative VTE prophylaxis in total knee and hip arthroplasty.
In acutely or critically ill medical patients, the ASH guideline suggests using pharmacologic VTE prophylaxis over mechanical VTE prophylaxis, such as intermittent pneumatic compression (IPC) (
Option B

) or gradient stockings. IPC is indicated for a patient at increased risk for VTE and at high risk for major bleeding or experiencing bleeding on prophylactic-dose anticoagulants. It is also very unlikely that this patient with extensive cellulitis would tolerate the discomfort of IPC or gradient stockings.
In acutely ill medical patients, the ASH guideline panel does not suggest combined use of IPC devices and parenteral anticoagulation prophylaxis over parenteral anticoagulation alone (
Options C, D

). This recommendation is based on low-quality evidence because there are no trials comparing both strategies in this population. The ASH guideline recommends combined mechanical and pharmacologic prophylaxis over pharmacologic prophylaxis alone in the hospitalized surgical patient.

objective.__html: Prevent venous thromboembolism in a hospitalized patient.

references: Schünemann HJ, Cushman M, Burnett AE, et al. American Society of Hematology 2018 guidelines for management of venous thromboembolism: prophylaxis for hospitalized and nonhospitalized medical patients. Blood Adv. 2018;2:3198-225.
doi:10.1182/bloodadvances.2018022954

title: Question 117

children: This question has been updated as a result of postpublication analysis and/or new data that are relevant to the question.

A 30-year-old man is evaluated during a routine wellness visit. He is asymptomatic, has no ongoing medical problems, and does not use tobacco products. Previous screening for hepatitis C virus and HIV infections were negative. His immunizations are up to date.
On physical examination, blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg. BMI is 22 kg/m
. The remainder of the examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate screening for this patient?

The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening for unhealthy alcohol use in primary care settings in adults aged 18 years or older, including pregnant women, and providing persons engaged in risky or hazardous drinking with brief behavioral counseling interventions to reduce unhealthy alcohol use.
Screening instruments to identify unhealthy alcohol use include the Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test (AUDIT), AUDIT-Consumption (AUDIT-C), and Single Alcohol Screening Question (SASQ).
The most appropriate screening is for hazardous alcohol drinking (
Option B

). The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends screening for unhealthy alcohol use in primary care settings in adults aged 18 years or older, including pregnant women, and providing persons engaged in risky or hazardous drinking with brief behavioral counseling interventions to reduce unhealthy alcohol use. Unhealthy alcohol use is the third leading cause of preventable death in the United States. Individuals with unhealthy alcohol use often interact with the health care system but rarely receive appropriate treatment. Screening instruments to identify harmful drinking include the Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test (AUDIT), AUDIT-Consumption (AUDIT-C), and Single Alcohol Screening Question (SASQ). The AUDIT is a validated 10-item screening test that takes approximately 2 to 3 minutes to administer; the AUDIT-C is a briefer (three-item) version of the AUDIT. With single-item screening, the clinician asks, “How many times in the past year have you had five [four for women and persons aged >65 years] or more drinks in 1 day?” Patients with a positive screening result should be evaluated for alcohol use disorder and medical complications of excessive alcohol intake.
The USPSTF recommends screening for diabetes mellitus (
Option A

) in adults aged 35 to 70 years who are overweight or obese. The American Diabetes Association (ADA) recommends that screening be performed in patients of any age who are overweight or obese and have one or more risk factors for diabetes. The ADA also recommends screening all adults beginning at age 35 years, regardless of risk factors. This patient has no indication for diabetes screening.
According to the USPSTF, evidence is insufficient to assess the balance of benefits and harms of screening for obstructive sleep apnea (
Option C
) in asymptomatic adults with the currently available tools.
The USPSTF concludes that evidence is insufficient to recommend for or against screening for thyroid dysfunction (
Option D

). The American Thyroid Association and the American Association of Clinical Endocrinologists, however, recommend measuring thyroid-stimulating hormone in individuals at risk for hypothyroidism (e.g., personal history of autoimmune disease, neck radiation, or thyroid surgery); they additionally suggest considering screening in adults aged 60 years or older. This patient has no indication for thyroid function screening.

objective.__html: Screen a patient for hazardous drinking.

references: Curry SJ, Krist AH, Owens DK, et al; US Preventive Services Task Force. Screening and behavioral counseling interventions to reduce unhealthy alcohol use in adolescents and adults: US Preventive Services Task Force recommendation statement. JAMA. 2018;320:1899-909.

title: Question 118

children: A 33-year-old woman is evaluated for a 4-day history of increased vaginal discharge and itching. She is sexually active with men and has one partner. She takes an oral contraceptive pill for contraception. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago and was normal. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and she takes no other medication.
External genital examination reveals excoriations. Speculum examination reveals thick, white, odorless discharge. The cervix is normal appearing. Bimanual examination is unremarkable.
A pregnancy test result is negative.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

text.__html: Saline and potassium hydroxide wet mounts

children: Clinical findings do not sufficiently distinguish among the common causes of vaginitis, and laboratory testing is necessary to establish a diagnosis.

Diagnostic testing for vaginitis includes assessment of vaginal pH; amine (whiff) test; and microscopic evaluation of the specimen to look for clue cells on the wet mount and yeast, hyphae, and pseudohyphae on the potassium hydroxide preparation.
The most appropriate management is microscopic evaluation of saline and potassium hydroxide (KOH) wet mounts of the vaginal discharge (
Option D

). Vaginitis describes conditions associated with vulvovaginal symptoms that may include vaginal discharge, burning, itching, or odor. Vaginal discharge can be physiologic, related to ovulation or pregnancy, or infectious, most commonly bacterial vaginosis, candidiasis, or trichomoniasis. Other causes of vaginal discharge include irritation from use of douches, atrophic vaginitis, malignancy, or a foreign body. Physical examination includes assessment of the vulva and vagina for erythema, edema, excoriation, papillomas, and the type of discharge. However, clinical findings do not sufficiently distinguish among the common causes of vaginitis, and laboratory testing is necessary to establish a diagnosis. Diagnostic testing includes assessment of vaginal pH; amine (whiff) test; and microscopic evaluation of the specimen to look for clue cells on the wet mount and yeast, hyphae, and pseudohyphae on the KOH preparation. Occasionally, motile trichomonads can be visualized on a wet preparation, suggesting trichomoniasis; in these cases, antigen testing is recommended because it can be difficult to diagnose trichomoniasis on microscopy alone. If microscopy is unavailable, nucleic acid amplification testing for the common pathogens can assist with the diagnosis.
Intravaginal clotrimazole (
Option A
) and oral fluconazole (
Option B

) are appropriate treatments for a vaginal yeast infection. Although history and physical examination are important, the diagnosis should be confirmed. Vaginal yeast infections are confirmed by the presence of yeast, hyphae, or pseudohyphae on KOH wet mounts.
Oral metronidazole (
Option C

) is appropriate treatment for bacterial vaginosis and trichomoniasis, although the dose and duration differ. Bacterial vaginosis is diagnosed using the Amsel criteria, which requires presence of three of the following four criteria: vaginal pH greater than 4.5; thin, homogenous vaginal discharge; positive whiff test, and at least 20% clue cells on saline wet mount. Patients with trichomoniasis typically present with increased discolored vaginal discharge, dyspareunia, itching, and postcoital bleeding. The diagnosis of trichomoniasis is most secure after a positive saline wet mount and nucleic acid amplification test.

objective.__html: Evaluate a vaginal discharge.

references: Workowski KA, Bolan GA; Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Sexually transmitted diseases treatment guidelines, 2015. MMWR Recomm Rep. 2015;64:1-137.

title: Question 119

children: A 92-year-old woman is being discharged home in the care of her daughter after treatment for heart failure. Medical history is also significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Outpatient medications are lisinopril, carvedilol, atorvastatin, and furosemide. She is currently asymptomatic. At the time of discharge, physical examination shows no evidence of volume overload and laboratory studies are normal.
Which of the following factors is fundamental to a successful transition of care for this patient?

text.__html: Discharge planning by the hospital physician
Explicit communication with the primary care physician

children: Poor communication between inpatient and outpatient clinicians and between providers and patients is associated with increased risk for hospital readmission.
A multidisciplinary team approach to discharge planning decreases the risk for readmission.
The factor in this patient's hospital discharge process that is fundamental to a successful transition of care is explicit communication with the primary care physician (
Option B

). Poor communication between inpatient and outpatient clinicians and between clinicians and patients is associated with increased risk for hospital readmission. During transitions, physicians should strive to provide clear, concise, and accurate patient records to subsequent clinicians. Physicians must additionally educate patients and families on the expected course and red flag symptoms that necessitate reevaluation.

A multidisciplinary team approach to discharge planning should decrease this patient's risk for readmission. Transitions of care are enhanced when multidisciplinary teams, including those with a dedicated case manager, are used for hospital discharge planning. Discharge planning by the hospital physician (
Option A
) is an important and necessary element of successful transitions of care but by itself is often not sufficient.

Accurate medication reconciliation, although time consuming, is paramount to decreasing the likelihood of readmission because medication errors frequently occur with transitions of care. Medication reconciliation during this patient's discharge process is a crucial factor in reducing the risk for subsequent readmission. This may be performed by the discharging clinician or pharmacist; several studies have shown that medication reconciliation is most effective when performed by a pharmacist. Medication reconciliation performed by the patient's daughter alone (
Option C
) misses the opportunity for best practices associated with reducing premature hospital readmission.
The simple ordering of laboratory tests is not fundamental to a successful transition of care. Laboratory tests may not be necessary in the immediate postdischarge period (
Option D
), particularly if predischarge laboratory values were normal.

objective.__html: Manage transition of care at hospital discharge.

references: Kamermayer AK, Leasure AR, Anderson L. The effectiveness of transitions-of-care interventions in reducing hospital readmissions and mortality: a systematic review. Dimens Crit Care Nurs. 2017;36:311-6.

title: Question 120

children: A 62-year-old woman is evaluated for a 6-month history of intermittent, painful sores on the back of her hands that worsen with sun exposure. She has no other medical problems and takes no medications.
Skin findings are
shown
Skin punch biopsy results are pending.
Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test?
Porphyria cutanea tarda is a photosensitive disorder that present with scarring and blistering on sun-exposed skin, most commonly on the dorsal hands.
Porphyria cutanea tarda is most commonly associated with hepatitis C virus infection, alcohol-induced liver disease, and hemochromatosis.
The most appropriate diagnostic test is plasma and urine porphyrin levels (
Option D

). This patient likely has porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT), a photosensitive disorder that presents clinically with scarring and blistering on sun-exposed skin, most commonly the dorsal hands. Hyperpigmentation of the skin and hypertrichosis of the cheeks are also common. The photosensitivity is caused by excess porphyrins deposited in the skin that are sensitive to visible light, particularly the blue-light wavelength. PCT is the most common porphyria and typically presents in patients older than 40 years. Plasma and urine porphyrins should be measured to confirm the diagnosis of PCT to differentiate from pseudoporphyria, which presents similarly clinically but has normal plasma and urine porphyrin levels. Pseudoporphyria is commonly caused by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, tetracyclines, and diuretics. Although skin biopsy can be performed, pathology can be nonspecific and is not necessary. PCT is most commonly associated with hepatitis C virus infection, alcohol-induced liver disease, and hemochromatosis. Testing for other susceptibility factors, such as HIV and hemochromatosis, should also be considered. Treatment for PCT is phlebotomy or twice-weekly hydroxychloroquine.

Bullous lupus erythematosus is an uncommon skin manifestation of systemic lupus erythematosus. In this condition, vesicles and bullae are localized to the neck and upper trunk and also unexposed skin. Direct immunofluorescence testing of a skin biopsy is diagnostically helpful. Antinuclear antibody testing (
Option A

) is unlikely to help in the evaluation of bullous conditions because of its lack of specificity. This patient's blistering disease is confined to her hands and is not consistent with bullous lupus erythematosus.
Anti–tissue transglutaminase antibody testing (
Option B

) is the initial step in the diagnosis of dermatitis herpetiformis, an intensely pruritic bullous disease most commonly found on the elbows, knees, and buttocks that is associated with celiac disease. This patient's clinical findings are not consistent with dermatitis herpetiformis, and anti–tissue transglutaminase antibody testing is not needed.

The onset of bullous pemphigoid is usually in adults aged 60 years or older and presents with urticarial and eczematous lesions that progress to tense bullae on an erythematous base. The most common sites of involvement are the trunk, extremity flexures, and axillary and inguinal folds. Oral involvement is present in approximately 20% of patients. Antibody tests are helping for monitoring disease activity in patients with bullous pemphigoid. This patient's findings are not consistent with bullous pemphigoid, and antibody testing (
Option C
) is not appropriate.

objective.__html: Diagnose porphyria cutanea tarda.

references: Bissell DM, Anderson KE, Bonkovsky HL. Porphyria. N Engl J Med. 2017;377:862-72.

title: Question 121

children: This question has been updated as a result of postpublication analysis and/or new data that are relevant to the question.

A 65-year-old woman is evaluated during a wellness visit. She received the tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis vaccine 7 years ago; the 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine 6 years ago; the two-dose recombinant herpes zoster vaccine (spaced 7 months apart) 3 years ago; and the influenza vaccine during the most recent influenza season. She has also been vaccinated against COVID-19. Her medical history is unremarkable. She is a current smoker with a 35–pack-year history and is planning to quit. She does not use alcohol or recreational drugs. She has no plans for international travel. She takes no medications.
After a discussion of risks and benefits, the patient wants to receive all age-appropriate vaccinations.
Which of the following is the most appropriate vaccine to administer at this visit?
Eligible patients who previously received the 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine should undergo vaccination with either of the pneumococcal conjugate vaccines.
The most appropriate vaccine to administer at this visit is the 20-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV20) (
Option C

). According to the CDC Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP), adults aged 65 years or older should receive either the PCV20 alone or the 15-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV15) followed by the 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23) at least 1 year later. Patients aged 19 to 64 years with underlying medical conditions or immunocompromise should also undergo vaccination. Eligible patients who previously received the PPSV23, such as this patient, should receive either of the pneumococcal conjugate vaccines. If PCV15 is used, follow-up vaccination with PPSV23 would not be necessary, as this patient has already received PPSV23. This patient meets the age criteria for vaccination and also has an underlying medical condition (cigarette smoking) that would prompt vaccination regardless of age. The ACIP does not recommend revaccination with PPSV23 (
Option D
). PPSV23 administration would be indicated only if she had previously received PCV15 to complete the PCV15/PPSV23 series.
The ACIP recommends that adults aged 50 years or older receive the two-dose recombinant herpes zoster vaccine (
Option A

) administered 2 to 6 months apart. Although this patient received her doses 7 months apart, this is not expected to decrease the efficacy of the vaccine series; a third dose is not indicated for this patient.
The tetanus and diphtheria toxoids (Td) vaccine (
Option B

) is not indicated for this patient at this visit. The Td is indicated every 10 years, with at least one dose replaced by the tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine. This patient received the Tdap vaccine 7 years ago and will not be due for her next Td vaccination until age 68 years.

objective.__html: Manage pneumococcal vaccination in a person older than 65 years.

references: Murthy N, Wodi AP, Bernstein H, et al; Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices. Recommended adult immunization schedule, United States, 2022.

children: Ann Intern Med

title: Question 122

children: A 72-year-old man is evaluated for recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs). He is currently asymptomatic. Seven days ago, he presented with dysuria, urgency, and suprapubic pain. A urine culture was obtained, and he was started on empiric trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. This is his third UTI in 12 months. All previous urine cultures grew
Escherichia coli

sensitive to trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. All episodes were treated with a 7-day course of antibiotics, with rapid resolution of symptoms. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and he takes no other medications.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. Digital rectal examination reveals a nontender prostate with no bogginess. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable.
Urine culture shows growth of
E. coli
sensitive to trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

text.__html: Prostatic massage followed by urine culture

children: Chronic bacterial prostatitis commonly manifests as recurrent lower urinary tract infections with the same organism.
Patients with chronic bacterial prostatitis require an extended course (at least 4-6 weeks) of antimicrobial therapy that has good prostatic tissue penetration and covers the causative organism.
The most appropriate management is a 6-week course of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (
Option C

). This patient has chronic bacterial prostatitis. Chronic bacterial prostatitis involves persistent prostate infection lasting longer than 3 months. It commonly manifests as recurrent lower urinary tract infections (UTIs) with the same organism. On digital rectal examination, the prostate may be normal, tender, and/or boggy. It is not uncommon for these patients to have a normal digital rectal examination, especially between UTI episodes or during treatment. Patients with chronic bacterial prostatitis require an extended treatment course (at least 4-6 weeks) of antimicrobial therapy that has good prostatic tissue penetration and covers the causative organism. This patient's urine cultures have repeatedly grown
Escherichia coli

sensitive to trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, which has excellent prostatic tissue penetration and is an appropriate antibiotic choice for this patient. A fluoroquinolone, such as ciprofloxacin or levofloxacin, is also often a viable treatment option.
CT of the prostate (
Option A

) is not indicated at this time. CT is helpful in identifying prostate abscess in patients with acute bacterial prostatitis in whom appropriate antimicrobial therapy has failed. This patient has improved with each course of antibiotics, making chronic bacterial prostatitis more likely than a prostate abscess.
Prostatic massage followed by urine culture (
Option B

) has diagnostic utility in patients with chronic bacterial prostatitis because it may lead to identification of a causative organism when an organism cannot be identified by standard urine culture. In this patient, urine culture has identified
E. coli
as the causative organism for each UTI episode, obviating the need for prostatic massage followed by urine culture.
No additional treatment (
Option D

) will probably result in a cycle of recurrent infections and is not the best strategy for this patient. A prolonged treatment cycle with an antibiotic selected by culture sensitivity findings is recommended for patients with chronic bacterial prostatitis.

objective.__html: Treat a patient with chronic bacterial prostatitis.

references: Gill BC, Shoskes DA. Bacterial prostatitis. Curr Opin Infect Dis. 2016;29:86-91.

title: Question 123

children: A 40-year-old woman is evaluated during a routine wellness visit. She asks about breast cancer screening. She has no medical problems or concerning family history, including no history of breast cancer, and has no risk factors for breast cancer.
On physical examination, breast examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most reasonable breast cancer screening management strategy for this patient?

Although screening mammography in women aged 40 to 49 years may reduce the risk for breast cancer death, the number of deaths averted is smaller than that in older women and the number of false-positive results and unnecessary biopsies is larger.

For patients younger than 50 years who are interested in breast cancer screening, shared decision making that includes consideration of the patient's level of risk, values, and preferences is a reasonable strategy to inform the screening decision.
The most appropriate initial breast cancer screening management strategy for this patient is engagement in shared decision making (
Option D

). This patient is younger than 50 years and is at average risk for breast cancer. Women at average risk include those without family history of breast cancer or prior irradiation therapy to the chest region. Guidelines from multiple specialty societies and the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) unanimously encourage annual or biennial screening mammography in women beginning at age 50 years. Although screening mammography in women aged 40 to 49 years may reduce the risk for breast cancer death, the number of deaths averted is smaller than that in older women and the number of false-positive results and unnecessary biopsies is larger. In addition to false-positive results and unnecessary biopsies, all women undergoing regular screening mammography are at risk for the diagnosis and treatment of noninvasive and invasive breast cancer that would otherwise not have become a threat to their health, or even apparent, during their lifetime (overdiagnosis). Beginning mammography screening at a younger age and screening more frequently may increase the risk for overdiagnosis and subsequent overtreatment. For patients younger than 50 years who are interested in screening, shared decision making is a reasonable strategy. Shared decision making includes consideration of the patient's level of risk, values, and preferences that will help inform the screening decision.
Breast MRI (
Option A

) is not currently recommended as first-line strategy for breast cancer screening because data are limited to suggest it lowers breast cancer mortality when utilized in women at average risk, such as this patient.
The USPSTF concludes that the current evidence is insufficient to assess the benefits and harms of digital breast tomosynthesis (
Option B
) as a primary screening method for breast cancer, and digital breast tomosynthesis is therefore not a reasonable option for this patient.
Although mammography (
Option C

) is the imaging modality of choice for breast cancer screening in average-risk patients, the benefit and harms of screening are very finely balanced in patients younger than 50 years. Before mammography is offered, a shared decision-making approach should be undertaken with this young patient at average risk for breast cancer.

objective.__html: Use shared decision making in breast cancer screening discussions.

references: Siu AL; U.S. Preventive Services Task Force. Screening for breast cancer: U.S. preventive services task force recommendation statement.

Medical history is significant for obesity, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus. Medications are metoprolol, amlodipine, metformin (withheld preoperatively), and hydromorphone.
On physical examination, temperature is 37 °C (98.7 °F), blood pressure is 149/88 mm Hg, pulse rate is 89/min, and respiration rate is 16/min. While awake and upright,

intermittently dips to 88% on 2 L of oxygen. BMI is 42. His neck is large. On pulmonary examination, lungs are clear. The abdomen is soft and protuberant, with a large pannus.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

text.__html: Elevate head of the bed and limit sedating medications
Start bilevel positive airway pressure ventilation

children: All surgical patients should be screened preoperatively for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA); a commonly used screening tool for OSA is the STOP-BANG score.

Initial perioperative risk-reduction strategies for a patient at high risk for obstructive sleep apnea include continuous pulse oximetry monitoring, elevation of the head of the bed, and limiting sedating medications.
The most appropriate management is to continue pulse oximetry monitoring, elevate the head of bed, and limit sedating medications (
Option B

). This hospitalized patient has oxygen desaturations that correspond with his physical position and sleep status but no examination findings suggestive of a primary pulmonary process. He has several risk factors for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), including an elevated BMI, hypertension, snoring, a large neck, and male sex. This clinical scenario is most consistent with OSA-related desaturations in the setting of supine positioning and somnolence due to recent anesthesia. OSA is exceedingly common in both men and women older than 50 years, and it remains undiagnosed in the majority of patients with the condition. Before surgery, all patients should be screened for OSA, which is associated with adverse perioperative outcomes, including cardiac events, pulmonary complications, and ICU admissions. A commonly used preoperative screening tool for OSA is the STOP-BANG score (1 point each for Snoring, Tiredness, Observed apneas, elevated blood Pressure, BMI >35, Age >50 years, Neck circumference >40 cm, and male Gender).

Although postoperative pulmonary embolism can occur, this patient has neither consistent hypoxemia nor tachycardia and, most important, has an excellent alternative explanation for his symptoms. Chest CT angiography (
Option A
) should not be pursued unless clinical findings to suggest pulmonary embolism emerge.
Given the absence of wheezing on examination and no history of obstructive pulmonary disease, there is no indication for a β-agonist bronchodilator, such as albuterol (
Option C
Continuous or bilevel positive pressure therapy (
Option D

) is effective for established OSA; however, there is objective evidence that this patient will likely respond to conservative measures. Positive pressure ventilation should be reserved for a lack of response or clinical worsening. However, after hospital discharge, evaluation for OSA is indicated.
Starting empiric antibiotics (
Option E

) is not indicated because there is no evidence of infection. Although bacterial pneumonia can occur after surgery, it would not become clinically apparent in anesthesia recovery, and this patient has no features consistent with pneumonia.

objective.__html: Treat obstructive sleep apnea in the postanesthesia care unit.

references: Chung F, Memtsoudis SG, Ramachandran SK, et al. Society of Anesthesia and Sleep Medicine guidelines on preoperative screening and assessment of adult patients with obstructive sleep apnea. Anesth Analg. 2016;123:452-73.

title: Question 125

children: A 26-year-old man is evaluated for redness of the left eye accompanied by yellow discharge and crusting on the eyelids for the past 2 days. The symptoms are most noticeable upon awakening. He reports some visual blurring that clears with blinking. The right eye is uninvolved. He reports no other symptoms. He does not wear contact lenses. Medical history is unremarkable, and he takes no medications.

On physical examination, there is diffuse circumferential conjunctival erythema of the left eye that is most noticeable peripherally. A small amount of dried, yellow discharge is noted on the superior and inferior eyelashes. Visual acuity is 20/30 in both eyes. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Acute bacterial conjunctivitis, most commonly caused by
Staphylococcus aureus
, typically presents with several days of unilateral diffuse conjunctival redness and mucopurulent discharge.
Hyperacute bacterial conjunctivitis is a potentially vision-threatening condition caused by
Neisseria gonorrhea
infection and is characterized by rapid onset of profuse purulent discharge and diffuse bright red conjunctival hemorrhage.
The most likely diagnosis is acute bacterial conjunctivitis (
Option A
). In adults,
Staphylococcus aureus

is most commonly implicated. Bacterial conjunctivitis is highly contagious and is usually spread by person-to-person contact or through contact with contaminated surfaces. Patients most commonly present with several days of unilateral diffuse conjunctival redness and discharge, although bilateral involvement may occur. The discharge is frequently mucopurulent and accompanied by eyelid debris and matting, which is worse upon awakening. Patients, such as this one, may also have visual blurring that improves with blinking; overt changes in visual acuity do not occur.
Patients with blepharitis (
Option B

) typically present with chronic symptoms characterized by red, swollen, or itchy eyelids; ocular gritty sensation; and crusting of eyelashes in the morning. Because of the accompanying disordered tear composition, affected patients may develop eye irritation and excessive tear production. This patient's primary symptoms are acute eye redness and discharge without eyelid involvement, which is not consistent with blepharitis.
Hyperacute bacterial conjunctivitis (
Option C
) is a potentially vision-threatening condition caused by
Neisseria gonorrhea

infection. It is characterized by rapid onset of profuse purulent discharge and diffuse bright red conjunctival hemorrhage. If untreated, it can progress to corneal ulceration. This patient's symptoms are relatively mild and do not support a diagnosis of hyperacute bacterial conjunctivitis.
Although scleritis (
Option D
) causes diffuse eye redness, it is typically accompanied by severe eye pain, visual disturbance, photophobia, and watery discharge, which are not present in this patient.
Viral conjunctivitis (
Option E

), most commonly caused by adenovirus, frequently occurs in the setting of upper respiratory tract symptoms. Patients with viral conjunctivitis often present with eye redness and clear, watery discharge that frequently begins unilaterally and eventually progresses to bilateral ocular involvement. On examination, preauricular lymphadenopathy is common. This patient has unilateral purulent discharge, which is not consistent with viral conjunctivitis.

objective.__html: Diagnose acute bacterial conjunctivitis.

references: Varu DM, Rhee MK, Akpek EK, et al; American Academy of Ophthalmology Preferred Practice Pattern Cornea and External Disease Panel. Conjunctivitis Preferred Practice Pattern®. Ophthalmology. 2019;126:P94-169.

title: Question 126

children: A 65-year-old woman is evaluated for a mole beneath the right eye that has been present for several months but appears to be growing.

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Nodular basal cell carcinoma typically presents as a pearly or translucent nodule or papule with arborizing telangiectasias and may have a central depression or ulceration with a rolled waxy border.
A small portion of basal cell carcinomas contain pigment and can mimic a malignant melanoma; biopsy is often needed to confirm the diagnosis.
The most likely diagnosis is pigmented basal cell carcinoma (BCC) (
Option B

). Nodular BCC typically presents as a pearly or translucent nodule or papule with arborizing telangiectasias. It may have a central depression or ulceration with a rolled waxy border. About 6% of BCCs are pigmented, such as this one, which has dark brown pigment along the superior border of the tumor and a dot of pigment located at the middle of the inferior border. Pigmented BCCs are more common in patients with darker skin. Pigmented BCCs are a low-risk BCC subtype. However, they can mimic malignant melanoma, and biopsy is necessary to differentiate them. Although they have low mortality, significant local tissue destruction can occur if not treated. Mohs micrographic surgery is a surgical technique that enhances the ability to leave surgical margins free of tumor and at the same time minimize the resection of normal tissue. Compared with standard excision, Mohs micrographic surgery is associated with a reduced rate of tumor recurrence. Mohs micrographic surgery is usually reserved for skin cancers that have a high risk for recurrence or for tumors located in areas where minimal destruction of tissue is of cosmetic or functional importance. For the lesion on this patient's face near the eye, Mohs micrographic surgery would be recommended for the best chance of complete tumor eradication and cosmetic outcomes.
Because of the asymmetry and color variation of this patient's lesion, malignant melanoma (
Option A

) could be considered in the differential diagnosis. However, the rolled borders of this patient's lesion and pearly translucent nature of the tumor are features of BCC and stand in contrast to the berry-like appearance of nodular melanoma (as
shown
Biopsy should be performed to confirm the diagnosis. The most likely diagnosis in this patient, however, is a pigmented BCC.
Seborrheic keratosis (
Option C

) is a benign skin growth, often on the trunk in older adults. It is usually hyperpigmented from brown to black in color. Unlike this patient's lesion, seborrheic keratosis presents as a well-circumscribed, keratotic, “stuck-on” papule.
Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) (
Option D

) of the skin is the second most common skin cancer. SCC typically presents as hyperkeratotic, indurated papules or plaques in sun-exposed areas. SCC does not typically have pigmentation or the rolled borders seen in this patient's lesion.

objective.__html: Diagnose pigmented basal cell carcinoma.

references: Kim DP, Kus KJ, Ruiz E. Basal cell carcinoma review. Hematol Oncol Clin North Am. 2019;33:13-24.
